description:
All of these for $6 (ONLY)
2 shrimp gow: sticky and chewy and soft in the most delicious way. There's one huge shrimp in each piece which is great!
1 sesame ball: sticky and chewy and not too sweet, which is a plus. There's plenty of red bean paste in there. The sesame gives it an aromatic smell. 
1 congee: what a great congee! Not bland and not too intense. This will be great for when you're sick or just want something mellow to eat for breakfast. A whole tub is only $3.50 with pieces of meat and 1,000 years egg in it. Love it so much! 
There are a handful of seatings inside the store so you can enjoy your food then and there!

Totally going to come back.
author: Yuan Z.

description:
I love Wing Lee! 

Disclaimer: I am by no means a dim sum expert. 

That being said I've been trying it more and more at different places and I still like Wing Lee the best. The food is good and the prices are fair. I especially like the shrimp gao. They also have these peanut balls (I don't know the real name, but I ask for the "peanut ball" and they know what I'm talking about) that are also really good, especially with some sriracha!
author: Emma B.

description:
Was in San Francisco last week and stopped by Wing Lee Bakery for some dim sum.  Got some shrimp har gow, pork siu mai, and joong to go.

I wanted to give it 3 and a half stars but Yelp doesn't have half stars.  So I upped it to 4 stars.  One thing I'll say it the dumplings, siu mai, and joong are huge.  Yep, not the typical tiny dim sum you find at other restaurants.
Also, it's refreshing to find joong outside of the Chinese dragon festival dates in the spring.  They're bamboo wrapped glutinous rice with fillings of pork, 1,000 year old egg (they're not really 1,000 years old..lol), dried shrimp, and other things.   

The shrimp har gow had dough that was way too thick in my opinion. Sui mai was fine.  Joong was ok. Prices were "ok" but with all the competition in SF, there are less expensive options like Good Luck Dim Sum on Clement Street.
author: Dana H.

description:
First of all this dim sum place has the rudest unhelpful staff ever. They bark at you to order, plus they will bark at you to ask how many items. Don't you dare say 1 order of whatever even though the menu has a whole section indicating dim sum items that come 3 to 1 order. Plus don't you dare ask questions on what things are...they will bypass you and you will be the fonder for the staff and all the Cantonese seniors citizens enjoying their dim sum and the cinema of life. The food most likely contains MSG. I do not suggest this place for dim sum newbies. If this was your first experience, it would definitely put you off of dim sum forever.

However I could overlook the rudeness if the food was great. But alas the majority of dim sum was blah and some items were plain disgusting. 

The bad...the egg custard and fried pork dumpling were yucky. The egg custard filling had a strange odor and sour taste. Took a teeny tiny nibble and tossed it. Yuck. The fried pork was hard and burnt with tasteless filling. I took one bite and tossed it. Yuck. Considering these were the first two items I attempted to eat...it didn't look promising. 

The good...not much to report out. Here it goes...Sui mai was hefty sized and decent tasting. Same with the har gow and fried sesame balls. They were ok, not great tasting. 

Also it is more of a grab n good place with a few tables usually occupied by the neighborhood seniors.
author: Lillian W.

description:
What! No BBQ pork buns at 11am? Oh well shrimp hargaw pork potstickers will have to suffice. Really good pork ginger pot stickers. Busting with porky juiciness tempered by sweet onion and ginger. 
Also tried a shrimp veg dumpling that was also light and yummy.
Shrimp hargaw had bug plump shrimp inside.
If you know what you want this place is great. Cheep no frills. Chili sauce in red catsup bottles and soy. They give you a plastic fork sans chopsticks. Easy snack right out of the plastic container. 
Perfect before taking on presidio golf course.
author: Craig G.

description: Wing Lee is the best place to get dim sum in the city. Small, cash only place but the workers are quick and will get you out of there in no time. Food quality is phenomenal.
author: Ali E.

description: Cheap, quick spot for dim sum. The portions were large, and the prices were reasonable. I ordered their lotus sticky rice, siu mai, and ha gao. I was impressed with the quality, so I'd recommend coming here if you're ever craving dim sum.
author: Aileen J.

description: Standard cheap takeout dim sum. Sure it doesn't taste as good as a proper teahouse, but it's also cheaper and damn near instant gratification. Cash only. The line goes quick.
author: Misha T.

description:
Love the dim sum shops on Clement St. Wing Lee always has a long line but you know why, cheap prices and delish dim sum. Don't expect a welcoming 'hello' or come on in from the counter help, they are there to serve hundreds of customers thousands of dim sum pieces in their 8 hr day, 'get em in and get em out- Fast'
Baked chicken bao is pillowy soft, sweet glaze on top, 5 Spice and hoisin flavors surround the chicken - I scarfed this before even getting to the car.  Shrimp dumplings and shrimp and leek dumplings are outrageous, large shrimp pieces, tender, crunchy and so fresh. Dumpling is tender soft from steaming - yummy.  Taro balls flavorful, crunchy exterior but greasy, because it's fried, duh, is is the sesame ball which is sweet and the bean paste is ever so smooth.
author: Rhondi S.

description:
Skip Good Luck and come here instead! GL was closed so we walked to this place on a whim....I'll never go back to Good Luck after eating at Wing Lee. Their Dim Sum is just plain better. More flavorful-every single thing we had was better than GL. 

Look no further for SF dim sum.
author: Steve S.

description: Was stralling nearby when this bakery caught my eye. Tried boiled leek shrimp gow and would say it was pretty good. The price was also low which was the best part. I guess it is shrimp with spring onions and the covering is of refined flour.
author: Sharad B.

description:
I was going to go to Good Luck dim sum but tha line was snaked all the way to the kitchen. So I drop in here to buy steamed BBQ pork buns, potstickers and shrimp and chive dumpling. Their shrimp and chive dumplings are the biggest I've seen outside Chinatown. At almost $1 a pc, it's not cheap either. However, it's a little reward for yourself when you need to cheer yourself up no?

BBQ pork steam buns are good. Service is perfunctory.
author: Wendy H.

description: Good fresh dim sum. Can have long lines as many local shop and get their food from here. Us uji ally when you have old Chinese customers it means that their food is good, which it is.
author: Andrew M.

description: Very good take-out dim sum (especially the sesame balls and black bean rice cakes; for savory I like the coriander gow and tofu skin rolls). Service is not so friendly but is efficient, which is important because the line can be long.
author: Katya F.

description: We were in the area and thought about checking this place out.  The shrimp gow and shumai were really good.  We also tried the baked and steam bbq pork bun.  The food was good and the service was fast.
author: Matthew G.

description: Delicious dim sum to go. Everything we ordered tasted pretty fresh. Would recommend for a quick and easy snack / lunch. Ordered the shrimp dumplings, siu mai, chicken and pork buns.
author: Casey P.

description:
Cheap, good and fast. That's Wing Lee. It's been on Clement since I was a kid. When you're hungry for some quick dim sum to-go or a bite real quick at communal tables, this is your spot. The furthest from fancy. It's a hole in the wall type spot...I get siu mai, pot stickers, har gow and bbq pork buns. So good. So simple... So inexpensive. Put it this way. We ordered: 2 bbq pork buns, 3 siu mai and 3 pot stickers. It was under $10.

Service is fast. You better be ready. I'm convinced the ladies are cussing me out in their native tongue cause I dont give my order in full right away. Hahaha.... Sorry! I couldnt make up my mind and everything looks good. Give me a break... lol

Street parking. Feed the meter along Clement. You may get lucky on the side streets.
author: Chuck D.

description:
This place is cheap. Fast. Amazing and you need to get here early!
I recommend the rice balls and steamed dumplings. They make a vault of them per day and usually sell out before 1030am.
author: Miguel E.

description: One of the freshest dim sum on Clemente St and it's so affordable. You get 3 shrimp gow for $2.30. You can't beat that cause the fancy dim sum places are double the price. I love the local feel and food is still amazing till this day. The aroma of this place still has the nostalgic feeling when I was just a kid walking down the streets with my Lola and the lingering freshness before we entered is bittersweet. Service still has genuine people who still care about there customers. I will definitely still come back for my dim sum craving!
author: Amanda E.

description:
I really enjoy this place- I go all the time!  I love the chicken jook and the crispy spring rolls.  The dim sum is good ~ I would have given it four stars but there was he one time I had my change practically thrown at me. If you're looking to be treated well - don't bother. If you want decent dim sum for a decent price in the Richmond - you found it!

Update 3/1/2018 - one of the ladies behind the counter recognized me - she said hi and smiled!! After 3 years - almost every weekend - sometimes 2x week!! It was an amazing feeling! It's like they finally acknowledged me!!
author: Marcia K.

description: This is my favorite Dim Sum on clement. There's lots of options, and I know everyone has their favorites, but this is mine because they are consistently good and still a great price. Been coming her for at least a decade. I like the shrimp gow. Cash only.
author: Hit And Run P.

description:
Cheap, tasty, quick, Chinese bakery.  got my fill of dumplings, congee, and steamed and baked BBQ buns.

Came in Sunday morning at 8:30am and there was already a lineup. 

If you're in the neighborhood check it out!
author: Chris O.

description: Every year we visit SF, and every year we set aside a day to visit Wing Lee for some delicious dim sum. I like the sticky rice, pot stickers, and siew mai. J also likes their gow. The place is small, with only five tables, but it's worth a trip to get some inexpensive, delicious dim sum. The food at their sister restaurant next door is also tasty and cheap.
author: Veronica S.

description:
While on a Monday in SF, decided to grab a few baked Chinese pork bun (char siu bao). Didnt want to go to Chinatown, so yelped and found this place open on Monday.  Found most Chinese restaurants and/or bakery's are closed on Monday and/or Tuesday's.

After a car backing out almost hit us. (Driver apparently backing out didn't see the stopped car on street (waiting for traffic to move forward), made one more round and found a space and fed the meter. Upon entering this corner bakery and placed an order of 8 baked BBQ  baos and 4 baked BBQ chicken baos. But they only had BBQ pork buns. So just got 8 buns for $12.00 ($1.50/ea)

Very disappointed. Bun was dry and smaller than our regular go to SF Bakery.  The filling was minimal, dry, less fat pieces (yes I like bits of fat in it), sweet sauce surrounding the pork mini bits was average, but good.  It was more bread than filling. It took a few bites to get to meat.   After a day, the top bun crust became rock hard too. Literally tapped on it and it was hard.

As a visiting out of towner, very I hoped for better as I don't frequent the city to often. So this foodie purchase was a bust :(
author: Chefs Daughter D.

description:
I'm a sucker for cheap dim sum spots - found this place on Yelp and decided to scope it out, especially after seeing a few posts about their sticky rice balls.  

The inside of the shop looks like your standard "dim sum to go" joint - glass cases filled with pastries and large metal steamers with dim sum staying nice and cozy inside.  There are several workers behind the counter taking orders.  The line was about 4 or 5 deep when I got there, but it moved within a reasonable pace.  There are a few tables (large and small) inside the shop if you decide to eat there rather than taking it to go.  I was a little surprised to find a bathroom (half the time, these hole in the wall Chinese places have no public restroom) present.  

As I inched closer to the front of the line, I started noticing that the worker was taking the dim sum from the counter and heating it up in the microwave.  Egggghhhhhhhhhh.  I don't think I've ever been at a food joint (excluding fast food) where the food was microwaved in front of me.  This was strange - I wasn't quite sure what to make of it.  It looked like the party in front of me was ordering various items, and with each item they picked, the worker tossed the dim sum onto the microwave plate and nuked it.  It would then be piled onto a pizza tray with the rest of the dim sum and served that way (presentation wasn't that great).  I guess this is how a large order of food is served if you're not taking it to go.  This scene just felt very unappetizing :(  

Anyway, I ordered my sticky rice balls - came out to about 80 cents each.  I was a little confused that they tossed it into a small plastic bag rather than a box of some sort.  I really think this place is trying to cut down on costs (i.e. serving food piled on a reusable pizza tray).  I think it's fine/great to be eco-friendly, but sometimes these things make me wonder what's happening in the back kitchen.  The rice ball tasted OK.  While it's the first time I've had (or even seen) sticky rice in a ball format, I felt like other sticky rice I've had was much better - those were more flavorful and usually comes out much hotter.  This version just wasn't memorable.  

Overall, I may be back to try other things.  Unfortunately, the microwaving just left a funny taste in my mind.  We'll see.
author: Laura C.

description:
A standard, dependable, perpetually busy dim sum diner where you line up, tell them your order, and pay in cash. Stalwarts like har gow, siu mai, and dan tat are very decent and cheap, although given the inexpensive prices, you get what you pay for in terms of quality. 

Not a bad choice if you want a dim sum fix that's cheap, fast, to go.
author: Vincent L.

description: Simple rules, order in 3's, if you want your noodles heated up say so, try to stay under $10 a person (even though we all know that we can easily put away more) and make sure you get some extra hot sauce for 25c.
author: Mike V.

description: Delicious!! We went overboard, despite being seasoned customers. Fave items were a peanut pork dumpling & the post stickers. Service was fabulously efficient, per usual.
author: Twinstar G.

description: A few weekends ago we did a taste test to compare the a few different highly rated dim sum places.  I'd been to Wing Lee many times before and had to include them.  Far and way these are the best pork buns by far.  In fact these are my favorite pork buns anywhere.  You can't go wrong with the baked or the steamed.  Egg rolls and potstickers aren't bad either, but the clear star are the pork buns.
author: Scott D.

description:
BEST DIN SUM PLACE IN SF I get all my dim sum from them weekly def recommend!

Their siew mai and ha gow are my go to I tend to get enough for my family each time

Parking can be a hassle but it's def worth it to get some
author: Chiu H.

description:
When you go to Wing Lee, you should know what to expect, it being one of the classic Clement street take out dim sum places. It's a quick moving, get in, get out dim sum place where you can get a meal for 4 for about five bucks.

The service, as such, isn't great, but the point of the establishment isn't the service. It's the food. Know what to order as soon as you get in line, if not, just point at some random thing that looks good, and chances are, it will. Knowing Cantonese helps. The steamed char siu bao are my favorite in the city, and everything else is pretty damn good too.
author: Griffin S.

description: Great spring to the bao, chicken meat was tasty (kinda like good luck dim sum's chicken over rice #conspiracy). Really enjoyable overall, little pricey? Not sure, but good value.
author: Ruobin W.

description:
Tasty, no frills dim sum place. It's cheap and cash only! The service was quick (especially if you can speak Chinese) and there's a few tables to eat at inside.

I got a small box filled with dumplings, shumai, and a BBQ pork bun all for $8. I really liked the shrimp dumplings in particular. They also sell some desserts too that looked pretty good. Overall great deal!
author: Linda X.

description: This is a great place to get disrespected. If you don't speak Chinese, be prepared to get constant eye rolls and rude service. A+ for rudeness
author: Chad D.

description:
Wow, I'm really surprised at the 4 star review. This place is mediocre at best, and totally skimps on the ingredients. We ordered the typical stuff - steamed BBQ pork bun, shrimp, pork and chive dumplings. The BBQ bun had a ton of bread and very little meat - we had to take several bites of the bun before getting to the pork filling. The shrimp dumplings were the same - they had a TON of flour/skin and maybe three teeny tiny little shrimp inside. We felt like we just ate a ton of white flour. The pork dumplings were decent.

We only came here because Good Luck dim sum is closed on Tuesdays. So unless you're dying for dim sum on a Tuesday, go to Good Luck dim sum (which is just two blocks away) instead!
author: Cee J.

description:
It was only fitting to celebrate the Chinese New Year with some dim sum! My boyfriend and I decided to try a new spot, opposed to our go-to Good Luck Dim Sum down the block. Even though we decided to try a new place, we still ended up ordering the same things. New year, same order. The 3 for $2.20 deal is a steal! We usually go for the shrimp gow, shrimp and leek gow, pork shumai, potstickers, and 2 custard buns. We also went halfsies on a pork bun, which was filled with sweet pork. All pretty tasty. You can expect to spend less than $15 to feed 2 starving people. 

I like how this place is cleaner than most restaurants on this block. Also has lots of tables to sit, which is good for larger groups. Overall, a good pick for some cheap authentic dim sum. Gung hay fat choy!
author: Rachelle Y.

description: If I had to choose an animal to represent Wing Lee Bakery I would choose a koala because of it is EXTREME koalaty!!!!!!! For the a few dollars, you can get some B-O-M-B dim sum! I go every Sunday morning and the wait is super short, with extremely fast service. Even if there is a line - it goes by very quickly, but there is usually no line. I love getting the giant [AND I MEAN GIANT] fluffy pork buns. SO GOOD. It is like eating a delicious meat filled cloud of goodness - and it's only $1.30.... Pretty cheap for maximal satisfaction. Other things I've tried there is the potstickers and the pork and chive dumplings - both which are delicious, hot and steamy dim sum delicacies. Anyways - the pork bun is the star of the show. Even eating it a couple days later after it being in the fridge, it still taste good. I definitely would recommend this place for anyone who is around the area and needs a quick delicious pick me up. Beware: CASH ONLY!
author: Anna L.

description:
I've had breakfast at 3 Chinese "bakeries" in San Francisco. Had congee (they all have 2 kinds) and something else plus Tea with Milk.  Well only on has tea with milk although here you can get tea & do your own milk.  The quality of the congee & rest of the food was about the same in all three. The exception for this place is that it's relatively clean, while the other 2 were not places I would take woman to. 

Anyway, breakfast at 8am for ~$6, these bakeries are it.
author: Leung T.

description: Five stars for the BBQ pork and roast duck! Tried three of their banana leaf wrapped sticky rice, and my fave was the one with mung beans and pork. The rice was not as sticky as I expected and flavor was a tad bland. Their BBQ buns are huge, not a lot of filling inside. The chicken buns were also huge but lacking in flavor. I'd still come back for their BBQ items. Price is great for all the food you get!
author: Mei W.

description: Har gow and Chinese sausage bun are by far the best items here. Come early to get the fresh stuff. You won't regret it.
author: Alex H.

description:
Been coming here since I was a child. Out of all the things constantly changing in the inner Richmond, wing lee dim sum is my ride or die. The dim sum
is bomb af here. That's it.
author: Jazzmin A.

description: Good local dim sum in the Clement area. Just gotta get here when it opens. Ladies at the counter can be intimidating, due to their demeanor. But if you know what to order, you're golden. Chicken dim sum is very good. Love their veggie pot stickers. Missed out on the baked pineapple buns, but was able to score on their cocktail bun. Which is yum  If you're from out of town, you should definitely try. Rule of thumb, come early.
author: Barbara P.

description:
I used to skip this place in favor of Good Luck, Gourmet, or Xiao Long Bao. Can't remember why.  Maybe I thought their cha siu bows weren't all that. 

But I just grabbed a few items, and hey, they're pretty good! The shark fin gow (don't worry, they are just pork and mushroom dumplings shaped kinda like a shark) were full of filling. And not as greasy/fatty as Good Luck's. 

Good selection, short line, old auntie enjoying her jook, fair prices for Clement Street. I'll put it back on my list of to go dim sum joints.
author: JJ H.

description:
I'm hooked on their jook.

Allergies aggravated by a cold led me to Wing Lee Bakery. 

$3 for a huge to go container of their chicken porridge does wonders to the body. Nothing is as comforting as a hot bowl of mushed up rice with some meat in it. 

Their dimsum is fresh from the steamers: we love the har gow and siu mai the best. 3 pieces for $2.30 seem a bit steep to me, but I'll take Wing Lee over any place in Chinatown. 

Parking sucks, but that doesn't apply if you're buying dimsum that costs less than the price of a gallon of gas. Or you can take Muni. Your pick.
author: Janice C.

description:
Based on a recommendation from SF Eater and Chef Charles Bililies (of Souvla) I came back to Wing Lee to try out the chicken bun - something I've never had before. Turns out to be a good idea. A giant steamed bun ($1.20 - they were out of the baked buns) with tender braised dark meat chicken chunks inside. Nom nom. 

The ladies here prefer to speak Chinese so if you understand it's to your advantage.

CASH ONLY
author: Jean K.

description:
I love this place. I come here for breakfast whenever I'm driving by or am in the area. It's a cheap dim sum place in SF; I've never seen them reheat my dim sum and they're stored in huge bamboo steamers. Go in, order your food, and enjoy the fact that you spent x amount of less dollars here rather than on fancy SF brunch. Cash only. 

I forgot the specific price (my guess is 1.60/order), but each order has three pieces (except the larger stuff like Cha Siu Bao). I usually get the siu mai, har gow (shrimp dumpling) and lo mai bao (steamed rice ball), with Cha Siu Bao. They'll combine your dim sum in clear plastic containers and bag it for you. The line moves quickly and efficiently. Enough said.
author: Amanda H.

description: Yay for BBQ pork bun. Mehhh for pineapple bun. Hella cheap though. I'd go back for dim sum.
author: Kelly G.

description: I've enjoyed the dim sum at Wing Lee for over 30 years. It's always consistent and never disappoints. The restaurant isn't fancy but the food is amazing. They serve the biggest steamed bao I've ever seen. The shark fin and shumai never disappoint. I try to go there every time I get back home to San Francisco.
author: Denise M.

description:
Prices keep going up and up. It is now 3 pieces for $2.20. Basic  take out dim sum place. It doesn't really compare to a real dim sum restaurant like Koi Palace or Hong Kong Lounge, which is fine as long as you know that going in. It's like comparing a hamburger from McDonald's to one from Umami, as long as you have realistic expectations, you can still enjoy that Big Mac.  

The dim sum here is usually filled with tons of msg, and the wrapper is very, very thick. They have all of the basics like har gow, sui mai, BBQ buns, and chicken buns. It's all designed to fill you up quickly, and to eat on the run. Take it for what's its worth and you'll be alright.
author: Dom L.

description:
I've tried so many to-go dim sum joints on Clement and they're all pretty much the same: 1) one order consists of three pieces of dumplings for $2 that hits the spot for lunch hangry stomach 2) know what you want before you order or you'll get even extra rude customer service 3) for westernized palates, know the difference between steam vs baked bun, hargow vs suimai, and don't expect your vegetarian dumplings to be meat free or not tainted by meat pans or kitchen appliances 4) don't try to peak into the kitchen and try to avoid looking at the floor 

I wouldn't be surprised if some of the reviews here were mistaken for another cliche dim sum place on Clement.  My coworker and I are always arguing about which dim sum place we go to with some yellow awning. 

Four stars for $4 lunches!
author: Bailey N.

description:
Very good Dim Sum - always freshly made and kept warm in very large steamers. 
The Pork Siu Man is very good. Also order the Char Siu Baos, Shrimp Dumplings and the Steamed Pork Buns. The place is very 'original', the ladies working there all speak mainly Chinese and you should be prepared to order as the ladies try to break some sort of speed record in serving you. It is a fun place, excellent dim sum at an affordable price
author: Joachim U.

description: Sticky rice wrapped in lotus leaf aka "lo mai gai" is one of my favorite dim sum foods. Wing Lee definitely has the worst that I've ever bought from a dim sum bakery. At $3 each, I would expect it to be filled with at least a decent amount of the typical fillings. But what I got was just a solid square block of sticky rice. NEVER AGAIN!
author: Alex F.

description:
On the days that I feel like being a pescetarian this is the first place I think of for some odd reason. I think it's because I'm addicted to their Shrimp dumplings and Chive & Shrimp dumplings. Best hands down in my opinion. Top it with some Sriracha and I'm in heaven!!! 

Out of all of other dim sum places I think that the texture of their wrappers are the best, soft and chewy. I can literally eat about 100 of these if I didn't care about portion control XD 

My only complaint is that I hate being yelled at by Asian ladies when they ask me "what do you want?!"  Or " next" or "How many?!" But I think that it's just their tone of voice. LOL
author: Rosalyn L.

description:
My new favorite spot for takeout dim sum. Here's a quick rundown on the must haves:

Baked pork bun (char siu bao)-- perfect combo of fluffy and meaty
Taro puff -- crisp, non-greasy exterior. Crunchy, savory water chestnut filling but the taro paste is slightly sweet
Chive dumplings -- soft wrapper, excellent chive and shrimp filling
Deep fried water chestnut dumpling -- crispy and chewy exterior. Yummy meat and water chestnut filling. 

For less than $12 you'll have plenty of delicious variety and won't have to wait 45m for a table. Wing Lee ftw!
author: Jenny N.

description:
Dim sum for $2.25. I like it. 

A lot.

Parking sucks, as usual, but it's worth taking a few turns. Their dim sum is goooood.
author: Sebastian F.

description: Basic Chinese bakery with dumplings and congee. Not exactly the cleanest place but the food was OK.
author: Pete L.

description: They aren't very polite...but they have great dim sum! My favorite to get here is their egg tarts. I also recommend baked pork bun, chicken stick, and sesame ball.
author: Mo M.

description: If you want to experience the worst customer service ever...this is the place for you!  The same at their Irving Street location near 24th Avenue. I've been a longtime customer and have noticed that their portion size have gone down and prices have gone up. Not to mention that they use meat sludge in their dim sum.  Yes there is such a thing as meat sledge--this was actually broadcast on a PBS program.
author: Ali L.

description:
Yum. Easy to get service. Staff is nice. No frills good eats at a reasonable price. Try the jook, siew mai, haw gao, radish cake, sticky rice, tarp cake, and sesame
ball. They feed lots of hungry people who look happy when they're a bit to bite into what they ordered. Everyone leaves full. Definitely recommend.
author: Spire S.

description: Stopped by here on our way out of the city. Got 8 BBQ pork buns, 2 shu mai, 1 shrimp  roll, 1 leaf wrapped rice with chicken and mushrooms, 2 bottles of water and a can of coke- came out to $30.  Buns were good but not as good as in Chinatown bakery- less meat/ more bread at a bigger price.  Ok in a pinch.
author: Seong M.

description:
This is the Chinese Bakery equivalent of Seinfeld's Soup Nazi.  Great food at good prices, almost always a line, and don't ask questions.  You had better know what you want when it is your turn to order or you will get the glare.

Great selection of items.  Everything I have tried here I have enjoyed.  I have even used them for large orders for gatherings.

The service is fast, though not conducive to the undecided tourist.  Some of the regulars are know to just cut to the front of the line when they come in (I have seen it myself).  And since the line forms at the counter and goes back into the store, it easy for them to do this.  But at least they know what they want, order quickly, and often have cash in hand before even ordering.

I stop in at least once a month for my BBQ pork bun fix.
author: Jeff H.

description:
There are so many places to go for dim sum on the street.  I find Wing Lee to be one of the cleaner ones with the most variety.  

What puts it over the top is the freshness of the product and for me the jook and "yow tiew" otherwise known as Chinese doughnut.  It is like soul food for me and comes at a very modest price.

There is only one lady to avoid as she is nit very nice and likes to get mad at you if you don't order correctly "only 3 in order , so i give you more". There are usually three ladies behind the counter so kids like to call it 3 card monte for dim sum ladies.

Other favorites include the baked Char-Siew bow, ha gow, sesame balls, and pot stickers.

Next door they also have a hot plate restaurant for ordering Chow Mien and Chow Fun.
author: Erik H.

description:
So I decided to go on a dim sum hunt in Richmond today. I started at Wing Lee on Clement street. 

*Note* I am basing all of my dim sum reviews on the following three items (as they are my favorites): Baked bbq pork bun, Har gao and Siu Mai.

Bao - The bun was rather dry. The filling was decent but lacked flavor although it did have decent size chunks of pork which is something I look for.

Har gao - While this was fairly moist compared to the other items I got, there were almost no shrimp in it and those it did have were tiny little bay shrimps! Unacceptable.

Siu mai - The pork filling again lacked flavor and the whole thing was rather dry, both inside and out.

So far, this was one of my least favorite dim sum shops. I will not be returning to this one.
author: Mark O.

description: The best BBQ pork bun good thing it's in the city and far away from me. It can be addictive!
author: Noel O.

description: Affordable and a little bit of everything! Dependable dim sum place.
author: Kelly S.

description: This is my favorite place to get potstickers and rice cakes. The steamed pork buns are delicious. Ive had other things and they were d gear too, but these things stand out for me. Cash only!
author: Shawna F.

description:
Food is okay, counter staff are racist.
Been buying dim sum here for 30 years.
Went today for multiple items, server dumped into the smallest container possible, breaking the items, then gives me the nastiest growl when I requested she arrange the items instead of mashing them.

4 orders of hargow, fungor, harcheegow, plus four lomaikai. She threw the lomaikai into a bag, Huff's, takes my $20.

Avoid if you like your dimsum fresh and pretty. 

Oh, yes, I am non-asian.
author: Joseph F.

description:
Over charged me for the stuff I bought and kept telling me they were out of pineapple and cocktail buns, even though the buns were in plain sight. 

They can all rot in hell. Go to Good Luck Dim Sum instead.
author: Krishan M.

description:
Little dim sum place in San Francisco is great. I used to come to this place when I was a kid but it has been turned over through the years. If it is still excellen,  their prices are outstanding, the service is your typical Chinese low drama service.

I live in San Jose and we do have some decent dim sum down here but it is way more expensive. San Francisco is the place to go. We bought a whole bunch and ate it for days.
author: Cat H.

description:
One of my FAV dim sum shops.
Shrimp har gow
Sesame balls
Sticky rice - no mai gai or jung
Congee - typically sells out early
Baked and steam pork buns
Meat sui mai
Bean curd roll
The list goes on and it well worth a stop by if you are wanting Good dim sum.
Prices are very reasonable considering quality, costs, and portion plus stomach "fillability".
Yummy!
author: David H.

description: The barbecue pork buns are OUT OF THIS WORLD. The bread is fluffy and sweet, while the pork is tender and teeming with flavor. I always pick up a couple of chicken skewers, pork shu mai, and the gooey rice cake with custard inside.
author: Loveys F.

description:
I bought eight pieces of dim sum, one pork bun, three egg custards and three sesame balls. It was $14

I liked everything.  But I'd probably try another place on the street when I'm back in the area.
author: Foodlover B.

description:
This place is N.A.S.T.Y.
Do not eat here. I've been coming here sporadically over the past 15 years. Every single time they give me the food it is ALWAYS cold. Do they not realize people are buying the food to eat right away? Normally I stay away from greasy dim sum places on Clement St. But today the person I was with was craving it, and so I ended up eating some cold chicken skewers. In addition to the cold food served , they overcharged us, and my friend got food poisoned and was vomiting immediately after eating their food. Please do yourself a favor and don't eat here. She had the steamed pork bun and sesame balls right before she threw up on the street right outside this "restaurant". She is now feeling better after getting their food out of  her system. Beware!
author: Mary P.

description: So just had to mention that I STILL come here every day for lunch. I even went around and tried the other local dim sum spots and they literally suck in comparison. Some of them actually just suck on their own. So just don't go to any of them, come to Wing Lee! But only after 2pm because I will be pissed if you take the last of my beloved har gow and beef shumai, which was EXCEPTIONALLY delicious today. Gahhhhh. I gush.
author: Christine U.

description: I love this place!!! Best dim sum in SF. They have many things to choose from.  Everything looks delicious.  It's always consistent and the prices are incredibly low! The staff is always pleasant, and they don't mind explaining what the items are.  I come here often, and I love it.
author: lashawnte b.

description: Standard average dim sum for very cheap prices. I came here several times this week to grab a quick breakfast to go food. The dumplings have thick wrappers and the buns had more dough than filling but the price can't be beat. 6 buns and a dozen dumplings for only $18!
author: Wanda L.

description:
Love to eat red bean rice cake
Sesame ball, plain bread and variety dim sum
Cheap, fresh tasty foods
If you want to eat something cheap or quick bite, you should go this place.
author: Jane K.

description:
Their dim sum is so cheap and yummy at the same time!!!  Drizzle the dim sum with hot sauce and soy sauce so it'll add spicy and salty flavors to the overall dim sum meal!  MmMmmm!

Where do I even start to place out what I have ordered here?

L I S T  O F  R E C O M M E N D A T I O N S
- Bean Curd Roll
- Chicken Combination Bun and Pork Bun
- Steamed Shrimp with Chives
- Steamed Pork (Siu Mai) and Beef 
- Shrimp (Har Gow)
- Fried Taro
- Fried Pork Ball (Ham Suy Gok)
- Steamed White Carrot Cake
- Steamed Egg Custard Bun

Sample picture of one of our dim sum platters - http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/wing-lee-bakery-san-francisco?userid=I-FmdvI28N7OIIt4JZOgIg#DA-XtKujmlmdRxQbIwj_mg

All of this, made a splendid, inexpensive, brunch meal that fed 3 hungry people all for under about 15 bucks!  Bring cash!
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Not the cleanest nor are the ladies behind the counter friendly, their har gao and shrimp & leek dim sum were pretty good and their chicken skewers were delicious. 

They lose points because their char siu bao, while *huge, were not good: The bao was fluffy but a little too sweet and the pork inside was a strangely disparate combination of fattiness and mealiness as well as being too sweet. 

The BBQ pork's sauce was strange, too, it having no other flavor besides overly sweet and being an unnatural color of sienna red.

I'd recommend Wing Lee in a pinch but only for the steamed dim sum and chicken skewers.
author: Jennifer O.

description:
The Steamed Pork Bun here features untraditional brownish bread, that looked like it was made with whole wheat. This departure from tradition for the bread, and the average tasting meat within, made for an unimpressive experience. 

That said, the other items we tried here were much better. The Savory Pork and Vegetable Buns provided a great combination of flavors, and the dim sum items we tried -- the Chive Dumpling and Bean Curd in Tofu Wrap -- were also great and definitely worth checking out.

This visit was part of a 6-person BBQ Pork Bun Crawl to a bunch of San Francisco's most popular bakeries. To read up on other bakeries we visited, check out my Yelp list: http://www.yelp.com/list/bbq-pork-bun-crawl-sf-san-francisco.
author: Mark C.

description:
Small little hole-in-the-wall in the Richmond, with it's more meat-heavy dishes being served in the take-out restaurant directly next to it.

They have decent shortbread crust dan-tats, although they're a little too buttery for my taste, and the filling is more like a bland, creamy custard.

Cash only!
author: Claire S.

description:
This place has AMAZING steamed BBQ pork buns. 

I first came in here because it was the first dim sum place I found in the area. While I was still deciding what to order, I overhead the lady in front of me tell the cashier she will eat 2 of the BBQ pork buns at once. I figured I would try one, even though I was skeptical since the buns didn't really look like the ones I've had at other dim sum places. Best decision that day. I love bread and the bun was really soft and chewy. The meat was really good too. I will admit that after leaving the store and checking out the other dim sum places in the area, I came back and ordered a second one.
author: Amanda R.

description: I will drive hours to eat here!  The staff isn't always the friendliest, but that might be because of a language barrier, but the food?!?!?! I have yet to have something here I didn't like.  Obviously the pork buns are AMAZING!  I can't decide which ones I like the most, the baked or steamed.  Just tried their beef curry baked bun, holy cow, flavor EXPLOSION!  Deliciously tender beef with Chinese curry spice and onions.  So good.  The onion pan cakes are simple and divine with a light crisp on the edges and delicious onion flavor throughout.  Don't forget the dim sum!  Totally affordable, and delicious!  Did I say delicious???? It's delicious!
author: Kim K.

description: First time here. Got a few different things since I've never had any. Tried the pork bun, chicken potstickers and pork rice balls. All were very delicious. $6.50 w the hot sauce. Have enough for lunch and dinner :)
author: Yesenia S.

description:
Having access to dim sum was purely taken for granted when I lived in San Francisco and San Jose. Now I live in Santa Cruz and I can say that I am deprived. #firstworldproblems

A day in the city w/ my kids and my best friend frolicking around hitting up our many bookmarks. I wasn't hungry but I knew I needed to get my fix because I have been craving it daily. 

I stepped in because Yelp had good ratings and the items looked sinfully delicious from the window. I did not see banh cuon but I was thrilled when they said they have it. They're rice rolls... I had shiu mai and har gow which are essentially steamed dumplings. 

Poor service but wonderful and cheap food.

Santa Cruz, please take notes.
author: Tram N.

description: Everything was cold so the lady had to MICROWAVE our food. It's not worth the drive or a second visit. Spent about $14 for below mediocre dimsum. I could have gone to Good Mong Kok and left with two bags full of goodies for that price. What a disappointment and a horrid choice.
author: Ella A.

description:
Cheap, mass produced dim sum that hits the spot for those looking for a quick meal. Great for take out.

Ordered:
Shrimp Har Gow - Texture is a bit jelly feeling due to being oversteamed, should be more fim. Shrimp taste is okay.
Pork shiu mai - Large pieces, acceptable, reminds me of 99 ranch dim sum to go.steamed a bit too long
Beef shiu mai - Also large pieces, got some of that beef flavor in it, bit oversteamed probably due to sitting around longer, not being as popular as the pork version.

While I wouldn't be really looking for quality dim sum in a "to go" place, if you're nearby and want something fulfilling & cheap, Wing Lee fulfills that niche.
author: Steven C.

description:
Chicken buns is a solid go to here, rarely does it disappoint 

They don't shy away from portion or seasoning =) 

Overall Thoughts

Come hungry and just know you won't leave paying more that $7 for a satisfying snack/meal
author: Eddie W.

description: Whenever I visit my aunt, she would buy the steamed bbq pork bun for us to eat.  Normally, I don't like steamed buns because they seem to lack flavor.  However, the buns here were delicious.  The filling were juicy, with tons of sauce.  Since the filling was filled with sauce, I had to use the outer bread to mop up all the juice.  I just ate one before typing this review!  Besides the steamed bbq pork bun, my aunt would also order other dim sum items (stir fried rice rolls, steamed chicken bun, etc.).  Unfortunately, the flavors are sub par. Four stars is just for the steamed bbq pork bun.
author: Sandy Q.

description: Decent, cheap buns in an interesting shop. A fun place to try if you're exploring the area, like we were.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Most of the food was low on flavor, but also wasn't that salty or greasy. From best to worse:
- Baked bao was huge and evenly filled with lots of meat and good outside color.
- Fried taro had an enjoyable filling inside the mashed taro and a fun crispy fried exterior, but was a little throat scratchy.
- Leek-shrimp gow barely had any shrimp with bluntly cooked leeks.
- Pork shui mai was too bland with hard meaty chunks
- Steamed bao was also huge, but the pork filling was oddly saucy.
author: Brian U.

description: Best bang for you buck dim sum. My family always goes when we're in the area, amazing quality and we can usually be filled off of less than $5 a person worth of food.
author: Byron P.

description:
I love this dim sum establishment! The food is always fresh since there are so many customers, especially during breakfast and lunchtime! There are a couple of servers, but customers always take their time when they choose out their dim sum so it takes awhile. 

My favorite is the shrimp dumpling (ha-gow)! It has the right amount of crunch and the skin is perfect. It won't break apart and drop the shrimp halfway while eating. They also have different varieties that other stores do not usually carry such as the shrimp with corn dumpling. 

I can't ever seem to leave this place without spending $15-20 worth of dim sum! It's so good, but packed with loads of calories... The egg tarts here are pretty good and they always seem to run out when I try to get some towards the end of the day. 

There are tables in the back where you can sit and enjoy your dim sum with a cup of coffee which is perfect. 

The servers are really nice and they don't care if you can't speak Chinese. (Unlike other places that look down on you if you can't name your dim sum in Chinese especially if you're Chinese) They are extremely helpful when you want recommendations on what's good also.
author: Maybo L.

description:
Do not come here based on the reviews. This place didn't taste good... like at all. I was tricked into coming here because of its positive reviews on yelp and had some sort of expectations. The bf and I drove out here to meet a friend for a late lunch - spent $17 dollars in total for three people - considering that each dumpling dim sum dish costed $1.80 for three, I'd say we got a pretty good variety.

I am from HK, grew up there and know what "good" dim sum is as well as "to go" dim sum quality. This place just was not up to par and I was very disappointed. Go to the "to go" places in Chinatown, they were much better and more flavorful. The only decent thing was the char siu bao and maybe the chicken/veggie bao. Everything else was meh, not flavorful and disappointing. Also, the ladies were rude - I called and asked in Cantonese what time they were open till and then if they have seating in the restaurant and she asked me "and so what do you want?" Um.... obviously all I want to know is the answer to those two questions so I can come in and spend money at your restaurant... tsk tsk. 

Anyways, 2 stars is being generous, the place isn't good, it's dirty (oh btw, a random lady who worked there sat at our table back facing us while we were eating and was spitting persimmon skin onto her hand and after finishing her fruit, then walked to the front to work while rinsing her hands only with water and no soap! - ugh gross!) Okay, I just decided to downgrade this place to a one star after writing that sentence, dont come.
author: Vanessa K.

description:
Everything you want for fast food Dim Sum:

Quick, tasty, and fulfilling. 

And of course, cheap. 

If you go here everyday, you don't need to cook.

$15-18 will take care of you for 3 meals. 

Give it a try!
author: Phillip K.

description: The dim sum at this place flunked the most basic test: they weren't hot. The dough of the har gao was too gummy. The bean curd rolls must have sat around for too long--the carrot was bitter. The zhong (sticky rice wrapped in lotus leaves) was okay, but then that's something you can buy at the supermarket and reheat yourself in the microwave.
author: Chung L.

description:
Been to a lot of dim sum places in the city and this place is my Go To! 

Unlike Chinatown or Inner Sunset, there is a better opportunity for you to find parking. 

The dim sum is delicious, quick and cheap. I usually buy in bulk. You can also call in ahead of them. 

Another plus that it's next door to Schuberts  Bakery! That place is to die for. Hit em back to back.
author: Arron E.

description:
Weekday, 1:30 PM - 4 people

Quick in and out - what else can you expect from a takeout dim sum place?  We were on the way back to the office, so we stopped in here to get a sampling of what they had.  First thing we noticed was English on the menus!  This is a big plus - some places in Chinatown don't bother doing this, and although I know what is being offered (from living in Asia for years), most people are probably confused and left to point aimlessly at what looks appetizing.  My choices were the go-to orders at this type of place, because unfortunately they were lacking on the flaky pastries (char siu so, for example).  I saw egg tarts tucked away in one corner under a heating lamp, but they didn't look very good. 

+Steamed BBQ Pork bun - good amount of meat, less fat/gristle than other places I've visited in Chinatown
+Banana cake - great flavor, kind of disintegrated in my hands.  Banana flavor really came through and not overly sweet
+Steamed Chicken bun - could actually see the chunks of chicken meat, as opposed to congealed chicken parts mush I've seen in other areas of the city
+Steamed Egg Custard Bun - good flavor, not the best, not the worst.  

I paid $3.30 total for my 3 steamed buns, and I tried someone else's banana cake.  Good value for what I got.  Overall a nice takeout dim sum experience (you have to distinguish between takeout and sit-down dim sum - VERY different).  If you live in the Western half, and you don't feel like going to Chinatown, this is a great alternative.
author: Ben K.

description: Good is good and fresh for sure! And it's clean!!! Also staff are super nice and helpful! They look happy at work! Some of the dimsum places on this street, staff can be really demanding and pushy I'll come back!
author: Timtim H.

description: My favorite dim sum in SF and and very authentic!! I literally come here every weekend on my lunch break. Get the shu mai!! :)
author: Crystal X.

description:
Him: Man, think I ate too much because I feel hella chill, kinda sleepy. It's weird. I think we need to get some coffee before we go or do anything else. 

Me: Dude......you're not feeling the effects of a food coma, you overdosed on MSG!

This isn't the first time he's eaten dim sum at Wing Lee. In fact, he's been here a few times for their super cheap food. Most of the dim sum items cost around $1.60 for 3 pieces. You can mix and match to your heart's desire.
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cHBLiy_53nQZrsrR-NH_Hg?select=RTkqU69GAUQA8D04MW8BMQ

On this particular day, boy decided to introduced me to something new: "shark meat dumplings". I thought he meant "shark fin dumplings", a shu mai with ground pork, shrimp and bits of shark fin. There was no shark fin at all, but A LOT of shark meat.

I still didn't believe him so I asked the lady behind the counter. Yep, it was indeed shark meat mixed with veggies. 

It tasted funky. I don't care what everyone else says, this $hit definitely doesn't taste like chicken at all.

 Shark meat is sometimes referred to as the "poor man's swordfish" because of it's similar taste and texture to swordfish. But this particular shark meat gau was gross. Everything about it tasted off: the smell, the texture and the sweet funky taste that results from using too much MSG. 
http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cHBLiy_53nQZrsrR-NH_Hg?select=TLGidONVqC_y8SqPkPhHKw

I forced myself to finish one dumpling, and left the 2nd one half eaten. Even the pork shu mai tasted too sweet and weird. Boy ended up having to eat majority of the MSG-laddened food......i believe around 9 pcs, no wonder he got sick. Poor guy.
author: Cin T.

description: The big Chix bao are great reminds me of the ones used to get in Chinatown growing up
author: Victor C.

description:
Quick, cheap, and good.

If you're craving for dim sum (take out) in the Richmond, I highly suggest coming here -- but make sure you know what you want before you order because the workers here don't have any patience.  

I usually get the Shu Mai, Pot stickers, BBQ Pork bun, Chinese Donut, Sweet Rice Cake, and the Red Bean Sesame balls.The portion size are pretty huge, you definitely get what you pay for here and it's super quick. I think most of the dim sum sells 3 at $1.90 or somewhere around that range, which isn't bad. 

Highly recommend. Also, I believe it's cash only! So make sure to have some on hand. And, don't feel flustered when ordering, it may seem intimating at first but they tend to get you the correct dim sum if you order confidently.
author: Julia K.

description: Great, inexpensive dim sum! This is not really a sit down restaurant, but there are tables and chairs if you want to eat there.
author: Angela W.

description:
Came here for lunch.
It was good. I was surprised how cheap the food was. My sister had a juk and she said it was good, and that the rice was nice and soft. She also had steamed beef rice noodle roll, and recommended it to me. I ordered one, and it was different from what I expected. Instead of soft noodles, it was thicker and like an actual roll. Despite never eating this type, it was pretty good. I also got a siu mai and it was really big and meaty. 
The two ladies working were fast. They forgot to give me a fork, but quickly gave me one when I asked.
Overall it was pretty good, especially for the price.
author: MaryAnn H.

description:
Been here twice and it delivers good bang-for-the-buck. The chicken steamed bun was pretty good but I prefer the baked chicken buns. I wish the chicken fillings inside the baked buns were fried/grilled instead of the exact same as in the steamed buns.

The potstickers were a little disappointing. The 'wrap' wasn't all that texturally and I have had more flavourful fillings at many other places. The shrimp sew mai was par for the course and I think the bbq chicken skewer I had the first time was overkill. I liked it!

Both my meals here were well under the $10 mark and the first time I had only 2 of the potstickers and boxed the remaining 4!

I wouldn't mind jumping in here again for a quick bite, on my way to Schubert's bakery next door, but I'd try the others in the same neighbourhood before I settle on any one "favourite" joint.
author: Umesh T.

description: This place is amazing. FRESH FRESH dimsum pretty much all day. Pork buns, amazing. People are friendly enough. Amazing food for an amazing price. This is my favorite dim sum place in SF!!
author: Flavia D.

description:
Steamed bao bigger than my fist for 90 cents!? Yes please!

The pork in the chai sui bao is chunky and has a good five spice kick. I love throwing some chilli sauce on their for a bit of extra kick. The coriander gow gee is an absolute steal - 3 for $1.70! They're big and plump, the veggie filling is good but the dough is a little thick and flabby and a bit too oily for my liking.

While these might not be the most refined dumplings and bao you've ever had, they do pack some flavour and they're mighty mighty cheap. If you're hungry and want to stuff your tummy hole for just a few dollars then you'd do a lot worse than coming here and eating a plate of hot steaming buns.
author: Tresna L.

description:
Uhh...three pot stickers for $1.60? Fuck yeah. Those tasty little steamed pockets of shrimp, chives and cabbage perfection. 

I don't care for those little egg custard tarlets everyone seems to love. Today I bought four of them for my boyfriend and I ended up eating half of them before I made it to Arguello to catch the 33 back home. The egg flavor was delicate, not that overpowering egg currdling taste I've experienced so many times. The crust was flaky without crumbling to pieces in my hand. The aftertaste was sweet and not rancid. 

I love how it only takes one great experience and properly prepared food product to make you forget all the horrible previous encounters.

I love you Wing Lee Bakery.
author: Illyanna M.

description:
This spot was my bestfriends favorite chinese bakery in the city. She loved the BBQ porn buns.

I sampled the pineapple bun and wasn't impressed however the steamed porn buns are indeed delicious. I will return here now and again.
author: Kristy F.

description: I went to the to-go part....they open early and the size of their steam and baked buns are definitely worth the price!!
author: Keeks P.

description:
Baked. BBQ. Pork. Bun. Oh my gosh. So cheap. So delicious. 

The last time I ate a pork bun was at the base of Mt Fuji after I'd finished hiking and was starving. It was not objectively delicious but delicious at the time. I had not since partaken in any pork buns, because carbs. However, recently my bf, a life-long San Franciscan, convinced me to partake in a Wing Lee bun. Life changed. Everything I've tried here is yummy. I mean, you can sample the whole place for less than $20.
author: Aubrey O.

description:
Came here last week for some quick bites... or snacks... or dim sum! The line was long (came around the afternoon) but the service was fast. Ordered WHEAT pork buns for the sis (she loves that) but I didn't manage to taste it because I was too busy eating the egg custard bun... it was freshly baked and it was fluffy and delish! 

Price: can't beat it! 

Highly recommend if you're craving dim sum but wants to avoid the dim sum craze!
author: Cath M.

description: They raised their prices to $2 for every 3! Kinda sad but what can you do? Its good stuff!
author: Janelle D.

description:
I love this place! Whenever i want dim sum and wish to avoid crazy dim sum restaurant waits I would think of this place. I've been coming here/ordering to go since forever :)  
Typically every order of a dim sum is 3 pieces for $1.60 
Prices are so reasonable you can afford to try everything!

They have ha gow + sew mai (shrimp/pork dumpling), sticky rice (wrapped in green leaf), my favorite one is the one with turnip inside dumpling (fried or steamed), cha sew bao (bbq pork buns), leek dumplings, egg tarts and so much more!  
If you can't decide what to order, just pick anything because i'm sure it'll be tasty!

*note: the steam chicken buns are delicious + huge!

Cash only!
author: Roxana L.

description:
My boyfriend and I came in for some quick dim sum. Overall, it was pretty good. However, I'd recommend taking it to go, as the seating here is limited. We sat at a table with another couple, right near the counter, so lines congregated near us -- was difficult to really enjoy our food and eat slowly. 

But overall, the dim sum was pretty good and very inexpensive. Would come back for dim-sum to go (preferably on a warm day where we could eat it on a picnic blanket in the park!).
author: Siv L.

description:
H-Y-P-O-G-L-Y-C-E-M-I-C.

Ok, so I've never been medically diagnosed but when this girl gets a rumbly in my tummy, it's like hitting a wall. No energy, I can barely speak, my face feels like it may slide off my head and I get a little crank-tastic. And that's when you know that I need food. :)

While running errands in the Richmond, I HAD to stop to get a pick me up that would give me a pep but not fill me up too much for dinner. We picked up 6 Steamed Shrimp Dumplings and 6 Pork Shumai. Each were 3 for $1.50. But to our surprise when we opened our container was that we scored an extra free Shrimp Dumpling and both types were HUGE!!! Easily the size of a golf ball!!! S-C-O-R-E!

Pork was surprisingly flavorful with a nice "bite" to it. The shrimp were quite large in the dumplings and were well cooked.

Tummy Monster appeased, blood sugar up, and I was ready to roll :)
author: Nam N.

description:
Still the best combination buns (dai bao) and chicken in sticky rice wrapped it n lotis leaf.

The shrimp filled items are meager.  I couldn't believe there was only 1/4 of an inch size round piece of shrimp in the leeks and shrimp dumpling.  The har gow is also light on the shrimp.  Sadly, they are now using baby bay shrimp (as if you can get any smaller). This is not traditional and a terrible substitution.

I definitely have to go to two different dim sum take out places when I am in the Richmond.
author: Debbie T.

description:
I picked up some shrimp dumplings, a pot sticker and an egg tart recently. Everything was good but could have been better. The shrimp dumplings are still huge but a lot of the size is just the wrapper. The pot sticker wasn't very flavorful and the egg tart crust was more crumbly than flaky. I prefer the latter. Also, everything seemed a bit more greasier during this visit. 

Prices went up another 10 cents again, and service hasn't change, for me at least. Still cold.
author: Maya S.

description:
Ready to go, ready to eat, ready to die for.. 
They pass my dim sum test,
I got 1 box full of pork & shrimp siu mai,
& i loved every bite. They also have every other chinese bakery item u can want, chinese donuts to steam bbq pork bun. This hood is known for the asian food so, im not suprised. I will be back. 

But seating for eating in is not very ideal. Get it to go
author: Mono L.

description: We shop on clement 2 to 3 times a week and buy dim sum from various bakeries.  However the food here is consistently medicore at best.  I dont usually give 1 star but this one deserves one.  Let me explain.  We bought 3 egg tarts.  We shared one on the way to another shop.  As I took a small nibble, the crust left a bitter after taste.   I HAVE NEVER experienced such a taste from any baked goods before.  I love bitter melon but not bitter egg tart.  I decided to bring it back to inform them of my discovery.  They just replied back "thats how it is".  Didnt apologize, no thank you, no offer of any refund whatsoever.  I left the two  eggtarts on the counter and walked out.
author: S F.

description: OH MY SHUMAI. The food here is so dang good. The dim sum is seriously the best of all that I have tried. I will definitely remember this place forever. If you're around the area, definitely give this place a try! Pork shumai with the hot sauce! :)))))
author: Joy S.

description:
Some of the best (if not the best) Joong, baos,  jin dui in the City. Pricing is very reasonable. 
Me and my family have been coming here for as long as I can remember.  We have never been disappointed with the quality or service.. If your driving parking can be difficult at times, but believe me it's well worth the walk.
author: Brian C.

description: Good quick n easy place. No nonsense or frills, but fast, very cheap, and pretty tasty. Most items are pretty greasy but I appreciate that the fillings aren't just the cheapest meat slurry they can pack in there - there are items with crispy veggies and even somewhat subtle ingredients. I like the pork bun (not crazy sweet) and the chicken combo bun, veggie dumplings, and if they have the sesame ball dessert you should def get it.
author: Scott K.

description: Recommended by my sister to order a chicken bun jumbo size for a $1.80 which contain chicken, eggs , mushroom , Chinese sausage , and boy let me tell you that's my lunch. It tastes awesome, that's my go to spot after my post workout at the gym! I would recommend anybody and everybody to go and try this place out, they also have restaurant right next door on the corner which is cheap.
author: D D.

description: Clean and friendly place great for stopping by for a dumpling or my favorite treat, a sesame ball. Stumbled upon this spot accidentally and will come back!
author: Chelsea G.

description:
My dad frequently gets dim sum and chow mein, drumsticks and such to go from here.  One day he brought back dim sum and I thought this one dumpling I ate was my favorite shrimp and chive dumpling....took bites of it and saw they put celery in it in lieu of chives.  Who puts celery in dumplings?  Yuck!  Other than that all the dumplings have been full of yummy fillings and satisfied my tummy.  The fried chicken is huge and the chow mein is pretty standard.

Good alternative to busy nearby Good Luck Dim Sum.
author: Cat C.

description: Got beef cherng fun, but not the best. Cheap but would rather pay more for better quality
author: Jessica W.

description:
One of my favorite dim sum spots!!

I try not to think about the cleanliness here... ::shivers down my spine:: 

That being said food is good.
author: Andrew V.

description:
I've been here a couple of times and have had both savory and sweet items. Always have enjoyed them. 

The staff is pretty typical of similar dim sum places in the area: if you don't know what you want immediately they're brusque and ignore you. Just because I'm ethnically Chinese doesn't mean I'm familiar with dim sum!

Last note: not really any seating options, so better place to grab and go than to eat-in.
author: Rowena L.

description:
I have been coming here for over 23 years. It's not changed a bit. The Charsiu baos here can be had either baked or steamed. Both are giant and very tasty.

The dumplings here can be a little greasy but it's definitely the street food type dim sum you'd expect from a little shop like this. I find the skin on the dumplings to be a little too thick for my taste.

Still, I do like their sesame balls and I rarely leave this bakery without two loaded bags in hand.
author: Allison J.

description:
Not nearly as good as its counterpart down the street (Good Luck) and the baked items tend to stay out longer and be less fresh I think. Shrimp dumplings have a pretty chewy exterior (not a good shrimp-to-skin ratio). 

Friendly folks, good prices, but not all that great of quality.
author: Neal C.

description:
This is the dim sum bakery I've been looking for!  It's tasty, fresh, cheap and fast!
I'll have to try it a few more times, hope they are consistently this good.  I've tried a few other highly rated dim sum bakeries in San Francisco and Oakland chinatowns and they have been okay but I do like to try some of the different items they have on offer and usually there will be something that just tastes funky (and not just in a way that's different), I liked everything we ordered here, everything tasted very fresh (didn't get anything deep fried this time though).

Steamed BBQ Pork Bun - Nice, not too much dough (as compared to many others, it is supposed to be somewhat bready), dough was flavorful, light yeasty taste (some have no flavor at all).  Filling had nice meat with a little fat (not grisly), sauce had a light smokiness to it that went well with the yeastiness in the dough.  Most of all there was not a hint of funk in the meat.  I feel that often the strong BBQ flavor (even at some of the highly rated bakeries) is masking some funky meat and I'm really grossed out when I get a hit of that older meat flavor, not a bit of it here.  I hope this remains consistent! :)

Pot Stickers - Nice but not stand out, would have liked a little more roasty, seared flavor but again fresh and I liked the larger bits of lightly crunchy cabbage in them.   

Bean Curd Rolls - These soy bean skin wrapped rolls were delicious, crunchy vegetables inside, nice sauce.

Combo Pork Dumpling - I really liked the nice thin steamed skin on this.

Round steamed dumpling (unknown name) - Lightly sweet, dark sauce inside with peanuts and probably small pork bits, and some vegetables, it was more of a flattened ball shape with a thicker, mochi like skin, different and good too.

I'm going back!
author: Kelly B.

description: I seriously have to stop trusting Yelp reviews when it comes to dim sum in SF.  Yes, this stuff is cheap.  I got an order of leek chives with shrimp dumplings (3), an order of peanut dumplings (3), turnip cake (3 large ones), one steamed BBQ pork bun, and one glutinous rice with chicken in banana leaf - all for under $10.  But the dumpling skin is so thick with cornstarch, and the pork bun is so doughy, and the turnip cake so bland, that it just isn't that good as the 4 star average Yelp ratings suggest.
author: Vivian W.

description: I have been craving the special steam chix bun, which contains chix, sausage, egg, & shiitake mushroom. I've been searching for a place & after many tries, this place IS IT!! They call it the "combination" bun and it costs $1.70 each. Well worth it because it is huge and a meal in itself. I also tried their shrimp dumplings, which were equally good and their egg arts, delicious! I highly recommend this place!
author: Aleda G.

description: My absolute favorite place to get takeaway dim sum. It's a bang for your buck! I bring it to my work all the time, and my coworkers keep raving about how delicious the har gow and Chiu Chow dumplings taste!
author: Amanda H.

description:
Decent dim sum to go. There are a few tables but since I live so close I prefer to get things to go and eat it at home. I also don't have to deal with parking which is usually an issue on Clement. 

Everything is super cheap, $5 can go a long way here. Depending on the time of day there may or may not be a super long line, but since everything is already ready and the women who work there are all business, it goes quickly.
author: Vicky J.

description: Plenty of non-pork items, which is rare at dim sum places. Lots of veg options, very cheap. However, they serve shark fin. I realized that after ordering, and won't be going back because I don't want to support that. Pretty terrible.
author: Tanya S.

description:
Wing Lee continues to be my favorite dim sum spot along Clement Street.  Granted, I haven't tried every single dim sum shop along Clement Street, but among the ones I have tried in that area (Good Luck Dim Sum, Gourmet Dim Sum & Clement Restaurant) Wing Lee stands out as the one restaurant that uses the least MSG.  That's good news for someone like me who is sensitive to MSG or high sodium levels.

Like most dim sum places I have my likes and dislikes.  You will never, ever see me eating turnip cakes, leek dumplings, beef siu mais or beef rice rolls at any dim sum shop regardless of how good they are.  I don't like the taste of them, and I definitely don't like the look of them.

As my friend Sara A and I embarked on a six day great outdoors trip this would be the only restaurant food purchase of our entire trip.  Everything except for the shrimp gows were exceptional, and through the magic of words and pictures here is where my review begins.  One other thing, what I refer to the pastries as may not be what the restaurant refers to them as.

Chicken Siu Mai (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cHBLiy_53nQZrsrR-NH_Hg?select=3iTDI7x3FT6o4yuJ7WCuSw) - It's everything you love about your pork siu mais, but ground chicken thigh meat is used instead of the pork.  The filling seems pretty simple with ground chicken, finely chopped mushrooms and carrots that are wrapped in a thin flour wrapper and steamed.  These were very well seasoned and I could not detect any MSG.

Shrimp Gow "aka" Har Gow (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cHBLiy_53nQZrsrR-NH_Hg?select=wOHusAFk0IJyootF2tx1EA) - You get at least two baby shrimp in each along with some finely chopped bamboo shoot, and some gritty tapioca starch encased in a rather thick steamed rice flour skin that is super rubbery.  Sara and I actually played catch with one, and it was so rubbery it didn't break open.  These were okay, but I definitely detected some MSG inside the filling.

Fun Gor or Steamed Pork Dumpling (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cHBLiy_53nQZrsrR-NH_Hg?select=VkDFwAVV3MgUDwC7k-rh4w) - The filling is very well compacted and had good flavor.  The rice flour skin was also on the thick side, but aside from the ones my mom used to make I've come to expect thick skins on fun gors.  The filling consisted of minced pork, shrimp bits, mushrooms, carrots, bamboo shoots, green onion and cilantro.  All were chopped finely.  No MSG taste.

Sweet Rice Cake (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cHBLiy_53nQZrsrR-NH_Hg?select=96VVquk3h_uoAi1i-qV1qg) - These are a personal favorite of mine.  Pretty simple too.  It's a ball of sweet glutinous rice (sticky rice) flavored with minced green onion and bits of BBQ pork and wrapped inside a super thin rice flour membrane.  These pastries appear small but just a few will fill you up because the rice is packed so firmly.  Here is how it looks on the inside (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cHBLiy_53nQZrsrR-NH_Hg?select=80EgwX6Zdg9u79wABfmtHw).

Bean Curd Rolls (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cHBLiy_53nQZrsrR-NH_Hg?select=xho1Q8i5AVXQsn1fJmkLxw) - We had to try these because we had never seen them offered here before.  These are a good vegetarian option to the meat filled rice rolls and very tasty.  The filling consisted of thin glass noodles, chopped shiitake mushrooms, strips of carrot and strips of wood ear wrapped in hydrated dried bean curd and steamed.  They're served with soy sauce and chopped green onion.  We both agreed that these were delicious for a dish containing no meat.  Here's the shot of the filling (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cHBLiy_53nQZrsrR-NH_Hg?select=aCOYiEaIWv7T3HWTqRR8Pg).

Chicken Combination Bun (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/cHBLiy_53nQZrsrR-NH_Hg?select=8FD0AwItk92djvd1YaikXA) - My dad and I love Wing Lee's chicken combination buns.  As you can see from the photo there is tender, juicy chicken thigh meat with green onions, a part of a hard boiled egg, a whole shiitake mushroom and a piece of Chinese sausage inside the steamed sweet bun.  Best of all ... no MSG taste.

The ladies here are cool and all are very much trilingual (Cantonese, Mandarin, English).  If they can understand my Chinglish they can understand anyone.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description:
best take out dim sum....bar none!!
my favorite place to buy Mom some dim sum also to take home and devour with passion!!
Shui Mai...fun gor w/peanuts....hom tay( what flavor)
Sticky rice in banana leaf...w/ peanuts....
fun gor...cha sil bow( steamed for me)....
jook and chinese doughnut......yummy!!
author: chris f.

description:
I believe it was 3 dumplings for $1.80.  It's one of the better to-go dim sum/bakeries that I can go to.  The other dim sum place down the street on 11th ave is getting a bit ridiculous with charging for everything (boxes, etc).  
They have a lot of the popular items, haw gao, shu mai, sticky rice, etc. 
But they do charge for hot sauce!
author: Christi S.

description: The pork and vegetable bao are some of the best I've ever had! The char siu bao are decent but nothing out of the ordinary.
author: Jo B.

description:
I like dim sum take out shops in San Francisco.  

This joint has 3 items/$1.80.  

Hargow
Leek/Chives with shrimp

My favorite here is the bean curd wrap which is vegetarian. (glass noodles/carrots/woodear) A bit dry but overall I like it.
author: Jboogie L.

description:
Yummy and damn cheap! Most of the stuff here are $1.50 to $1.80 for 3 pieces. I think prices went a little up. Come here before 1700 hours before most of their stuff sells out. It helps to speak Cantonese here although you will still be adequately served if you dont. Im a normal face here and already made friends with the ladies behind the counter. They are a nice group to deal with.

I Always come here to buy bulk loads of to go dim sum and egg custart tarts (daan taat) for dinner and for breakfast at home if im ever in the Richmond district. I always buy 2 FULL plastic boxes and it costs me $13 to $15 which feeds 3 people at home breakfast, lunch and dinner for 4 days. 

Egg custard tart (daan taat): pie like crust (not the 'so pey' flaky type) with sweetened egg in the centre. $.65 per piece and tastes awesome.

Sesame ball: $1.40 each. Crispy outside with chewy inner layer filled with dark lotus seed pastes. Again awesome. Even retains its crispiness days after being bought and microwaved at home.

Cha Sew So: dont know what its called in english but it is a squar flat pastry wrapped around little amounts of Cha Sew (BBQ pork). LOVE the crispy and soft delicate pastry. BBQ pork inside gives it a nice touch. Like a Cha Sew Bau pork bun but with a pastry instead of a bun. A little more BBQ pork inside would be nice but I Highly recommend it.

Pork or beef Sew Mai: even though its not in par with Koi Palace or Asian Pearl standards, we all still love it. The beef sew mai tastes more like the beef balls (ngau yook) served in dim sum restaurants. Both damn good. $1.40 for 3 pieces.

Ha Gau (shrimp gau): love it and the shrimp inside was flavourfull considering this place is a cheap to go dim sum shop.

Spring roll: lots of vegetables inside. The type i personally enjoy. Even when i leave it in my fridge for days and the outer layer is totally soggy, i still love it. It is crispy when you eat it fresh though.

If you are nit picky about dim sum, then go to Asian Pearl or Koi Palace. What you get here is what you pay. Dirt cheap dim sum and fairly good food and fast efficient service. Me coming from Hong Kong and being accustomed to real deal dim sum and Chinese food, I still have no complaints about eating from here.
author: Chung L M.

description:
This is my go to place for dim sum take out:

Shrimp Har Gow: This is the clear white spherical dumpling. Pretty delish, make sure you dip it in chili sauce and soy sauce.

Shrimp Wrapped in White Noodle (Har Cheung): SKIP. The noodle is so thick and tough on the outside. It is supposed to be silky and delicate. The shrimp is tiny on the inside. And the sweet soy sauce on top is too watery.

Shark Fin Gow: Not bad. It's like a huge meatball in the shape of a dumpling. I prefer the siu mai.

Siu Mai: YUM. Mushroomy :) 

Chive Dumpling: Meh - Skip. Clear spherical dumpling filled with dark green chives and a shrimp.

Coriander Dumpling: This one had a nice little crunch. It is large clear dumpling with chopped up veggies.

Jook: can't go wrong here!
author: Jess C.

description: This is a good Chinese bakery. I like their steamed BBQ pork buns. Their spring rolls are good.  The combination chicken bun is also good and filling. Their steamed buns are made fresh and the fillings inside the buns are juicy and delicious. The prices are very low.  Customer service is OK.  I would go there, if you want something cheap and fast.
author: Hiroshi K.

description: I love this place.  Always delicious and the prices cannot be beat.  I go out of my way to come here for my Dim Sum fix.  The staff are always polite and courteous and helpful.  I recommend Wing Lee Bakery 100%!  Give them a try.
author: Daniel P.

description:
I would walk another block down to 7th street to get their dim sum. For the same price, it's worth an extra 20 steps. 

The hargow here is not very tasty and I get the impression that it's been sitting there for a while. You know what it is? The wrapper they use around the hargow and shrimp rolls is TOO THICK! It completely takes away from the flavors in the filling.  If that's what you like, this is the right place for you. 

I gave this place 3 different tries, and I feel the same way everytime; I always say to myself, "I should have gone to the place down the block."
author: Yunah R.

description:
I stumbled upon this place while wandering through SF last weekend, and I loved it!  Cheap, delicious dimsum--what more can you ask for?

Tip #1: Significantly cheaper than a sit-down dim sum restaurant.  I paid around 6 dollars for a filling meal. 

Tip #2:  Over half of the board was in Chinese so it can be tricky to know what to order (most of my purchases were buns and dumplings I randomly pointed to).

Overall: I would definitely suggest this place. Inexpensive + tasty = my favorite kind of restaurant.
author: Sarah W.

description: Probably the worst Dim Sum place in Inner Richmond. They have a lot of variety but the taste of the Siu Mai is mediocre, the skin of the shrimp dumpling is too thick. Their buns is decent however. I recommend Good Luck Dim Sum or Gourmet Dim Sum and Cafe for superior taste.
author: Robert S.

description:
I'm no dim sum aficionado, but this place is pretty darn good. Just make sure to order your food to go; there is negative ambiance here.
