Hard to beat a baked chicken or BBQ pork bun for one whole dollar and steamed dumplings/sew mai/gow at 3 for $1.70. And, yes, they are good.

Come with friends and order a little of everything. Make sure you ask for some napkins to go in the bag - those (savory) taro cakes and sesame balls left me quite a greasy mess. Oh, and soy sauce. The baked chicken bun was lacking in the flavor department and could have used some.

Minor gripes, but overall, I've been happy on the multiple occasions I've eaten (from) here. 
Now, if only I knew what a "Wife Cake" is...  looks like next time I'll have to spring an extra buck to solve that mystery.
author: Alissa A.

description:
CASH ONLY.  On 6th & Clement St.  We ate some dim sum where you tell the lady what you want & they just get it for you.

3 Chicken sui mai & 3 steam chive dumplings $3.83 or so.  It was ok food, I'd go back.

Some tables to sit & eat your food.

One unisex bathroom you need a key to use.

Next door is the BBQ station - that looks pretty good too.
author: Ann L.

description: I stop by every week or so.  They never know what I'm saying, but I always leave about three dollars poorer with a bag of some kinda dumpling(s), a rice ball with chopped stuff in it, and a pork bun when I'm extra hungry.  I always like it. Sometimes I find a face in my rice ball and bring it with me to mass, just in case.
author: Gina P.

description:
If you are ever in San Francisco, craving some dim sum, but don't want to deal with the wait at a restaurant, I strongly suggest coming here.

Wing Lee's is cheap and delicious. Of course it's nothing compared to high end dim sum, but for the price you pay, it is well worth it. 

They sell ha gao at 3 for $1.50. 

Remember though, cash only.
author: Karma B.

description:
So growing up in SF.. my mom would bring me here a lot. i used to not eat at all,  no joke. Until I came here! I love their jook omg. Since I don't live in SF anymore.. :( I don't come here as often. I remember coming here after going to Vietnamese school on the weekends and my dad would get me their preserved egg jook and egg tarts omg I still remember and that was about 12 years ago when I was 4. The prices here are pretty cheap compared to other dim sum places I know, that would charge 3 pieces for about $2.10. My mom sometimes goes to the temple around here and then buys like 3-4 boxes of takeout to bring home to me ^____^ yeah this place is one of my faves. Their baos, har gow, and sesame balls are the best! I really love their sticky rice and jook as well. My dad really likes buying the BBQ and the noodles they have next door.

BTW, I'm eating one of their char siu baos right now.
author: Tiffany T.

description:
I'm pretty sure 3 is a lucky number in Chinese culture. Maybe that's why all the dim sum shops on Clement dispense their orders in batches of 3. At Wing Lee, without hesitation I immediately request one order of my favorite dim sum, har gao (shrimp dumplings); but I usually have to put a little more thought into deciding which one or two others I'll really be able to finish 3 of. Should I go for the pork shumai? Potstickers? Veggies rolled up in the flat noodles? Especially with the huge line of people that has inevitably queued up behind me, I've never had the courage to ask if it's possible to mix and match.

There's certainly not a lack of takeout dim sum places along this street, and I don't necessarily have a concrete reason as to why Wing Lee is my favorite of the bunch, but I can assure you that it's good. Recently I gave their whole wheat cha siu bao (BBQ pork bun) a try--it was amazing! I may have liked it even more than I do original steamed bao, which I like a lot. Look at these Chinese people, getting all health conscious and stuff... gotta love the way they keep with the times!

Also make sure you pick up an egg custard tart. For 80 cents, how could you not?
author: Kate V.

description: Wing Lee Bakery is diamond in the rough amidst the plethora of dim sum offerings along Clement. Of the various places in the city I've tried so far, Wing Lee has had the best pork buns. So much yum.
author: Tini T.

description:
mm mm Dim Sum. Heavy comfort food in the mix this week, and Wing Lee is the best place to get it. 

I would probably love most of the bakeries on Clement st....but... Wing Lee has become a place to stop on my way home from work after an especially tiring day. 
If you are in the area and in the mood for something deliciously different Wing Lee Bakery is your place! I have found the reviews have been very helpful in finding new items. The things I really enjoy here are: har gow and sesame seed balls.

....and comin' in real hot under-budget, I have never spent more than $4 on a meal here...Categorized as "hipster grub"!
author: Jocelyn B.

description:
FOOD:
Cherng fun (long noodle)
Dumpling
Dan tat (egg custard)
Green chive dumpling 

*All the food is yummieee!! 

SERVICE:
Order pay at counter


ATMOSPHERE:
Few tables to sit, small place, otherwise typical window front with dim sum goodies in display
author: Angela L.

description:
Me likey.

Fast Food Dim Sum at its finest.  Fresh and ready to go, cheap as they come, with good variety.  Has all the basics across Har Gow, Siu Mai, and the Bao.  Really, really good Bao.

$12 for the family of 3.

Service?  Well, c'mon, this is a little bit like rating fast food too.  For that, yep - good service on a relative basis.  But this ain't no white napkin sit-down candlelight jointy-joint.

There is not a lot of seating area, but it's popular for take-out.  We did the sit down, and it's fine.
author: Tyler H.

description:
I prefer this place to Good Luck Dim Sum, one of its neighbors and a definite favorite. The beef siu mai and har gao are generally better here. Also, the wait tends to be shorter.

I do miss the lower prices. I've come here, on and off, since '98 or '99. Of course, not much hasn't gone up in price *and* 50 cents a piece is still darn reasonable.
author: Paulina F.

description: Best lotus-leaf-wrapped rice meal! Here or in LA. If you have somewhere else in mind, I am open to suggestions.
author: Kislev A.

description: Freshness is hit or miss and the cheong fun noodle wrap is way too thick, but when other stuff is fresh it's tasty affordable. I'd come here again for jook at least, but be careful about the dim sum you order!
author: Linus W.

description:
spotted a parking space, scored the space,  popped in a quarter and grabbed a pair of buns.

eats:
-steamed chicken bun(.8)
ground up chicken in a giant fluffy bun. guess cubed chicken would be dry
semi-juicy
3.5 stars
-steamed pork bun (.8)
quarter bits of tender pork char siu in a nice sauce. nice fluffy bun
4 stars

takeouts:
-probably the best buns i've eaten. more meat would be better.
-service quick
-may try siu mai, har gow next but they can't beat the buns.
-cash only
author: Victor G.

description:
The dim sum at Wing Lee Bakery is really good! I'm not talking Hong Kong, Kowloon Bay status dim sum, but really good stuff here. 

Just like many of the other shops along Clement, this restaurant does not stick out. I always choose my dim sum joints based on word of mouth from friends or my trusty Yelp app. Yelp did me right again!

The food is fresh. Since business is steady, you get dim sum that hasn't been sitting around for 12 hours. The Har Gow has a healthy serving of shrimp filled inside. Love it! Their custard tart is rich and delicious. Something rare with their Sui Mai offerings is they serve 3 kinds (pork, chicken, beef). I was expecting the chicken Sui Mai to be dry, but that was not the case. 

Service was polite. I never expect world class customer service from places like this. It's the quality that matters most here. Definitely a recommended dim sum spot if you are in the area!
author: Paul C.

description: Really cheap. Really good. This is my new favorite morning stop.
author: Morris R.

description:
They have those GIANT chicken combo steamed baos, filled with chicken, sausage, egg, and shiitake mushroom.  My favorite!   Why do I have such a hard time finding the combo buns in Chinatown?

Other dim sum is always top notch too.  

Came in this afternoon and noticed they now have a new healthier option:  chicken/pork/combo buns made with wheat flour instead of white flour.  Interesting...
author: Joanne G.

description:
For the Health Conscious: Wing Lee NOW offers WHEAT BBQ Pork buns, Combo buns, Chicken buns, and Sausage buns!!!!

At first, when I saw it on the menu I was very skeptical, but the lady assured me it was tasty. For a mere 80 cents, why not? And, she was right! Because it was steamed the wheat bun was very fluffy, light with a faint sweetness to it. The only difference is you get a slightly grainy texture from the wheat, but other than that, I couldn't tell the difference from their normal white bun!

Don't know how much heathier it can be since the pork, chicken, and/or sausage filling is pretty fatty itself, but at least you can say you're eating "HEALTHY CARBS"!!!!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
This is my favorite place on Clement Street for steamed pork buns. My boyfriend and I typically walk down Clement and take a look to see which dim sum place has the biggest line - and then head to that place. If the line is longest, this place must be doing something right!

Delicious steamed pork buns: not too sweet, not too much dough, and a low price. No one should pay $3 for a pork bun (ahem... not like one particular place you can find in the Ferry Building downtown). 

No nonsense staff, low prices and delicious makes this a great place for dim sum to take home.
author: Jen B.

description: Fast, cheap, and ghetto. Don't expect to be treated better than anybody. But the food is really good. Sew mai is the best thing I had.
author: Alex L.

description:
As good as it gets for down and dirty dim sum.  The line out the door says it all, as most people take dim sum home.  We'll freeze the leftovers and my daughter eats them for breakfast and lunch.   

The combination (sausage, boiled egg, pork pieces and who knows what else is in there) is a meal in a bun.  Don't miss the sesame balls and the BBQ pork buns and the custard buns, they are very good.  Prices are cheap, running anywhere from 60 cents to $1.50 per piece.  Hot tea and drinks will run you a buck.

The food is delicious -- where else can you get dinner for $3 in SF?  They close early, around 6PM on weekends and sometimes they'll mark down the prices 50% at closing.

If you eat there, you might need to wipe down the tabletops.  The tables and bathroom aren't the cleanest I've seen, but compared to  places I've been in China, they're pretty good.
author: Chris K.

description:
Still the best!  

They have the usual deals: 1 piece for 80 cents, 3 pieces for $1.60, or something close to that.  Through the years their dim sum has been superior to all the other dim sum shops on Clement Street.  

Break your diet in small increments.
author: David D.

description:
Full lotus.

Quintessential yoga position: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lotus_position

Quintessential Chinese bakery offerings: Har Gow (shrimp dumpling) and a mini mooncake for a buck and change. Enjoyed both, especially the lotus seed dessert.

Plenty of money left over for Bikram: http://www.yelp.com/biz/bikram-yoga-in-the-mission-san-francisco-2#hrid:ytsQzfD4vrHZIxldW8Ot5Q
author: Jason B.

description:
You know when Mario goes to that giant world where all the bricks and turtles are gigantic? That's how I felt when I saw the size of their dim sum here.

Everything was so delicious that I bought a bunch to-go, including something that looked like little balls of fried rice, to serve at my Christmas Eve dinner (I know, I'm such a fob.)

Prices? Can't be beat. Be prepared to stuff yourself silly for cheap!

The only downside is there's barely any space to sit, espeically with the line wrapped around the inside of the store like some amusement park ride. Most people get takeout for that exact reason, I would guess.
author: Amaryllia L.

description:
Cool dim sum find in the Inner Richmond neighborhood.

This place gets my props for:
- tasty and affordable dim-sum
- friendly and efficient workers

My last trip included har-gow, siu-mai, gai-bow and joung.
All boxed-up and ready to enjoy later that night.
I did nosh on a gai-bow on the way back to car.

Sidenote: I actually know someone named Wing Lee (it's not his bakery).

If you're in the neighborhood, consider making a stop here.
I'm giving this a 3.75-star experience.
author: Derek N.

description: Really cheap, super delicious steamed buns served with the slightly irritated, indifferent service I've come to expect from quality Chinese joints. Tasty hot sauce as well.
author: Sam G.

description: Meh. Not very good. Their dim sum was not as good as other places in the area. I would not recommend. The staff are quick and friendly. I will not be back.
author: Janet D.

description: The dim sum here is amazing. I have been coming here since i was in a stroller. Such excellent food. Too bad they dont accept card. I will still always come here.
author: Jeff L.

description:
Super cheap and bomb dim sum.

I only order the pork shu mai and the pan-fried turnip cake so I can't tell you much about anything else, but man, for the price, these are so good. $1.60 for 3 pork shu mai- what a STEAL.
author: Patrick P.

description: Not good. Someone spoke very highly of this place, compared to other more popular places in the area... But the dim sum was overly doughy and the fillings just weren't executed quite well. There was an extra pork fat essence that turned me off. Har gow was sub par. With so many options near by, sadly I will not be returning
author: MyHanh H.

description: they have something called the "big chicken bun" and its so good.  I am from the east bay and i'll drive out all the way to sf for these buns.  They have so much stuff in the buns it's worth much more than what you paid (0.90 cents)
author: Stephanie Y.

description:
Man Yelp you have to start letting us rate 1/2 stars lol.
I think this place deserves a 3.5-4star.

As a dim sum connoisseur this place has the good and bads. Goods: egg yolk bun, sui mai, p/f shrimp chives dumpling and preserved egg congee. These are the only items I get here because Wing Lee is one of the better places that makes these items. 

So my normal routine on Clement St would be: come here for the specified yums, then head to Clement Bakery/Restaurant for baked goods, and finally to Good Luck dim sum for har gow. You just gotta know where you get the good stuff!

Oh and I was so peeved that Wing Lee tried charging me 10cents for a small container for hot sauce... can't complain I should know better, I ended up just squirting some of the hot sauce in my togo container. 

**note: this is the only place I trust the hot sauce, because they keep them in these ketchup bottles that don't allow people to touch it. Just in case anyone is OCD and cares enough about clean hot sauce with their dim sum. Cheers!
author: Jen L.

description:
My erotic and guilty pleasure. It's part scavenger hunt, part mystery box, part "ooo how cheap is it gonna be!" I'll pop in here unplanned on any odd day of the week at any odd hour and see what's steamin'.
 i've had good luck with the siumai, har gow, chive dumplings with 1 shrimp, some other odd dumpling with pork and shrimp... and today i had the very strangest; tofu skin wrapped around vermicelli, mushrooms, and carrot drenched in a sweet corn starch sauce. very bizarre... very intriguing to weirdos like me. Don't be shy to ask them to lift up the various lids, if it looks good eat it!
I usually spend exactly $5.10 for 6-9 hefty pieces. It's an experience for sure. Eat it plain, eat it with sauce, eat it hot, eat it cool... it's always interestingly yummy. I'd like to try other joints but I just always drift easily into this one...
author: Libra J.

description: Perhaps I'd have given more stars if I'd have been able to eat the food. But the lady behind the counter just passed me by in favor of some elderly Chinese people behind me. Fuck her. Lung Fung bakery 13 blocks west, also on Clement, retains my loyalty.
author: Joe G.

description: Oh Yum!   Stopped by to get my fix of BBQ pork bun goodness.  They have fantastic pork buns ($1.30 each), and all kinds of fantastic looking dim sum.  This time we didn't get any dim sum because there wasn't a free table in the place, but we will definitely be back soon.  Everything looks fresh and delicious.  Great prices too.
author: Christine Z.

description: My absolute favorite to-go dim sum place of all time! I've tried a variety of dim sum to-go on clement st but they don't compare to here! I love the sticky rice balls where the skin is thin and the rice balls are soft and chewy! I love the pan fried chive dumpling when it's hot (not nearly as good when it's cold!). The porridge is cheap and delicious! I always opt for the pork and thousand egg porridge, so filling and yummy for my tummy! In addition, I love the siu Mai and shrimp dumplings! The skin is thin and the ingredients taste fresh! I love the steamed taro dumpling too- haven't found it anywhere else in the city! If the lines look long, don't be fooled! It moves pretty quick and it is worth the wait! Cash only though so be prepared!
author: Jennifer W.

description:
This place can only be described as a hole in the wall.  I've been going there for awhile, just stopping in for their baked and steamed pork buns.  Both are very good, and when I think of pork buns the Wing Lee pork buns are what I think of.  

They have a great selection of dumplings, though i would recommend their chive dumplings, as well as their mixed pork dumplings.  They manage to get the dumpling wrapper just right, not gummy, but dense enough to not fall apart when you're trying to eat it.  Their congee was pretty good too, though a bit bland for my taste.  A little soy sauce and sriracha took care of that though.  It would have been nice if there was  more meat (chicken or pork) along with the rice porridge, but it filled me up and was a great thing to eat on a cold day like today.  I would also recommend the rice rolls and the wrapped lotus leaves.

Their prices are ridiculously cheap.  You can get an order of 3 dumplings, a pork bun, and a huge portion of congee for under $5!  There is always a line waiting for dim sum with both Asians and non-Asians, which is certainly a good sign  

Atmosphere wise, it's doesn't exactly strike me as the cleanest place, but maybe that adds to the charm?  Maybe.
author: Adam E.

description:
I have been eating here for years as it's right across the street from one of my favorite bookstores.  Wing Lee is pretty good, and really really cheap.
It is not the best dim sum in the city for sure, but the price is right. If you want the best selection, come early.  They run out of taro pretty fast.

Also, be prepared to be a little pushy if you want to get helped. Some of the neighborhood ladies seem to feel that they shouldn't have to wait in line. I beg to differ, ladies.  So no I'm not going accept you stepping ahead of me unless you're ancient and have a cane. 

Lastly, no frills, but if you eat it here in the crappy 'dining room'  it'll taste best.  If you try to take it home it wont hold up so well.
author: El B.

description:
Cheap, but you get what you pay for. Truly a takeout dim sum place, and they should make that clearer. At noon on a Sunday, we found the food was barely warm. When we asked the employee to warm it up in the microwave, we were met with a cringing, reluctant look. Best if you buy it back and warm it up in the comfort of your own home.

The portions were large and filling, but that might be because they used a lot of flour in the dishes with wraps or buns and the "skin" wrappings were very thick. The rice noodle roll (cheong fun) in particular had thicker than normal skin, so by the end we started picking out the meat to eat instead.

FYI, the Shanghai dumplings here are done in a different style with the flour buns instead of the dumpling soup wrap that is seen in some dim sum places.
author: Audrey L.

description: Edible but all tasted a little off. You can definitely find better dim sum nearby. We had potstickers, shrimp and leeks, shrimp, sesame w/bean curd, and pork buns.
author: Sarah M.

description:
This place is not too bad.

Stopped in here after seeing how busy it was, also to see the line stack up I figured it had to be a local favorite.

Place appeared to be fairly clean compared to others and it was busy enough to tempt me.

Not starving but in the mood for a quick savory treat, I decided to go with one chicken kabob and a custard bun all for $2.50 not bad at all.

Service was friendly, quick yet sincere.

The chicken kabob was surprisingly delicious- meaty and flavorful with few little pieces of fat throughout, though not too bad.

Custard bun was ok, texture was fluffy soft and chewy (definite plus) though HUGE! Little to big for me. Custard with in bun was the best part; I actually ended up just throwing most of the actual bun out and eating custard part.

Overall from what I had it was descent and flavorful, prices are great and I do believe I would go back to try more of there different types of buns ect...
author: Shannon H.

description:
My favorite dim sum spot. The pork buns are amazing whether you get them steamed or baked. The dumplings are huge and full of flavor too. And it's CHEAP! $0.90 for a bun or 3 dumplings for $1.80. You can get a ton of food for around $5. 

It's a definite stop when wandering around Clement street, or a destination for a quick bite on the weekend. Remember, cash only!
author: John R.

description:
Oh man, their combo chicken baos are pretty delish! 

I crave those sometimes! So filling, and two meals! I usually split it in half and it'll fill me up for lunch! 

Also, they have these fried shrimp dumplings that are basically like fried har gaws. 

YUM!
author: Alison N.

description:
mmmmmm CHA SIU BOW baked bbq pork buns!!!! I LOVE this place!
They've been here since my childhood with amazing prices and COMFORT FOOD.
Take-out the baked pork buns, pork siu mai, and mooncakes to picnic in GGPark  : )
author: Bunny C.

description:
The dim sum here is excellent! I always get the shrimp dumplings. The secret hot sauce is the best and found no where else! If you're looking for good service, you won't find it here.... the employees are nice enough, but interactions are short, as they're all about business. Definitely worth it. They do have a bathroom for customers, and it's usually clean enough.

Definitely worth trying for lunch!
author: Kali L.

description:
I must say, their Ha-gow (shrimp dumplings) are YUM! Full of flavor and always fresh! This place is consistently busy and the trays/ containers of steamed delicacies are usually replenished every 20 min. The pastries are made in the morning, but I can't review them because I've never had them. =)

Great place for favorable tasting and cheap Dim Sum on the go!

1. Steam pork buns
2. Ha-Gow (shrimp dumplings)
3. Sweet rice cake
4. Pork shumai Dumplings
5. Fun-goh (pork, shrimp, mushrooms)
author: Oliver D.

description:
It has passed the lunch time and I was really starving. I stopped by at this place and ordered as though there's no tomorrow. It's true that the place is cheap and one can be very well fed under $15. Unfortunately, I am not impressed with the food. 

The size of each dumpling is big, but that's because the skin is thicker than it normally is.  I tried the har gow, shrimp and chive dumplings and vegetable steam dumplings--all of which delivered their usual taste but I am not a big fan of the thick skin. There's also a good amount of fat in each har gow. The egg custard tart tasted really bland and I had a hard time finishing one. I also ordered the chicken combination bun, the custard bun, and the sesame balls, and I was not impressed with any of these.  They all came with larger size, with bigger portion of the skin/flour.  It's not that I am hard to please, but I doubt if you would feel the same if you had been to many other better dim sum places--esp those in SoCal! 

The bottom line is that the place would be a quick fix for anyone craving for dim sum. The best part is that it is cheap. But in terms of the food, don't expect the best or anything impressive here. And be prepared to have some thick skinned dumplings!

Staffs are friendly and the lady who helped me with the order had a smile on her face. Not that it's unusual but probably worth a note. Cash only. Parking depends on luck. I got a spot within 5 min on a weekend.
author: Elle W.

description:
Another steamed chicken bun review from yours truly.  I believe I've had steamed chicken buns from every dim sum takeout place that offers them on Clement, Irving, Noreiga and Taraval (though I haven't written a review for all of those places).  Wing Lee offers a good version of the steamed combination chicken bun but Clement Restaurant's steamed chicken buns reign supreme in the Richmond and the Sunset.

Combination chicken bun analysis ($1.30):
* Appearance/construction:  Round and big, not that heavy though.  The filling is not tightly packed inside but appeared to be almost in four separate areas.  The bun was too loose.  
* Bun dough: good flavor, smooth, slightly sweet, not too dense but a little denser than Clement Restaurant's, not soggy at all
* Filling:  The chicken chunks are bigger here which is a nice touch.  Comes with one whole shitake mushroom, a piece of Chinese sausage, a wedge of hard-boiled egg.  Nicely seasoned, not too salty, tender chicken.  Needs more filling.
* Temperature: Served warm (big plus)

The combination chicken buns are the most expensive steamed buns they have.  They had other steamed buns like chicken, pork & vegetable, egg custard, etc., and baked buns too.  The dim sum dumplings looked larger than average (3 for $1.50) and they had chewy red bean pancakes.  I didn't step foot into the deli side which has a separate entrance.  Seating is available.  

Cash only of course.
author: Lolia S.

description:
Cash Only!

Popular items are super fresh and hot: shrimp dumplings, pork/other buns, siu mai - anything in the ginormous metal steamers or in the bun ovens. The bun dough is fluffy and a bit sweet, which I love but some find odd. I also love the BBQ chicken skewers - charred to perfection with lots of juicy, flavorful fatty bits laced through each bite. 

The items offered to the left, near the window, are less fresh and not always piping hot. They do offer a few vegetarian options: a vegetarian bun, a tofu skin roll, and the almost-vegetarian fried marinated tofu with mystery fish paste filling (which you can just detach with a fork), but none of these are usually served hot.

I promise they don't serve anything super creepy like mashed brains or chicken feet disguised in buns, so pretty please - don't be the guy who holds up the line pointing at everything asking "what's that? what's that? what's that?" If it looks tasty, just try it! It probably will be.
author: Diane Y.

description: Good food and service was great almost too good. Its dimsum ! They bombarded me with choices and there is nothing wrong with that. Just go there take your time and relax !
author: Samir A.

description:
STEAM. PORK. BUNS. The end. 

Not really the end, but the steam pork buns are no joke. The dough is just right and the meat inside is perfection. Whenever I visit my parents in So.Cal I always have to bring them back a box of the steam pork buns or they wont let me in the house. A dozen of these bad boys are less than $10! 

The rest of the dim sum is pretty good too, and cheap ($1.60 for 3 pieces) But if you want the good stuff you should plan on coming in the morning, the tend to run out later in the day. The sticky rice and taro dumplings are yummy!  

I've never sat to eat there, but they do have tables available to sit down and eat. But don't expect fine dining service. You get in line, wait your turn, point to what you want, then the workers yell "How many?" or "Anything else" and move on to the next one.
author: Mae L.

description: Clement Street is a good alternative to Chinatown, and, to me, Wing Lee Bakery is the very center of Clement Street.  Wing Lee is my all-around number-one pick for dim sum in the city.  It's not a fancy place by any means, but it's quick, cheap, and very delicious!  Parking can be difficult if you come at the wrong time or day, but it's better than Chinatown (and cheaper, too).
author: Chris Y.

description: Good food and best bang for your buck! My bf and I don't eat pork so we love this place because it has tons of non pork options.
author: Anne N.

description:
Cheap dim-sum to go! This is my go-to place when I'm craving dim sum & need it quick. You're getting good stuff for what you're paying for. $1.60 for 3 dumplings. 

Very thick & meaty dumplings, such as the shui mai & shark fin gow. I usually get those, along with some bbq pork buns and hargow with chives. 

Skip the shrimp rice rolls. The rice rolls are super thick, and the sweet soy sauce tastes watered down. 

FYI, this isn't one of those dim sum places where they push around the carts full of steaming dumplings. Definitely good stuff for the price though!
author: Katrina H.

description: My dad was craving dim sum simply because we were in Chinatown, SF so I yelped a place and the #1 spot was closed for remodeling!  Just our luck.  So Wing Lee seemed to be the second best place to go within walking vicinity.  Once we got there, there was a long line but it went by fairly quickly.  We ordered quite a few items and the only thing that stood out to me was chicken skewers.  Everything else was A-OK.  The lady behind the counter didn't know much english so it was a bit frustrating trying to communicate what we wanted.  However, the other ladies, while still busy helping other customers, were happy to help and didn't get impatient.  Pretty decent prices but food isn't great enough to get me to come back.
author: Yvonne N.

description: solid 4 stars.  Dim Sum was tasty and very well priced.  We came in after 6pm (which it said it was closed) and presumably we got the leftovers, which was fine.  Quite tasty still!
author: Matt V.

description: They have the best BBQ pork steamed/baked buns! I just stopped by and bought 3 which cost $2.70. Amazing!
author: Grace C.

description: Geat dim sums and bakery stuffs. Expect the lady at the counter to give you a strange look and attitude. But I am here for the foods anyway.
author: Edith C.

description:
Clement street.  If you know the name of the street and you know where it is in the city you are setup. Setup for everything like groceries, food, restaurants, man pretty much anything.   Not gonna lie you can survive on pennies if you live near Clement.

I call it chinatown #2. Chinatown #1 we all know. Chinatown #2 though is where you can find parking on the street most of the time...  everything you want and anything you need or really don't need as well you'll find here along this stretch of clement....

If yah haven't been to Wing Lee before you probably have passed by it.  Don't be afraid next time you happen to be around the corner of 6th and Clement area swing on by you won't be going home unhappy.

Not gonna fill this review up with fluff thats already mentioned in other peoples review about the dim sum and what not offered here.  Its pretty damn good for a take out place where you go in having a general idea of what you want and leaving the spot.  You can't compare it to a sit down restaurant because this aint a fucking sit down restaurant that serves dim sum and shit.   Well I've actually been here several times over the past few years just getting around to submitting a yelp review because I guess thats what you gotta do if you like a place or if you don't like one as well.

Bottom line, some good o'l fashion dim sum and baked goods being peddled outta this joint.  You probably heard it before and if ya have good for you.  If ya dont know now ya know! - Cheap and fast, way better than garbage fast food corporations.  If you want cheap, fast, the oh hells yeah stuff come on here for the fucking yummy shit.  I'm actually hungry thinking about what I'm writing about...   HHHHHottt  dawwwwggggggg!   Baaaazoooookah!
author: marcus o.

description: Cool little Dim Sum place in the Richmond district, great authentic food at a great price, I can't resist picking up a thing or two when I'm in the area.
author: Nick F.

description: BEST DIM SUM IN SF! I am not overdoing it here. It is really that great. Whole wheat pork bun. OHHHHH sweet satan I gotta get my butt back out to the Richmond.
author: Amy W.

description:
Har gow for $1.60/3 pieces??

Yes Please! 

I go to Wing Lee's when I need a quick dim sum fix . The shrimp dumplings are consistently big, so cheap and tastes good! I kind of shudder sometimes when I go to a sit down dim sum place knowing that I can go here and get twice as much dim sum for the same price. 

I steer clear of the items by the window though, they are cold.
author: Valerie P.

description:
My friend, D, and I stopped by for some take-out dim sum.  
I got:

3 Sesame balls (my favorite)
2 baked buns
2 wives buns (buns with bitter melon)
4 moon cakes with bean paste

all for $7.50

They were freshly made and yummy.

My friend, D, got sesame balls and wives cakes.  She said the sesame ball was the best she ever had!

We happened to catch them when there was no line!  But by the time we finished ordering there was a line out the door.

Service was friendly.  And she carefully wrapped all my purchases separately so they arrived home tasty and unscrunched!

I could have easily have ordered more but I knew I was going to be returning!
author: Rinky N.

description: I used to really like this place but now the dim sum seems to be dry and overcooked in the steamer.
author: Carolyn N.

description:
Take-out dim sum...hmm...while the concept is not new even in Hong Kong, it certainly is not what I think dim sum should be. Granted, I'm rating this place based on the food alone.

If you read every review, you'll find that the reason this place gets a lot of stars is because it's cheap. The reason I'm giving the place a 2-star is also because it's cheap...dirt cheap, because the food isn't even worth that.

But if you know anything about dim sum -- don't believe the reviews. All the dim sum are oversized and cheap, but, well, they hardly compare to the offerings of any good dim sum restaurants in the area. Worst is, when I ordered the radish cakes (which actually tastes pretty good) and rice noodles (with beef in it), they have to microwave the food, right in front of my eyes.

Speaking of which, rice noodles (cheung fun) are supposed to be very, very thin, with meat rolled up into it. The rice noodles here have to be more than 0.5 cm thick, which is nothing like I've seen.

So, if you're tight on money, this place will feed you well. (a bbq pork bun is bigger than my hand, but the filling is just so-so) If you're hunting for good dim sum spots, you might want to pass on this -- even with the cheap price I don't think I'll go there again. It's all about the price to quality ratio - I've had way better dim sum for just a bit more than that price.
author: Alice C.

description: Are you broke? Running low on money? Feeling hungry, and wanting to stuff your face until you slowly and happily fall into a coma? Well Wing Lee Bakery is the place to do it! But seriously, Wing Lee is a fantastic spot to get great dim sums, in large quantities for very cheap! If I go in and get 5 dollars worth, I'll be very content. Wing Lee however is not a place you go for the atmosphere, just the food. If you want a nice sit down dim sum place, I'd recommend somewhere else, but if you want great dim sum to go or just a quick bite, this is the spot!
author: Matthias K.

description: I ordered sui mai, steamed pork buns, and sesame balls. All of the were good. the pork buns were bigger than I expected. they were also full of filling. The sui mai were very moist and flavorful. The sesame balls were alright. I've had better, but they were good. All in all this place was good and I will come back any time I'm on Clement St. For three pork buns, six sui mai and four sesame balls I paid about $7. The price was good and the dim sum was good takeout.
author: Thomas J.

description:
i can't read the reviews on this page. I cannot see how there are so many 4 star reviews. This food is out o control. Take a bike through the pan handle, a bit into the park and into Inner Richmond. 

eat the pork buns. fall in love.

head over to green apple and peruse the selection of great books while fantasizing about your new secret obsession.

lose your cool. bolt. head across the street, back into the loving embrace of the bbq pork buns, smother in their chili paste, washed down with a bottle of water so as to not taint the delicate flavor of the bun with a fruity or sugary beverage.

buy 4 more buns and take them home to your friends.

you have arrived.
author: Sean F.

description:
megh. just ok dimsum... always on the quest for the best everything.. and I am not a fan of this spot..

the siu mai is very meaty.. but not much too it than that.. 

the har gow.. way too much of the wrap.. and not enough shrimp... 

overall. I won't be returning.
author: Lisa Marie N.

description:
Shrimp dumplings: ehhh
Chives dumplings: yahhhhhhhh  *thumbs up*
Shu mai: yahh

cheap and fast. can't go wrong here! And don't be surprised if you get yelled at by chiinese ladies, lol.
author: Emily T.

description:
Food: 3 stars
Price: 5 stars

As a cantonese american growing up with dim sum I would have to say that the food here was so-so.

Charsui bao: Good but the pork was a bit runny and saucy. I sense that they must put a butt load of sugar and not that much quality char sui. The white bread surrounding the meat was good though.

Chicken kabob stick: chicken had a nice bbq flavor but was greasy and kind of dry and overcooked. 

Har gow: the shrimp part was good but the rice part was overly thick and was very greasy.

Cocktail bun: a bit dry and the filling was a bit dry also. I mean overall the bun was good but I definitely had better in many other places. I know $0.60 cents is cheap but most places sell that thing 4/$1 and it tastes way better.

Overall the food here is ok but the price is FREAKIN CHEAP! i didn't even know they sell dim sum for so cheap. 3 hargow for 1.50?? Huge bbq pork bun for $.80?!?! The weekend before this i got a nasty and dry viet sandwich for $4 a block from this place.

I would come here if I just wanted a quick fix but in order to get quality dim sum you are going to have to go a (good) restaurant (Tai Wu and Koi Palace and Fook Yuen come to mind).
author: Em F.

description:
I used to spend much of my live in this part of town, though have since moved to Sacramento. I keep going back to this place, though, whenever I'm in NW San Francisco. I'm particularly fond of stopping here to get food to take for a picnic at the GG Bridge or in GG Park.

Is it the most authentic dim sum? Honestly, I have no idea -- I'm a gweilo -- but it compares favorably to the food I enjoyed in Oakland's chinatown as a kid, so I figure it must at least come pretty close to hitting the mark.

One note: They aren't as busy as Good Luck, which means you're usually in and out in two minutes. But it also means that there isn't as fast of turnover in food, so freshness is occasionally an issue. I say it's worth the trade off -- but be warned and take a moment to ensure what you're ordering is fresh because cold pot stickers aren't so good.
author: Devin L.

description:
This is my GO-TO spot whenever I'm having a dim-sum craving. Is it the best dim-sum there is to be had, well no, but that's to be expected considering you can feed 2 for $10. My "must" items are the shumai which are obscenely large and thus ridiculously filling and pork-riffic, the BBQ baked pork buns (which I think are significantly better than Good Luck down the street) - I usually get 4 of these to eat throughout the week b/c they are that good, and lastly sesame balls which are perfectly crisp and contain just the right amount of ooey gooey red bean filling.

Service here is quick and efficient, just don't expect too many smiles.
author: David H.

description:
I do not care what anyone else says but I love this place. It is my personal favorite and in my opinion, best place in SF to get dim sum.

The neighborhood is amazing and friendly. The store is no different! The workers are all nice, friendly and prompt. Quick and easy service :] There are a few tables and chairs inside for those who want to eat inside but i usually just order to go and eat in while walking around Clement. Also, what I love most about this place is how clean the store is and how not greasy their food is. YAY!

This place is a most def. recommended spot for those who like dim sum. Check it out!  (Order the ha gao's :} )
author: Michael N.

description:
Not the best dim sum around, but how can you beat $1.50 dim sum?! For $1.50, you can get an order of nice plump shrimp dumplings (har gow), pork dumplings (shiu mai) or many many other kinds of dim sum hot off the steam racks.  And their dumplings are pretty reasonably sized too.

Bottom line: Probably one of the best dim sum cheap eats in SF area. Come here for value and for a quick and satisfying fix to your dim sum craving but don't expect fine dim sum.
author: Jim C.

description:
We found ourselves in the Inner Richmond last weekend after a quick visit to Cheap Pete's. Once my framing needs were taken care of it seemed like a good time to explore Clement street. 

First off, I was in awe at how many Chinese food restaurants there are out there. It's literally like a whole other China Town. Secondly, I'm a huge fan of pork buns at Wing Lee. I ask you, how is it that BBQ pork smothered in sweet, sticky dough is so good? It's not complex. It's not groundbreaking...but damn is it good. They're huge too. Just one was the perfect amount. 

The potstickers were awesome too but the fried rice balls were weird and not flavorful. Stick to the buns and the stickers.
author: Julia N.

description:
Stopped in on Saturday November 12th, 2011 around 5 PM. Immediately greeted by the staff - and was able to order. I liked the fact that they had the menu in English on the walls.

Amazing Har Gow and Pork Dumplings! Dumplings were full of shrimp and pork. As others stated 3 dumplings for $1.60 which is a steal; two orders of dumplings; a chicken skewer and a diet soda ran to $5.60! Meal with quite filling and actually extremely healthy!
author: Brian D.

description: I got their sesame balls and it was pretty bland. There was so little filling and the har how was nothing special. I suggest tallying up the total yourself. They told us 3 for 1.90 and when we computed it all later we realized they over charged us .10 more per item then stated. 10 cents might now seem like much but 10 cents per item and if done with every person it can add up to a decent amount of extra money for them! False advertisement
author: Jewlz L.

description: Delicious and cheap! This is my spot for some cheap dim sum. The place itself is very simple, but the food hits the spot!
author: Brisa D.

description:
I wanna know what crawled up the butt of the person helping me. 

I don't consider dim sum places the gold standard of customer service but damn, can you maybe not complain loudly about how I'm not supposed to buy "only" one of each of the dim sum I picked? (apparently they're sold in increments of 3 or 4. wtf, i'm not gonna buy that many of the SAME kind.) Last time I checked it wasn't illegal to just get three different ones. Would it hurt to ask if I wanted it to go or for here so you don't have to get mad at me because I interrupted you putting them in the microwave? Yeesh.
author: Tiffany C.

description:
As far as dim-sum goes, this is as good as it gets on this side of Chinatown.

First off, food is (in order of importance) a) tasty, b) cheap, and c) filling.  

The steamed buns are 70 cents each (Except for the chicken special one, which is $1.20, and twice as big as the regular chicken one.)  Now take heed; these are huge.  My favorite is the pork vegetable one.  Baked buns are slightly more, like 80 cents to $1.  

They have a pretty good variety of dimsum.  There's not as many as at a sit-down restaurant, but for some reason, all the ones that I usually order anyway are here, shrimp and chive gow, shark fin gow, shrimp har gow, or tun cake.  3 of a kind for $1.50, but if you're nice, they might let you mix and match!

Jook (congee), especially the chicken one, is hearty and yummy and a bowl is $2.

Lobby is cozy and (relatively) clean.

I generally don't give a shit about service, because you can't eat service.  However, service here doesn't really leave anything to complain about.  They're incredibly efficient and neither friendly nor unfriendly (which puts them probably among the friendliest 20% of Chinese restaurants.)

The only thing I wasn't impressed with was the steamed BBQ pork bun.  It was edible, of course, but too much corn starch for my liking.  If you want a good laugh...order the steamed sausage bun.

Nothing beats sitting here with a comforting bowl of jook and a steamed bun and assorted dimsum before you while staring out into the rain.
author: David A.

description:
Great buns.  BBQ pork, steamed pork and veggie, chicken, or custard, etc.  Good quality and just yummy.

Good dim sum and jook.  Like everyone else is saying...$1.50 for an order of dim sum--the har gow, siu mai, potstickers, etc.  They also have the shrimp rice noodles, turnip cake, etc.  My favorite jook here is the ginger chicken.  The egg-and-pork isn't bad either, but I prefer the ginger chicken--a bit spicy, shiitake mushrooms, and just delicious and warm.

Note: Depends on when you go here.  Sometimes the food will sit there and become stale.  Other times, it's really fresh and ready to eat off the pans.  Also, they only take cash.  But a $20 will go a long way here for 4 people.  ;-)  They have a few tables for sit-down, but I'd suggest doing take-home...it'll be cleaner and more comfortable.  You've been warned!
author: Fannie S.

description:
The pricing is far better than places in china town - they are not catering tourists but rather local Asian community - which is a plus as you are more likely to get fresh food, and the pricing is far better than their downtown counterparts. 
My favorite is lotus seed moon-cake. Not sure if this is the best as it can be ( and if it is really all lotus seed paste inside or just mixed with white bean paste), but I found it very tasty not overly sweet or greasy.
author: M. M. K.

description:
If you just want dim sum without the atmosphere, to take home or to eat at a long table with elderly Chinese ladies, you can get satisfaction here for under $5 compared to over $20 at Ton Kiang. They have multiple kinds of sticky rice so try them all and the "big chicken bun" is usually generously filled. Ask for hot sauce if you are taking out and they'll give you some little containers you can fill from the jars on the tables.

This place is popular but the line seems to move much faster than Good Luck down the street.
author: Otis M.

description:
Super super cheap dim sum. You get what you pay for. 

The quality is meh, the outside of siu mai and ha gow is dry and thick. I get allergic to not fresh seafood and I'm definitely get allergic reaction when I eat anything that's got seafood in it here.
My white friends all seem to love the cha siu bao here, but I find it too fatty.
author: Erica L.

description: This is the best place for steamed pork buns. Very large excellent char siu pork nice and sweet and very addicting. Only $1.00 for 1 bun such a deal!
author: Roxy T.

description:
This "bakery" offers dim sum to-go, along with other chinese baked goods;   very similar to the nearby Good Luck Dim Sum.  I came to try this place when my stomach was too impatient for the long line at GLDS.

Har Gow: not bad, with full shrimp inside, but personally not a fan of some other ingredient that was also inside. (3 @$1.60)
Cilantro/Chive Gow: who/why would you put chunks of celery in a dumpling?!?!  fail. (3 @$1.60)
Siu Mai: pretty good and like that it wasn't too salty (3 @$1.60)
Sesame Ball: too doughy and rubbery. no go.
Chicken Bun: this chicken but that's big(ger) than your face (or my face!) was pretty good.  Big pieces of chicken and boiled egg inside a fresh bun.   This is repeat worthy. ($1.40)

Take-Away: As other reviews indicate, it's hard not to compare to GLDS.   Service is friendly(ier) and the pieces are bigger, but the skin is thicker and the ingredients are funny.
author: Carol K.

description:
Around noon one Saturday, I wanted to get some local dim sum with friends, and so we decided to try Wing Lee because of the good reviews. Unfortunately it seems hard to find a low-priced dine-in dim sum restaurant around SF, but this one had tables in the back that allowed you to order up front and eat at the restaurant. Hungry and reluctant to search further, we decided to eat here. I still miss the family style dim sum with the turning tables though.

The food was alright. I definitely have had better. The pork bun wasn't as tasty and sweet as I would've hoped. The rice noodle roll was thick, and the sauce wasn't that tasty. The egg custard wasn't as sweet and creamy as I hoped, and the crust wasn't flaky as other egg custards I've had. The other food was generally your normal dim sum.

So overall, the place wasn't that bad, but definitely not on par with the good dim sum restaurants I've tried. It was definitely cheap, but not worthy of 4 stars. Everything seemed a bit bland, but not bad I suppose.
author: Stephen P.

description:
although i've had better dim sum, wing lee is still very tasty...and you can't beat it for the value...

also great, if you want to grab something quick.  the ladies that work there are very efficient...so, it's basically in and out as long as you know what you want.  you stand in line (usually pretty short)...point ...pay...then enjoy.  you can easily have a meal for just around $5...with that type of deal, not much to complain about...

dim sum

pork dumpling

author: Amanda S.

description:
Becca's Christmascapade 2010 - A Triptych.
Part the First

I wanted to make it a diptych because it's a funnier word but alas, I patronized three businesses on Christmas day.  Wing Lee was the first.  I have previously found it hard to choose to go to a dim sum restaurant other than Good Luck, and so I planned in advance on going to Wing Lee.  My resolve was strong - I had passed by the goodies in their window many times, and the time was nigh for some of those goodies to land squarely in my stomach.

When we got there at 11am, it was really crowded!  Prime brunch time on a weekend, so that certainly made sense.  But the line moved quickly, and there was plenty of space at their long, communal tables to fit my boyfriend and me.  The line gave me plenty of time to covetously ogle their bountiful spread (Look, Ma!  No thesaurus!), and I was really impressed.  Their selection seemed to include a few more options than I was used to - combination buns, sweet steamed buns, baked buns, siu mai, potstickers, rice rolls, sticky rice, rice cakes, cakey cakes, and all with a variety of fillings.  We settled on the coriander gow, beef siu mai, taro dumplings, chicken sticky rice, and a chicken combination bun.

The shining stars, for me, were the beef siu mai.  The meat simply melted in my mouth, and the first bite revealed the glorious innards, in which the beef shone a lovely shade of pink.  The coriander gow were a close second, featuring more shrimp than I thought could fit in something so small, the tangy kick of the Chinese celery, and a rice wrapper thicker than you would think it had a right to be.  The taro dumpings were also impressive, containing more taro than I would have thought could possibly be squished into a dumpling of that size.

The combination bun and sticky rice were also really good, but not as flavorful as I would have liked.  The combination bun is a really interesting concept, combining multiple parts of a chicken with egg, sausage, and mushroom, but for everything that was in there, it was a little bland.  The bun itself, however, was really substantial but still fluffy.  My other gripe is that Wing Lee dim sum seems to all fall apart rather easily.  I realize this probably happens because the ingredients are fresher, or better for me, but it's a little less fun to eat a dumpling when you're desperately trying to make sure that you don't have to settle for eating all its components separately.

The atmosphere was delightful, and contained just the right amount of shouting in Chinese from the front counter back into the kitchen.  The tables were all clean, and were wiped down as I was watching, and there was only one bottle of hot sauce in the whole place, but I always find it really fun to share.  I'm very glad I went, and look forward to going again and sampling even more of that impressively ginormous menu.
author: Becca S.

description:
Like Good Luck Dim Sum, this place is cheap cheap cheap. They also have most all the usual dim sum items but I think they specialize more in breads and buns. I got their baked BBQ pork bun and it's DELICIOUS. Soft, fresh, and loads of goodness inside (not small shiesty portions you would expect from one of those sit-downs). Also tried the fried dumplings - also really really good. 

If I had to compare the two, I think Good Luck wins. The line was super long at GL vs 2-3 people at WL so I guess that says something? But whatever, do what I did and hit up both! 

Oh and they speak some English so keep the broken Chinese to yourself haha :P Cash only!
author: Yee-Shing W.

description:
This afternoon I had a supernatural yearning for an egg custard tart. I popped in here and got two for $1. 

Satisfied the hankering lickety-split.
author: Miriam W.

description: I've been a fan of this place since I was 12, and nothing has changed! Not my absolute fav, but it does the job when you get a dim sum craving. The combination bao is fantastic, and the shark fin dumpling is amazing. The shrimp har gow has a thicker skin that i notice some don't like, the sew mai (both pork and chicken) are filling and larger than most places and very tasty! Gotta love the pork and preserved egg jook for under 3 bucks too! I can come here with 20 bucks and feed a 5 person family no problem. The only thing that can get tough is the parking situation- Too many people that don't know where they're going or how to use a blinker, otherwise, Wing Lee is in my top 5 dim sum places!
author: Jen M.

description: Apologies to all...I was in error...Chicken combo bun was $1.30 each, so price increased $0.10 only!
author: Shirley N.

description:
This is my 2nd Dim Sum experience in SF.

I found this place by looking for the best of in Citysearch

I was not disappointed. Everything was cheap, and awesome.

I got there about noon time, and it wasn't as busy as I was expecting.

Coming from Miami any Dim Sum is good Dim Sum, but this place was definitely good and unbelievably cheap. I ordered a lot of food and it only came out to $4.40 and I was stuffed all day!
I wish I had more time here, I would have gone back to try everything (well, almost) on the menu.)

The only problem: now I'm spoiled. I won't go into my why Miami sucks for food (and everything else) rant on here..

I will be coming back for more!
author: Jeff G.

description: After +40 years of eating Dim Sum  ...I've got to say this is pretty good. Excellent prices, fresh product, friendly staff. Cafeteria Style service, a few tables to eat there if you want - not a 'cart style' restaurant.
author: Rich F.

description:
If you've only got a few minutes, and not a lot of cash, there is no meal quite as satisfying as a plate of dim sum from Wing Lee Bakery.  The food is very good and well-priced, and while the atmosphere is stark and spare, there is usually room at one of the tables where you can take a load off and relax for a few minutes while you eat your meal.  

They are constantly restocking the counter with big bamboo steamers filled with shrimp dumplings, pork dumplings, chicken dumplings with peanuts, spinach dumplings, and rice balls.   All delicious, and about 4 pieces will cost you around $2.00, and fill you up very nicely.  

They also have my favorite custard tarts, in a small size that will satisfy your sweet craving without putting you into a lunch coma.   If you really want to go for it, get a sesame ball, which is one of my favorites with its rich, oily, sweet/savory flavor.

You can't do much better than Wing Lee for well-made, nicely priced, fresh dim sum.  And the service, while more efficient than warm, could almost border on friendly.  I'll take it!
author: Liz S.

description: I decided to try this place out after a minute of waiting in a long line at Good Luck Dim Sum. I ordered the fresh shrimp noodles, what I thought the lady said was shrimp and chive, some shu mai, and two bean curd rolls. From what I've tried I still prefer the dumplings at GLDS but the decent quality and no lines makes it a good choice. The shrimp dumpling that I ordered had celery, carrots, and cilantro and it really grossed me out. Haha I'll be avoiding those in the future. The shu mai was decent, not super juicy though, and the shrimp noodle were actually really good but I always miss the sweet soy sauce. What I'm glad this place has is the bean curd rolls! Bean curd wrapped around glass noodles, fungus, mushrooms, and baby corn is right up my alley. I forgot to try a gai bao, but I definitely want to get one next time.
author: Krystle S.

description:
I like the staff there as they're quite friendly, especially towards end of the day when business is slow.

Food just isn't very fresh relative to other dim sum to go places on Clement.  Their hargow (shrimp dumpling) is always very peppery to mask the stale seafood taste.  Their dim sum sizes are larger than the competitors'.   Good thing is if the food's cold, they'll at least heat it up for you in the microwave.  

They do have the BBQ pork puff (baked pastry) which is hard to find in other dim sum places.
author: Yvonne Y.

description: This is our favorite place for cheap dim sum in San Francisco. We usually pick up food since there are very few tables and it often gets crowded. Their siu mai is very meaty and flavorful. The hargow has a thick doughy shell with large shrimp. They have a number of varieties of buns, including pork, chicken and pineapple (among others). The best thing about this place is the prices. Parking can be limited (street only - just keep circling and wait for someone to pull out if you have to), and there is no ambience, but you can't beat the price is in this area or in Sacramento.
author: Briana P.

description:
This is my go to spot for Dim Sum takeout. And there is a location in the Outer Sunset as well which is convenient. The dim sum is not the best, but you shouldn't be expecting that for a to go place.

The ha gows are plump and filled with shrimp not dumpling wrapping and the siu mai (chicken, beef, pork) are always tender and moist. I also would recommend one of the newer dim sum items, the taro dumpling for some variety. Congee comes in Pork w/ Preserved Egg and Chicken w/ Mushroom flavors and is never watery. 

The thing I have ordered in the past and didn't like was the shrimp or beef rolled up in flat noodles. Something about it doesn't taste right and it was cold. Otherwise, you can fill yourself up here with lotta good food for under $5. Great Deal!
author: Daniel L.

description: only came here because my mom loves their combo chicken buns! nothing is too far or waste of time, if it can put a smile on your moms face!! bought 10 for $15!
author: Winnie C.

description: Excellent egg custard. Plus, I liked the quiet of the cafe and appreciated the nice woman who stepped in to translate, when I asked a question.
author: Eva UnTiger S.

description: Amazing dim sum for amazingly cheap prices. This place is a completely different animal than Yank Sing which is also an excellent place minus the amazingly low prices. Here you can order a bunch of different things and it will be a full meal for less than $5. You can look at there picture menu on the wall or just point at the things you want to try. Just remember that it is cash only.
author: Ben U.

description: I am a dim sum fanatic and this is the place where i get my fix
author: Seaera T.

description:
Summary:
        On a cold gloomy day my sister Ermalyn called me to pick her up because she didn't want to wait 2 hours for our Aunt to get out of the Dentist. By the time I got there my Aunt was already done, so my sister told me to follow them so she can buy me some Siopao to take home. Before she told me to follow them she made fun of my "almost- falling off-licenses plate" .. haha.. I told her I liked it that way because it makes my car look unique.. hehe.
         So I followed, parked my car, put two nickels in the meter and walked towards Wing Lee Bakery. The place was small but big enough to dine in. My sister treated me.. bought 10 B.B.Q Pork buns and 12 for herself. Steam buns for only $.80 each is a pretty good deal. I saw a sign that said "Try Our New And Healthy Wheat Buns!" I should have got half wheat and half regular.. ahh.. maybe next time.
         We left the restaurant and she gave me one box, while she took the other. We said our goodbyes and I went home.As soon as I got home I pulled the pink plastic string that held the box together and grabbed a bun. It was nice , warm, & fresh. I told myself to only eat one but my hand crawled its way back to the box. My sister gave me the wrong box because mine had 12 buns instead of 10.. thats ok.. more for me.. teehee. I will definately be going back to this place.

Ordered: B.B.Q Pork Buns
Food: Yummy.
Price: Cheap. Steam Buns for $0.80 each
Service: Good.
Place: Small-Medium. Dine In. To Go.
Parking: Meter.
author: Marie L.

description: Unbelievably cheap and great selection. Obviously it is not a "piping hot from the oven" place, but if you want cheap and quick dim sum, this is the place to go. Great flavor and perfect for bringing less experienced friends who can just point.
author: Amy H.

description: Since they open, one particular favorite i get by the dozens is the combination steam bun (Chicken, Sausage, Egg, Mushroom) and now they have in whole wheat !! Yelpers, just give it a try.
author: Kru X.

description: cheap 3 fir $2 dumsum  used to be 3 fir $1.60 and decent chicken congee .  However the rude and unfriendly attitude of the young counter woman with the ponytail is enough to go elsewhere.  She placed 3 dumsum  on a slippery paper on a slippery tray . As I walked up to the table to put it down it all slipped off and fell on the floor .  When I told her this she briskly said  "that's your problem!  It has nothing to do with us!"  with  a mean face  and loud voice .  I had not even sat down yet. To replace 3 little cheap dimsum   with a smile would have made me a faithful customer.  To be so rude and nasty and MEAN makes me go elsewhere. If you think senior citizen customers should be abused and you like bugs in your dumplings then do come here.  Otherwise there are many  better choices.  Try Gourmet Dim Sum down the street : good service by the lady there , cheaper , nicer fresher food too.  One star is already being generous .
author: Cynthia Y.

description:
I bought some dim sum to go this past Sunday, and it was JUST ALL RIGHT.  The custard cups were cold, and a little stale.

The man at the counter was nice, but the one younger woman helping me was very curt and lacked "grace" in the customer service area.  They all seemed a little full of themselves (for example, our dim sum is the business, and who cares about "customer service")

In conclusion, I wouldn't go back... I would probably stick to buying dim sum in Oakland on a Sunday (at least the parking is free... for now!)
author: Anonymous U.

description: I'm new to the whole dim sum to go thing. The places on Clement seem to specialize in long lines and extremely cheap food. You can buy pretty much three of any dumplings for $1 to $1.60. Wing Lee comes in at the high end. The food is OK. The service wasn't welcoming to me. No frills. Long lines, but not too long. Glad the menu was also in English. I think I'll stick with sit down places in the future.
author: Dave B.

description: this place was disgusting!!my pregnant best friend and our kids were first timers here and it was the worst place i have ever eaten...my "pregnant" best friend and i were craving for dim sum but the place that we wanted to go to was closed so we've decided to walk around to see what other dim sum place was open  and we seen this spot that was open..we ordered alot of dim sum and fried egg rolls n chow mein..my pregnant best friend bit into a raw beef siu mai and so i told the server my best friend is pregnant and the beef siu mai is raw she can't eat this can i get something other then this?they said no she already bit into it..i said she only bit into one of em and still said no! as i was walking back she noticed the ceiling was open like stuff can fall on us and then she noticed that there was a table with mouse traps!!uuugghhh come on don't ever put mouse traps where your customers can see it!!never again!!
author: Jocelyn F.

description: I am a fan of the porridge (pork w/ preserved egg), bread, and various dim sum. I head over on a Sunday morning after church and have 2-3 trays of food between 5 of us; all that for less than $15, its a good bang for the buck. Go for it!
author: Michael G.

description:
Cheap and pretty good dim sum here. I got an order of the Pork Shumai dumplings, 3-pieces, all for a buck fifty wow! So I thought I'd splurge and picked up a Chicken Bun for an additional 90 cents. You can eat in or grab food to go. Several steaming dim sum dishes to choose from. Service was fairly fast.

Tummy was satisfied and the wallet stuffed...
author: Gary E.

description:
small dim sum take-out, great value- most standard items are 3 for $1.50, and they have generous sized items. What I love even MORE about this place is the pork & preserved egg porridge (for $2.50 or so, feeds 2). Other items I love here:

Steamed BBQ pork buns
Pan-fried turnip cake
chives + shrimp dumpling
ha gow/ siu mai
bai tang gao- white sugar pastry
Loh mai gui- bamboo wrapped sticky rice

Now that I moved to the south bay, there's no comparison to Wing Lee's. Usually I swing by here and Schubert's if I'm in the area.
author: Lina C.

description: Great prices and Amazing dim sum.  Egg tarts are great, they even have congee.  Shrimp roll not so good but rice in banana leaf is good.  Like the turnip cake too.
author: Shirley H.

description: Love the gao's here- ha gao, ngui chi gao, etc.  I think most of them have the tranlucent white tapioca wrapping.  The one with taro inside is so good - it's savory b c of the meat but also sweet bc of taro.  You can get a lot for not a ton of $.  One of the best dim sum bakeries in SF IMHO!
author: Alias A.

description: Cash only sometimes makes it a challenge, but everything is so inexpesive it's worth it. Service is so-so, but only place I can get a great baked chicken bun.
author: Roya J.

description:
I love this place! Great dim sum takeout at an even more amazing price. I ordered a bunch of dim sum for lunch, and the whole thing cost me only 3.50. That's the price of a latte. Ahhhh think I'm in love. :)

Oh and if you're not Asian like me, here's a great sauce you can make to use as a dip for your dim sum:

Pour out some soy sauce
Throw in some white rice vinegar or red wine vinegar
Scatter in some garlic powder
Throw in a smidgen of sugar if you'd like
Maybe some sesame oil
And then some crazy-ass Asian chili hot pepper sauce.

Et voila. Cheap wonderfulness that will probably make your blood pressure skyrocket. Watch that sodium...
author: Michelle G.

description:
WOW! When I want to make my mom REALLY happy...I bring her home her fave DIM SUM from WING LEE BAKERY! 

At 3 for $1.50 how can one go wrong! Great Shrimp Gow, Pork Sew Mai, and Pot Stickers! Dinner for under $5? WOW!

Easy to point if the language barrier gets in the way...

TO GO is the best option. (NOT a sit-down type of place...)
author: Addadada A.

description:
Wow this place is awesome and super cheap.
I was completely stuffed and had food left over for dinner and spent 8 bucks.  Only gripe that I had was that the pork buns were understuffed with pork...but for 1$ each (baked), they were awesome price/value.
I would definitely go back.

TLDR: awesome cheap food
author: John B.

description:
Their steamed char siu bows are the best; most of all you can walk out of there and feel like you are getting more than your money's worth. The Har gow and siu mai, chicken w/peanuts - any steamed dumpling is good. Some of their fried things can be too doughy like their gin duey - but the fried pork turnovers are especially delicious. Sticky rice balls - yummy. Their jung with peanuts is especially good - except the duck egg - I can do without the duck egg - bleuhhhh.

For take-out dim sum - this is the place - go in the morning so you don't have to wait in line...I'm a big believer in NOT standing in line cuz I can think of better things to be doing. They seem to replenish in the morning a lot so it's the best time to go.  Remember - cash only!
author: Dee Z.

description:
The food here is alright if you are in a mood to be cheap. The dumplings skins were thick and kind of starchy. The shrimp in the shrimp dumplings were huge and not bite sized at all. They lacked flavor and the shrimp fell out as soon as I took my first bite. The pork siu mai were dry and the bottom was inedible. The pork sticky rice was bland and it didn't have the flavor that usually accompanies such a good thing. The chicken on a stick tasted alright but it too was a little dry. I also bought the chive dumpling and that was so-so.  I will say that their food is fresh, which is why I included the second star. 

Michael was surprised at how horrible it was.....He usually can eat anything and say that it was good. Diana couldn't taste so she couldn't tell you. 

I should've just stuck with going to Good Luck Dim Sum like my gut (and tummy) told me to.
author: emi s.

description: Dim sum is superb! quick efficient ladies at the counter. If you're looking for a smile and great customer service, this isn't your place. It serves its purpose dim sum to go.
author: Frank T.

description: One of my favorite dim sum spots on Clement St. Cheap, fast and delicious dim sum!  The steamed pork buns are a must-have, but love everything on the menu. It's so tempting to visit this place nearly everyday. A must try for any dim sum fan
author: Bridget B.

description: I would always come when I'm at clement st. This dim sum place is awesome!! Most of the time, the line will be long but it is worth the wait. I would always get the combination buns, custard buns, and the shrimp rice rolls. Everything here is delicious and affordable.
author: Jessica C.

description:
LOVE this place. Cheap hole in the wall place for dimsum. 

BUT

Watch out for the cochroaches! I've seen some crawl all over the baked goods, but for years I haven't let that stop me from buying the dimsum.
author: RoseMichelle M.

description:
Typically, on any given Sunday, my early afternoon consist of walking four blocks down the street with my roommate to Good Luck to get our dim sum grub on.  The line was to the back of the room, so we said forget it and looked for other spots for dim sum in the area.  So many to choose from, we decided to Yelp for a recommendation.  

That led us here, Wing Lee Bakery.  There was actually no one there, so we were standing in front of the counter immediately.  Prices here were still great (most of the things were 3 for 1.50).  Nothing to say about the decor of the place but again, these to-go dim sum shops aren't there for their fancy dining.  The dim sum here were noticeably bigger than usual which is nothing to complain about!  I still think the taste doesn't quite measure up to what I've had.  

All in all, I think this is a great alternative.  I am a fan!  Not my first choice in the area, but still very delicious and a couple blocks closer to me =D.
author: Tom Y.

description:
My favorite all time dim-sum in the whole Bay area.
The pot stickers and the chicken skewers with onion and green bell pepper are whats keeps me coming back. Parking is difficult but it's so worth to come here and get there mostly steamed items. 

It's a bad idea to get here any time after 5:30 and expect to get a wide assortment of there eats. Their items sell very quickly. Yes it is very crowded at times. I try to leave a "tip" and the ladies behind the counter get a little uneasy and or confused. I asked why one time and they said " These asian businesses work a little differently"? I was surprised.

If your thirsty you can bring your food into the 540 and have a beer and eat your dim sum in their bar.

Good times.
author: Andrew Z.

description: Wing Lee Bakery rocks!!!  Their dim sum is sooo delicious and the prices are incredibly inexpensive.  I like getting the sui mai and also their pastry that's filled with chives and shrimp.  I don't remember what they're called, but they're the bomb!  They also have steamed bean buns are really good too.  Whenever I'm in the area, I try to come here.
author: Amy L.

description: Great food with cheap price. Yes, best pork buns.
author: Rose H.

description: Growing up, my favorite dim sum snack was the lotus paste bun, a million years later, it still is! Wing Lee has sweet lotus buns and more non-meat pastries like sweet rice cakes and black bean cakes, and if you eat meat, this place will be your heaven. Prices are great, lines are not crazy long, servers are quick and not too mean. Thank goodness this place isn't in walking distance from my house or I would be there all the time! While the food tastes amazing, I can't imagine that much oil and refined sugar and flour would be good for me. I'd die a quick but happy death!
author: Valerie L.

description: I think I may have found the best har gow in town.  Fresh shrimp dumplings, fresh rice wrapper.  Chewy and absolutely delicious and pretty cheap too.  Also tried their combination pork dumplings and they're not too bad.  They sure don't skimp out on portion size with their dim sum.
author: Chai S.

description: Excellent tasty Dim Sum at a great price.  The potstickers are probably some  of the best in the bay, they've ruined me for any others, they're flavorful and filled with ginger/porky goodness and have a thin wrapper.   All in all good food and a reasonable price also it's only 2 doors down from Schuberts bakery, which is a very good thing.  The only down fall is the parking is horrendous, but it's SF not much to do about that.
author: Sara B.

description:
For those of you who go to UCSF, and often to go the nurseteria to get your dim sum.... STOP!  UCSF gets their food from here, so you should just come and get it yourself here!  it's so cheap, 3 pieces for $1.50.  Their shrimp dumplings are filled with lots of shrimp, and are sooo flavorful.  Their pork siu mai are also very yummy. What I like about this dimsum place in particular is that their dim sum is pretty big, and flavorful.  I don't think you can go wrong with anything at this place. =)

oh yea... Cash only!
author: Diane L.

description: Another one of my must-visit places in SF that I've been frequenting since the days when I lived there. Dim sum from Wing Lee, washed down with a pina colada tapioca drink from Sweet Delite next door is the perfect meal. I love the cheung fun (long, flat rice noodles filled with shrimp or other things), jeen duy (sesame ball with lotus paste inside), ha gow (shrimp dumplings), and leen yung bow (lotus paste bow). My grandpa is a huge fan of the bows, so we usually take at least a dozen home for him. I like the quick, informal atmosphere, and it's always fun to people watch while we're eating. Don't forget to make a stop at Green Apple across the street afterward!
author: Melody I.

description:
I swear by Good Luck Dim Sum for cheap takeout dim sum. However, it's closed on Tuesdays, and I was craving those little bites of goodness after quite a crappy morning. I had heard about Wing Lee on Yelp, so I decided to check it out.

My order:
+Har gow: Always a favorite for me when getting dim sum. They were stuffed to the brim with shrimp, as opposed to some places that make their har gow with what I swear is about a teaspoon of shrimp, if that. However, the wrapper was a bit too thick and glutenous for my taste.
+Chicken siu mai: Pretty average. I love mushrooms, but their flavor overpowered the chicken. 
+Sesame balls: A childhood favorite. I was incredibly disappointed in these. The outside was hard (which is really odd) and had very little bean paste. 

Other observations:
+Everything I ordered was exceptionally greasy. Well, save for the sesame balls, those are supposed to be fried greasy goodness.
+Fantastic prices. You can easily stuff your face for $6. 
+The ladies at the counter were slightly more personable than the ladies at Good Luck Dim Sum

In short, I'll likely be back if its Tuesday and I'm desperately craving some dim sum. Otherwise, I'm sticking with my usual/
author: Leigh R.

description:
I went to Hong Kong Lounge only to find a block party of people surrounding the place. I couldn't even get to the door to grab a number!
     Feeling defeated, I wandered around famished and barely conscious. I look up randomly to see a sign for Dim Sum to go. I got in line and ordered all the standard Dim Sum favorites. My hands were trembling by the time I handed over the money.
     I sat down, shoved some shrimp dumplings in my mouth and was immediately recharged!
     This place is actually pretty good. The fried taro dumplings were crispy and flavorful. The shrimp dumplings were packed full of delicious shrimp. The chives added an extra flavor dimension to the shrimp. The siu mei were also juicy, well seasoned, and delicious.
     The spring rolls and egg custards were nothing to write home about. How good the dishes were really depends on how long they've been sitting out. Some of the items were piping hot and amazing. Others were kinda luke warm. However, after stuffing my face for less than 10 dollars and saving hours of my time, I have to say that I am a fan!
author: Siao W.

description:
Good, cheap eats...I like Wing Lee Bakery.  It's the only place I know of where I can spend $1.00 and feel completely full and satisfied!  As a matter of fact,  I went there the other day on my lunch break and bought several succulent morsels, including my fave, chive and shrimp shu mai.  

I also bought the greasiest sesame balls they could offer me and stealthily stuffed them in my bag so my co-workers wouldn't mooch...yum!   I love those balls...even though they turned my purse translucent and see through.
author: Kristina R.

description:
Mmm...yes!  Goooooooood Dim Sum ... hot and cheap!!!
