This is the spot I go to when I'm craving really good Har Gau!!  I used to think it was because they had the biggest shrimp, but they put some good fat in there too!  LoL!  The dumplings are bigger and more filled than other places and it does not have that fishy taste you sometimes get.  Yes, it tastes very fresh!!  Nice thin skin, too...not thick and not starchy.  

While you're at it get some Shao Mai, baked shao pao, steamed shao pao, spring rolls, egg custard.......

One time, I ordered a ton of stuff and when I was done the total came out to $11!!  NICE!

Don't forget to go to Schubert's a few doors down for dessert!!  Ooh, I think I will do my special Wing Lee to Schubert's trip today!!!
author: Ladi Da A.

description: I always stop by when im in the area. Parking can be hard to find, so I always try to go a little after they open. consistently quality dim sum. Especially love their rice porridge and har gow.
author: E S.

description: This place used to be good, but they've really gotten worse over the years. Was there just a week ago, had the Har Gow, the Chive and shrimp dumplings and the custard tart. The dumplings had overly thick wrappings and bland and measly fillings. The chives were cut way too big, the shrimps, almost non-existent. The custard tart was again mostly a thick shell, little filling. And why is everyone so impressed with $1.60 for 3 dumplings? Those are standard prices for dim sum on Clement. I recommend Good Luck Dim Sum on 9th.
author: V V.

description:
Decent prices for some dim sum~

Used to come here most of time in the morning for some dim sum when I used to work in the area.

The lady was nice and recognized my super handsome face after the first visit HAHAHAHAHAHA ok cross out the super handsome...

They carry the usual items, like ha gow, shu mai which had variations of pork or chicken, the shrimp rice rolls and some others. Their rice porridge is not bad too.
author: phillip w.

description:
I eat here a lot when I'm broke and desperate, and it's usually decent.. Hell, I just ate a steamed pork bun from these guys no less than 3 minutes ago. But here's the thing: sure, this place is cheap as hell, but I am never eating here again. I just experienced the most horrifying dining experience of my life.

The staff here wear rubber gloves at all times, but that's really just to create the illusion that they care about cleanliness. As I munched on my pork bun, I saw the two ladies poking and prodding each other's arms with their gloves. I'm hoping to God that they weren't comparing rashes. I kept eating, pretending it didn't bother me. After all, I'm broke and hungry. Then one of them went to the restroom and CAME BACK WEARING THE SAME FUCKING GLOVES. That was it. I threw out my bun and bolted.
author: Roman H.

description:
Okay so Dim Sum is to Clement Street as Burritos are to The Mission -- meaning people hold violently passionate beliefs as to which is the very very best of something that is basically indistinguishable from that which is being served next door.

So I am not going to go on about the bbq pork buns, or the egg custards, or the sweet rice balls. I am going to go on about the JOOK.  Because it is quite possibly the best damned jook on God's green earth.

Now it is true that I am not what you would call a jook expert, seeing as how the rolling hills of Central Pennsylvania are not so well known for jook. But Wing Lee has this special jook, the chicken mushroom ginger jook, which my 3 year old loves so much that it is the ultimate powerful tool for bribery and extortion. As follows:

"Big Red, if you don't stop that this instant we won't go get jook."
or
"Big Red, you can stay here in the ice cream parlor riding the mechanical pony or we can go get jook, which will it be?" 

...and you may think I am pulling your leg with that second one, except *this actually happened, and she chose the rice gruel over ice cream and mechanical ponies.* Spooky good jook.
author: Tailypo W.

description: The dim sum is OK. Its not bad, they typically run out of stuff so good to go there early. I asked lady if chicken combination bun had any pork. She said "no pork no pork" but off course the bun has pork sausage. The beef sui mai is good - no complaints!
author: Try E.

description: I give this place 5 stars because I could eat here everyday and be happy.  The dim sum is pretty greasy but oh so yummy, especially at the price it goes for.  When I want dim sum, this is the place I have in mind.
author: Nkauj T.

description:
This is my go to Dim sum place. I have tried other places and this is my favorite for togo dim sum.
Usually my pals and I stop in here then take dim sum over to the beach on a sunny afternoon. It's an amazing deal. For $10 you can feed two people. I love their shrimp and leek dumplings. Also they have baked and streamed pork buns.
author: Jennifer S.

description: Pretty good dim sum place.  Service is nice.  I think Good Luck down the street has the edge, but this is comparable.
author: Pig E.

description:
Har Gow, how I love thee.  The shrimpy centers they make here are plump with shrimpy deliciousness.  Unfortunately, their wrappers are like a big wad of gum.  Blech to rice-flavored gum!  

Some of the other dumplings are also yummy, but I can't get over the gummy wad of rice wrapper.

Baked pork buns are DELISH.  No downside.  Dough is sweet and delicate, and filling is full of pork chunks.  Woohoo for porky numnums!

I stop here kinda often considering it only warrants three-ish stars.  Can't explain it, but maybe because it's exactly midway between Smart and Final's parking lot and Green Apple Books.  Convenience wins!
author: Teal H.

description:
I have eaten Dim Sum before at houndreds of places. This one is by far the best in the Bay.  I seriously went there 4 days in a row and got the same thing over, and over, and over. 

$1.50 for three items, soda is .90 cents, sweet pork buns are .80 cents. AND the food is rocken'. 

Mix this with Green Apple books across the street and you have yourself a grand afternoon.
author: F B.

description:
Maaaan, since moving out of SF, I really miss Wing Lee. It was my favorite place to go and grab a super cheap / super filling meal. I'd recommend the pork siu mai, chicken kabob (sometimes a little cold, so try to get it when it's fresh), steamed BBQ pork bun (oh god yes), sesame balls, and shrimp thingamajig (har gow). You can get dangerously stuffed for $4. Come here with cash, as they don't take credit cards, and if you can, come in the early afternoon. It seems a little less crowded than the morning rush, and that's when they seem to replenish the waning supply of yummies with freshly-cooked yummies.

It's not the most relaxing environment... it gets crazy crowded and cramped, and you always have the pleasant aural sensation of the ladies behind the counter yelling back and forth with the ladies in the kitchen (they should invest in an intercom, I think). BUT: the food is soooo good. I've been to the fancier sit-down dim sum places in SF, and while they are okay, and probably healthier, I much prefer the cheap yummy fast-foodish stuff from Wing Lee. Sure, call me a barbarian for scoffing at your finest meats and cheeses, but sometimes you just want a goddamn Big Mac. :-)
author: Evan H.

description: got their chicken buns, a lot of chicken in it. pretty good
author: Ashley C.

description:
Dear Wing Lee Bakery,

Craving dim sum a little too late into Saturday afternoon/evening, my go-to dim sum place, Clement Restaurant, had already sold out of almost everything.  Walking home disappointed, we decided to stop into you, as you were still open and still had a decent line of people waiting for what was clearly a decent near-closing selection.

Your pork buns are delicious and by no means sub-par, but I still think I prefer those of Clement Restaurant.  However, your sesame balls were as good as anyone's AND still warm even by the time I got home, which is impressive.  

Best of all, though, were your MOON CAKES!  I'd never had moon cake before, and been meaning to try them for some time...and there they were, at the front of your bakery counter and only $0.60 each for a little 2-inch square!  We had the lotus and the black bean ones, which were both a delight--although, I prefer the lotus, which tasted to me somewhat like marzipan, somewhat like peanut butter, and somewhat like magic.  Wonderful, wonderful.

I will be back for more tiny, enchanted moon cakes soon and often.  The only trouble is wanting them too often, and fearing I might end up the shape of a moon cake myself!

Mooning,
Erin
author: Erin M.

description:
3.5 rounded up to 4 stars

I come here for take-out dim sum. The har gow (shrimp dumplings), siu mai (pork dumplings) and baked char siu bao (BBQ pork buns) are especially good here. 

There is seating available but I would recommend sitting elsewhere unless you like  eating in cramped and dirty spaces.
author: Trinh T.

description:
unremarkable fare. take out style dim sum. 
with a selection of about 20 or so items.

a few tables to sit at. generally clean and uncrowded.
it fails the bathroom test tho...
author: Cahaya S.

description:
There's been a long line of customers at the counter every time I've gone, and it's because of the greatness of the dim sum and the insanely low prices.  Yesterday, I got like two bagsful of all different kinds of stuff for just over $20.  Both the steamed and baked pork buns are great, the barbequed chicken on kebab sticks is always perfectly done, and the shrimp dim sum (the ones that look like seashells, with translucent wrapping) is really excellent.  (This time, the BBQ pork turnovers were a little on the bready side.) 

It can be a pain to park in the area, but it's worth it, I guarantee you.
author: moosedog i.

description:
This is the one Chinese bakery that the hubby goes to because the menu is in English... Other bakeries take note: english menus= more american customers, really more customers in general. Also, this place is pretty good for allowing you to point at stuff and ask what it is.
Hubby likes the pork bun thing and the shrimp thing... yes, those are technical terms.
Anyhoo. Its a pretty decent shop and REALLY cheap.
author: Tiffany M.

description:
Let's see here...

One order siu mai
One order potstickers
One order shrimp dumplings, and
One steamed barbeque pork bun

Oh, and a Diet Pepsi.  FOR LESS THAN SIX BUCKS!!!  Yeah!

That's my Wing Lee go-to meal.  I like this place a lot. Great dim sum and rock bottom prices and a very local flavor.  The complete opposite of those oft-touristed places in the other Chinatown (y'know the one closer to FiDi where us locals mockingly send out of town visitors to ... "Oh, yeah, it's genuine"  *snicker*)

Me, I'm all about value.  Wing Lee and my other favorite Clement Street dim sum stop, Clement Restaurant, gives me value every time I visit.  

And that's keeping it local.
author: Eileen P.

description:
Office mate and pal Peter  introduced my co-workers and I to Wing Lee and their hot little buns, and now we salivate in Pavlovian anticipation whenever we see him come into the office with that signature pink box.  God bless Peter; he brings a mix of the chicken and pork buns and some vegetarian and shrimp shu mai, and he does this at least once a month, to our utter delignt.  (incidentally, he also has many a donut day, and pie day, and costco cake day. . .well 5 BIG stars for Peter !!! )

I'll handily give four stars for Wing Lee and I'm not withholding the fifth star--just *reserving it* for the day I can actually go to the bakery itself and comment on the full experience.
author: Mark N.

description:
Date:  December 8, 2008 @ 12:06 PM

Occassion:  Craving for a really good jook

Ambiance:  Hole in a Wall Dimsum Place

Service:  Surprisingly friendly and accomodating to people who do not know the names of the dimsum.

Taste:  
1. Jook (Just how I like it:  thick,  with chunks of pork and hundred year old egg)
2 . 2 orders of plump shrimp dumplings ( 3 pcs each)
3.  1 order of dry tofu roll ( 4 delicious rolls filled with noodles, carrots and black mushrooms).

Tab: $8.45 for lunch today and tomorrow. (Yummy leftovers!!!)

Also available:  Meat buns, custard pies, sesame balls, diff kinds of dumplings and rice rolls.

Plus:  Accessible semi-clean bathroom.  Priceless while shopping on Clement Street.
author: Leah E.

description:
Wing Lee Bakery has definitely dropped down a peg or two since I last visited. This place used to make the best potstickers. Granted their shrimp balls and pork/beef balls left some to be desired but you could count on the Wing Lee potstickers. No more. 

Like the days of the styrofoam box and the pink plastic thank you bag, the good potstickers are gone. Oh and they're now more expensive too. 

I miss the good ol' days. Maybe I just grew up with a higher standard for Dim Sum.
author: Alexander L.

description:
Phenomenal value for money. This place is a gem.

Wife and I had a very filling dim-sum brunch here on a Sunday for a total of $8.

Pretty good across the board but of special interest - BBQ pork buns, Har Gow, Shu Mai, Chicken Dumplings.
author: Harsh X.

description: I've definitely come here before to pick up some pastries and dim sum but this time I grabbed a  single lotus cake for my boyfriend who loves lotus paste.  Every bite he took he had something bad to say about it albeit he ate it all.  It didn't seem fresh, the crust was a little odd, it's crunchy in odd places, etc.  Sigh....  So much for trying to do something nice.  Next time I will buy two and eat one to make sure it's up to par.  Everything is cheap enough that it's worth coming back.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
Alright, lets be honest with ourselves.  

Wing Lee is no fine dinning establishment.  The place is small.  The lighting is harsh.  The service and prices vary wildly depending on mood (I've ordered the same thing, every week, for a year now and paid anywhere from $3.02 to $5.60) and sanitation doesn't seem to be a major priority on anyone's mind (at least behind the counter.  I always think its cute that they take the time to wear gloves, but don't remove them to handle my dirty, filthy money.).  

That said, I effing love the Wing Lee Bakery.  If I wanted a fancy feast, I'd go to some of the overpriced sit down Dim Sum "Houses" found all over the City.  

I'll take the cheap (if variable) prices, the no nonsense attitude, the amazing rice balls and the screaming intercom system any day.  

What can I say?  I'm in love.  And sometimes love doesn't make any sense.  Sometimes you love something so wrong, that it just ends up being right.  Ask my boyfriend.  He'll tell you.
author: Jesse J.

description:
"Would it be wrong to get a rice plate?" 

When I hear my roommate ask me this, I know that greasy dim sum is soon in the tummy.  If you spend 10 dollars at the dim sum side and aren't full to bursting... well this is a family channel.

I get their chicken skewers, fried meat dumplings, beef rice rolls,  steamed bbq pork buns, coriander gow, siu mai, har gow, or other stuff, too, depending on how hungry I am.  I always try to get something new each time to expand my palette.

Go there for lunch, and you won't be disappointed - tasty, nice variety, friendly counter staff, inexpensive!
author: Paul B.

description:
We used to come here all the time for their lunch boxes that can fill you up for two meals for $5.  The key is to catch the server's eyes so they know you're there (they get very busy during lunchtime).  Don't dawdle with your order, they don't like you wasting their time much.  I feel like the quicker you order, the more they plop into your box.

Their dim sum is good, too.  I like the one with the spinach inside.  Oh, and their pot stickers are awesome.
author: Jenny L.

description:
They have very inexpensive, hot, testy staffed things for you.

Some things are priced for 3 pieces, but you can mix and match, and they honestly charge you for what ever you get.

I love taking their food and hot source to Golden Gate park and enjoy a picnic. 

The place has tables, but don't expect any style, but like a China town atmosphere.
author: Chacha M.

description:
This place *owns* take-out dim sum. Just a $1.40 for a set of three ha-gau, siu-mai, whatever else is sold in threes. Daan-taat (egg tarts) for 55c each. The large bao filled with chicken, mushrooms, laap cheung, everything-else-known-to-man for $1.20. Jin dui (sesame balls) for 50c (quite different from the ones you see at New Year, though). A nice cup of congee for $2 with everything you need, nothing you don't. The prices are great, the food is good, parking is there but like the rest of Clement St. it may be hard to get a spot, plenty of staff to keep the line moving - it's take-out dim sum at its very best.

Note: If you are new to dim sum, please know that most if not all take-out places do not accept cards of any kind, and when something is sold in a set of 3, it is sold in a set of 3. (EDIT: I've noticed some flexibility as of late.)  Also, there are usual order minimums before you'll get a plastic take-out box (usually 2 orders of dumplings - otherwise they'll just wrap it in plastic). Asking for anything else, especially if you speak no dialect of Chinese whatsoever, is futile. With that said, enjoy it!

EDIT: $1.50 now! Tsk!
author: Carl W.

description: I come here for the beef siu mai, shrimp dumplings, the chicken skewers, and the jook. It's decent food and convenient. Although there are plenty of dim sum places on Clement, I come here often because they're one of the better ones.
author: Mandy D.

description:
Good place for some take out dim sum. We frequent this location when we're unable to go to Chinatown.

They have one of the best chicken buns around. It's filled w/(of course) chicken, mushroom, egg, Chinese sausage, and cilantro (yuck!). It's huge so I only eat half per sitting. Tasty! Other good items include: sui mai, shark fin dumpling, chinese sausage bun, pork buns, and yellow cake. Good variety. Cheap. There's always a line, but they get to you pretty quick. 

There are some seats if you wish to dine in as well.
author: Veronica H.

description:
wing lee.. how i love thee... when i'm famished and low on cash any day... you deliciously take my hunger away...

okay. for real. dim sum to go might be one of the best ideas ever.

wing lee is amazing. so they don't understand english too well and i don't know any chinese. it's all good. the point and smile method is always successful.

my favorites are the pork buns. haven't tried the whole wheat ones but hopefully will soon. the har gow (shrimp dumplings) are to die for. they certainly don't skimp on the shrimp (heheh, i apparently love to rhyme in review) and they are so freakin' tasty. and only $1.50 for three!! my other favorite is the lo mai gai. bamboo wrapped rice with chicken and mushroom and other delicious things and i could easily eat one of these every day for the rest of my life. oh man. 

the best part is that you can get an order of har gow, lo mai gai, and a pork bun for under $5!!! FTW! yes, i just typed that.

sometimes i just point at stuff having no idea what it is and have NEVER been disappointed. 

check out the other wing lee right next door for their roasted duck and crispy pork too. an all around good time.
author: Becky B.

description:
THIS "IS" the place for take out or even stay and people watch while you enjoy a bowl of authentic not showy sort of treats.  

Helpful services and WONDERFUL, fresh, always just the right TEMP that you would expect from a neighborhood low-key eatery.  Everything is delicious and priced so generouly so don't feel bad if you are so inclined to walk out w/MORE than you planned when you enter this place.

If you have time and have PARKED nicely, meter cops are VERY ACTIVE in this part of the neighborhood ;) ya know.  Check out their BBQ right next to the bakery, on the Corner.  Order small plates if you please :p
author: LindaLu N.

description:
Why oh why must your baked pork buns be so full of fat? Every other bite is a bite of fat and no meat at all.

But your shrimp dumplings are nommalicious.
author: Wendy M.

description:
No no no!  

I first ran into this place's dim sum when I attended the book party of "The Fortune Cookie Chronicles" at Swig in March 2008.  The organizers provided dim sum and at that time I was really impressed with the siu mai (pork dumpling) and hai gao (shrimp dumpling).  So I asked the organizer where he got it.  

Since that time Wing Lee has been on my list and I finally got to it yesterday.  But I was super disappointed.  My dim sum was cold but that can be fixed if you ask them to reheat it.  

But the worse thing was the taste and preparation.  I think one of their selling points is to make the dim sum entree big and cheap to attract customers while forgoing the taste.  With my hai gao, they did have a big piece of shrimp, but the flour covering was even bigger - thus this was not tasty.  Their taro cake was even worse.  It was undercooked!

Dim sum, which is really a collection of light chinese dishes, on steroids is great!  But make sure it tastes great too.  And since this place didn't pass my taste test, needless to say, I'll pass on this place in the future.
author: Alan T.

description:
Almost gave Wing Lee three stars just 'cause it's so cheap, but then I thought about what really matters to me when it comes to dim sum. I'll happily pay more for good dim sum! So two stars it is.

Got a wide selection of the dumplings, which are always my favorite. Overall they were oily, cold, and the flavors were just so-so. If this was the only dim sum place on Clement street, I might go back someday. Since it's not, I'm sure to try someplace else next time.
author: yolanda y.

description: for the price you pay, the food was more than worth it. it was super cheap and very filling and good. i would go again.
author: Bowen W.

description:
This place is great for take out dim sum.  Their prices are very reasonable...and everything is always made so fresh.  My family and I come here for their siew mai, ha gao, and their sticky rice balls (not sure what it's called in Chinese).  Simply put, this place is reasonable and convenient when you can find parking in the area.  

When dining in at Wing Lee, they place your dim sum on a piece of wax paper and place everything on a pizza tray.  It's the cutest weirdest try I've seen for dim sum.  But hey if it works? 

Come here for dim sum to go, or quick bite to eat.  Prices are insanely reasonable.
author: Cass J.

description: The only thing this place has going for it is that it's dirt cheap. And you get a lot of dirt for that cheapness.  The food is greasy - but cheap.  The seating area is plain, no frills, not even napkins - again, cheap. The servers all seem to wish you to the ends of the earth, and I don't like paying someone to yell at me, especially when I'm giving them money.  All in all - pay a buck or two extra, and go someplace where the food is better, cleaner (hair in your rice noodles ain't no fun, especially when it's not yours), and easier parking, and you'll have a much more enjoyable meal.  Total thumbs down on this rat-trap of a place.
author: R.B. W.

description: My daughter and I have been going here for Dim Sum for about 7-8 years now.  It is very convenient being right across the street from another favorite, Green Apple Books. The food is really cheap, delicious and fun to eat. The people watching is good too. The dining room is just a simple place with a clean space to eat and a bathroom on Clement Street.  The real deal!
author: Effie F.

description: Cheap but food was dry and not very tasteful. I am definitely never going back. Also the server was very rude. I ended up throwing away one of the buns because I really didnt like it.
author: Eunice J.

description:
The dim sum is excellent, fresh, and insanely cheap. For smaller items, the price listed (usually in the 80 cents range) is for an "order", which is usually 3 pieces. It's hard to spend more than 3 bucks here.

The pork bao--a baked or steamed bun stuffed with sweet BBQ pork--is 90 cents, frickin' amazing, and a good hand-holdable, non-messy snack you can eat while you're walking around Clement St.

Don't be scared off by the line that's almost always inside, it moves very quickly. This place is awesome.
author: Nick G.

description: Cheap oily dim sum that used to be better than what they taste like now. I would avoid this location and go to the dim sum place two blocks down, by Walgreen's.
author: Theresa D.

description:
MMMMMmmm so so good!!!=0) I love this place!!! I always get the same thing-pork porridge,rice balls,chinese donut,and mini cabbage & pork buns(for mini me aka my kid) I usally go in the morning b4 the traffic(around 8am),  I order a tub of porridge and plop my butt down on a greasy seat and stir in sum of that slightly disgusting looking hot sauce. I usually get a seat near the mirror, in hopes that I will pace myself if I see myself inhaling my porridge, but it doesn't. 
Then a line starts that looks something like the line infront of Glide church during feeding time, they typically look hungry and dirty. I look up at the hungry people and shamelessly continue scarfing down my porridge like a lil piggy. oink oink baby!!! 


On the other side of this great dim sum spot is the next door bbq and whatever else is greasy under the sun. I think they share the same name as this dim sum spot. Anyways my family and I was wondering around for dessert after us having dinner on clement. We looked into the window and saw the nastiest, meanest, and fattest RAT!!! Yes I said it ladies and gentlemen and I was 100% sober!!! This rat was the mother load of them all. She was definately pregnant, she was the equivalent of a cross of a cat and a rat. To make matters worst, we spotted her slimmer younger brother scrawling around. I never ate there again!!
  
Slightly concerning because I am not sure if they share the same kitchen. I never dare to peek behind there to see.
author: Nancy K.

description: One of the best, cheap, to go Dim Sum places on Clement. Their steamed Cha Siu Bao (Pork Buns) are easily the best ones on Clement. Their service is great, they speak better English than the people at Good Luck Dim Sum, and they're actually kind of chattable. I love coming to both here and Good Luck when I'm buying dinner or lunch for myself or friends. 5$ goes a long way at both to get me full.
author: Ari F.

description: Rock bottom prices...as far as S.F. is concerned.. and good tasting dim sum. Not bad for a little take out place.
author: Orlando J.

description:
If you eat $5 worth of this yummy dim sum you will be miserably full. 

If you eat $7 worth of the yummy dim sum, you may not be able to move. 

Eating more than $7 worth could be dangerous.
author: Kathryn T.

description:
Best dim sum take-out place in the city!  At $0.50 a piece, you cannot go wrong here.  I usually like to mix and match my orders so that I can get a variety of things.  The wraps on their dim sum are really thin, moist and have the perfect texture.  Also, their shrimp always tastes fresh, unlike some other places I've been to.

My favorites:
- har gaw (shrimp dumpling)
- pork shu mai
- shrimp & leek dumpling
- shark fin dumpling

So delicious!
author: Katelynn L.

description: I'll admit that all I've tried from this place is their BBQ pork buns, but that's all it takes to earn them five stars.  They keep them warm in this oven behind the counter which makes them that much more delicious!  They don't skimp on the pork, either.  If someone invites you over for brunch, stop by and get a box of these babies and everyone will LOVE you!
author: Eileen H.

description:
I'm not sure, but I think the prices are going up. It used to seem absurdly cheap, but now it's just cheap.

I think this place offeres the freshest dim sum on upper Clement st. The shrimp gow are especially good. 

If you order not to go, they give you your stuff on a metal plate which is kind of cool.
author: Ryan A.

description: Wing Lee NEVER fails! They have the best shrimp dumpling in all of San Francisco. $5 fills me up and I always tell myself that I can never get enough!
author: Linda T.

description:
Warning: You may feel discomfort and intimidation when deciding what to order.  Don't worry this is normal.  Just point, don't ask questions and everything will be ok.

Despite this, I really like Wing Lee and go here often for insanely cheap dim sum.  I have no idea what I'm eating when I eat there, but it always tastes good and I am yet to have ill effects.  Although, who knows maybe one day a mutant alien will pop from my stomach singing "Hello My Baby."  But, until then, I think we're ok.
author: Erica O.

description:
Can't go wrong with this place.

Come here, order what you want; or point if you don't know/speak.

Come early, park right up front. 25-cents gets you 10min on the meter.

I walked out with $16 in food that can easily last me a few meals.
author: qirk z.

description:
The only reason for no 5-star stamp is because there are places where dim-sum is better for not that much more money. Full disclosure, however: if I walked up to my favorite downhome dumpling place and it was closed, I would probably sit down on the sidewalk in front and be very upset. Maybe even have a shaky lip.

We can't go around giving out 5-stars to everyone -- this is a subjective thing and although I really do love Wing Lee, there is some improvement to be made in flavor, which means that it could become a 5. Dammit, I sound like such a snoot right now.

I will say that I've seen other reviews and although some things are a little oily, I challenge the folks who think that to find the same exact item elsewhere in the City where it's less oily. I mean, come on now, it's traditionally-made dumpling that just cost you 50-cents. We're just lucky it ain't swimmin' in it when they hand it across the counter.

My faves are the coriander gao and beef siu-mai -- and I'll keep coming back because it's one the few places in town which makes all the traditional bao and dumplings with several meat options other than the swine.
author: D. R.

description: I now live seven blocks away and damn happy about it.  Went in for lunch and grabbed three shrimp gow and 3 of the hugest pork sew mai I've ever seen for $3.  Couldn't be happier.
author: Asha H.

description:
I usually stop by here during a day of shopping on Clement and its pretty good for what you pay. But since I've moved to the area I've gone a couple of times and noticed how rude the staff are. I don't know if its because I'm not Chinese and I don't know what everything is called, but it sucks either way. 

I went this morning to pick up a nice breakfast and I knew that I was going to order a lot so I asked for a to-go box. I saw that the woman in front of me was offered a box so I didn't think it would be a problem. Instead, the server looked at me like I was an idiot and threw all of my food into a plastic bag, which was exactly what I was trying to avoid. 

The experience wasn't all bad but unfortunately, the quality of service tainted my whole breakfast. I would recommend the baked pork bun and the shrimp gow (if its freshly made, mornings are best).
author: Shannon A.

description:
Congee here is good.
Cheap and good.
Had the Da Bao which was OK.  The innards were delicious but the outside bread wasn't dense enough.
The ham sui gok was crispy  but there wasn't much pork filling in them.
Two vitasoy drinks to finish them off.
$6.55 for two people you can't complain.
The women were very nice and had a good personality that makes that experience that much better.
author: Po L.

description: Love their baked char shiu Bao.  I like their Har Gow better than the ones at Lucky Dim Sum.  They seem to be bigger and better flavored.
author: Jim J.

description: Cheap delicious food - i'm a Dim Sum novice, but i'm pretty sure this is some of the best around. i had beef shu mai, pot stickers and a pork bun. They were all delicious, especially the shu mai - really really good, mmm. I left feeling very full and having spent around $4.00 - this place is awesome!
author: Ben B.

description: This place has really good tasting pork and thousand year old egg congee. They dont really give you that much in a container but it was pipping hot and enough to fill me up. I tried their egg custard which I was disappointed to find quite bland.
author: Helen L.

description:
CHEAP DIM SUM, not great dim sum.  I think the shrimp leeks and shrimp cilantro dumpling-thingies are OK, as are the baked pork buns.  The hagao are large but undistinguished.  The pork taro fried thing is pretty darn oily, even when freshly made.  

But it is damn cheap!  Hooray!
author: Daniel S.

description:
Every single time my parents drop me off at my BF's place in the city, we HAVE to make a stop at the Wing Lee BBQ next door for a lunch special (currently $4.75 including tax).  Two items over white rice, portions so generous it could serve two people for 2 meals, variety in dishes, freshness that is unparalleled.  They keep bringing out freshly cooked dishes and it looks like they only make it once because their rotating menu is hundreds long.  They always have the staples, pork hanging from a steel hook, ducks, broccoli and something, fried rice, noodles, etc.  But the curry chicken is so good even the British BF loves it.  The spareribs in black bean sauce has just the right seasonings and is not swimming in a puddle of grease like some places in the other chinatown.  

When I read someone else's review of the jook/rice porridge/rice soup, my heart skipped a beat.  Jook/rice porridge is comfort food to the nth degree for Asian people.  If Elvis had an Asian equivalent of his fried peanut butter and banana sandwich, it would be jook/rice porridge.  If there was an Asian equivalent to Mac and Cheese (simple, filling, hearty, child-friendly), it would be rice porridge/jook.  

The last time I was here with my parents, I got my prize.  The mushroom and chicken "rice soup"/jook/rice porridge.  How do they keep it so hot?  It's like an inferno in the core of the take-away container.  Hope is the only thing keeping the sodding plastic from melting.  The little spoon to go along practically begs you to wait before you attempt to put molten love in your mouth.  But of course I couldn't.  Wait, that is.  And I burnt my tongue.  In 3 different places.  And both sides of my mouth.

It was so good, I put it down when I was full, twice, before finishing the container.  One moment I was making the mindful decision to stop eating and I put the container down.  I blink and somehow, less than 2 minutes have passed and I'm clutching the plastic tub again, spoon somewhere between my mouth and that rice nirvana.  

The other stuff here is good too.  

But as far as I'm concerned, the jook/rice porridge has stolen my heart and tummy.  It shall forever be able to sooth my rumbly-tumbly, on hot summer morns, cold rainy days, when I'm feeling down, when I'm celebrating, when it's tuesday, when I'm nearby.  Sigh.....I could eat this forever.
author: Christina C.

description:
Extremely cheap take-out dim sum basically, and one of my favorite places to eat at when I lived two blocks away.

What initially drew me to the store was their yio tiao (literally "oil strips" which they call chinese donut/bread), one of my favorite snacks as a kid.  However, theirs aren't all that fresh usually (I think they make a batch in the morning for the entire day, and I usually bought them during lunch or in the afternoon.  It's always gone by dinner time).  My favorites are actually the steamed BBQ pork buns and their rice porridge (the one with preserved eggs).  Their custard tarts are alright, but there are better to be had from the various larger Chinese bakeries around Clement.
author: Yeh F.

description:
My boyfriend and I love coming here for dim sum. We usually always order the Chicken Siumei and the shrimp gow which is 3 for $1.40. The siumei is huge and does not have shrimp in it (since I dont eat shrimp but my boyfriend does!) They also have beef noodle rolls here for only $2! 
The dim sum here is good and prices are not bad. Make sure you get here before dinner time or else they may be out of what you are looking for!
author: Miss H K.

description:
Great place to pick up a snack after a day of shopping and walking around. 

The place isn't very clean, but the food is tasty, greasy and CHEAP. I wouldn't eat here too often, you might get sick.
author: Gladys C.

description:
As Goldilocks said after she wolfed down Baby Bear's porridge, the Wing Lee BBQ Pork Bun is just right!  They're not overly large, like at other places, and they're filled with chunks of meat, not huge chunks of gristle.  I personally think the fried rice dumplings are super yummy. 

And since I can only eat one other dumpling after a pork bun, that's pretty much where my story ends.
author: Robyn C.

description: You have to come here with a budget in mind else you spend every cash you have on you.  You can have a full course here-- sew mais (dumplings) for appetizer, congee and pork buns (steamed or baked) for your main course and egg tarts for dessert.  Point out everything you want or need and you're good to go!  They do have wheat buns which is a healthy alternative. But frankly, I don't see any difference because all other ingredients are fatty and oh so, delicious!
author: Mimi S.

description: The sesame ball I just ate was sad and tough. Why Wing Lee, why?
author: Jenn W.

description:
It used to be our top of the mind place for deep fried chicken drumsticks and lunchbox.  The drumsticks are so popular and the restaurant has to make a lot in a day to meet the demand.  We used to order 7-8 lbs for party all the time.  However, in the past 2 years, the price has been raised so much, from $2.75 per lb to $3 to $3.25...  We got 7 lbs for less than $20 in the past and now  possibly 6 lb for $21.

The lunchbox is also not the cheapest in the area any more.  The cheapest one is sold in the cafe next to Our Court Cafe on Clement at 11th Avenue.  But, the chicken drumsticks are the most tasty ones in that neighborhood.
author: Roserrele W.

description:
Get your ass over here and try the dim sum.  I can't tell you which one to order...some are better than others, but you'll have to figure that out.  What is ridiculous is you could feed a family of 5 for $10.   Sooo cheap and once you figure out what you like you'll be in heaven.

One recommendation.  The baked BBQ bun.
author: Shawn H.

description:
Every time I crave for some dim sum, this is one of the few places that I'd go to. The flavor and quality/quantity of the dim sum are good for the price. I like how their food are freshly made everyday and the turn over are quick. 
Come here with $10 and for sure you'll have a very full filling meal.
author: MC C.

description: I love this place because they are open until 7pm. Other dim sum places in the same here close around 6-630 so there isn't much of a selection at those places at those times. But at Wing Lee, the dim sum is still coming out fresh and hot after 6. My favorite here is the shrimp har gaw. Plus it's hella cheap!
author: Zherr-Anne A.

description:
Yes, the line can be long on a sunny day, but don't despair, it actually moves very quickly.  There's multiple people there to take your order so even the largest of orders don't become a bottleneck.  If you are inherently impatient though, just meditate on the food and say, "Soon you will be in my belllllllyyyyy".  It's only $0.70 per steamed pork bun, and $0.80 per baked.  

BTW.  Yeah, parking sucks on Clement, try one of the intersecting streets.
author: Johanan L.

description:
I absolutely love the barbecue pork puff pastry (80 cents per piece now)...it's light and crispy that you can see the layers then the center has the sweet sweet pork bbq. I also suggest anyone out there to try their skewered marianted pork with caramelized onions & green bell peppers...they're not greasy and it's really good.

Most of the dim sum are a good choice...I usually come here for the items that aren't sold by Good Luck Dim Sum...ahhh coconut cupcakes! ^_^...
author: Pauline L.

description:
This is our neighborhood Dim Sum take out place.  I really wished they delivered, but because they're so inexpensive, it probably doesn't make sense to.

I actually prefer this place over Ton Kiang's, but Ton Kiang's offers more types of Dim Sum.  The Wing Lee Bakery has better tasting Hai Gow and Shui Mai, just talking about it makes me want to go there now to get a taste.  

This is a CASH ONLY place and for the non-Chinese speaking, everyone behind the counter speaks/understands English, so don't be intimidated to check it out.  

There are only a few tables to sit at there, so its recommended to just pick up your favorites and go.  You can definitely get a meal for $20 enough for 4 people.  I'm happy!
author: Gina K.

description:
Good dim sum shop! I like how they have pretty much everything you want and the prices are soooooooo cheap..all the usual dim dum (ha gows, sew mai) are 3 for $1.50, and their selection is pretty substantial. They have 3 diff kinds of sew mai (chicken, pork, or beef) and they have some original gows too...like their taro gow..its hella good! Whenever I come here in the mornings, there is always a line...a pretty diverse line too...different types of asians (not just chinese), and caucasians too.

Heres a mini scorecard of some things I've eaten here:
Rice porridge: $2.25 eh..only ok kinda runny and the rice is a little gritty. 
Sin-Jook-Gurn (the beancurd wrapped  rolls): $2.00 for about 4 of them..hella good! Lots of flavor.
Potstickers: huge and also 3 for $1.50. Not bad, but I'd stick to the steamed dim dum.
Various steamed dim sum: good, and they also have an original kind of skin too..its more translucent and chewy but its good.
Buns: the most expensive thing on the menu...at 80 cents each. damn now that is breaking the bank. get the yellow custard buns! (nai wong bow) creamy and not too sweet...perfection!
author: Jessica h.

description: Egg tarts are 60 cents. Really, there's nothing much to complain about. Not the best egg tart I've had but definitely worth it for 60 cents. I would come back and order everything they have because i love oily buns, dumplings and cakes! And for such a low price...why not??
author: Lisa H.

description: I love eating at dim sum houses, but when I'm strapped for cash, I head out here and am full for less than $5.  Not much ambiance, but I'm coming here for the steamed pork buns, shrimp and chive dumplings, shark fin dumplings, tofu skin roll filled with clear noodles, vegetables and covered in what I think is oyster sauce. They also have decent Hom Sui Gok which is an acquired taste -- it looks like a football -- a fried sticky rice pastry filled with a bit of savory ground meat. For dessert I usually go for Jin Dui (fried sesame balls with red bean paste), Chinese egg tart or sweet rice cakes filled with custard cream or red bean paste (if you like Japanese sweet mochi, then give these a try).
author: Bodhi D.

description:
Wing Lee is my go-to place when I crave "to-go Dim Sum."  Most* Dim Sum items are good, come in generous portion and are very decently priced.  When I come here, I always order the same items which I know are good such as their pork Siu Mai (tasty and huge), their Shark Fin gow (delicious and plump), their Siu Lung Pao (mini steamed pork and vegetable buns - I love their soft and fluffy buns), on occasion their Egg rolls, and Lomai Kai (chicken sticky rice wrapped in lotus leaf - these are humongous here!).  

However, I would stay away from their *Ha-gow (shrimp dumplings) and any "gows" that involves a whitish-transparent wrapping.  These dumplings are hard to swallow given that the whitish wrapping, that contain the fillings, is really un-refined and super thick and heavy.  Eating these would usually cut my appetite right away.  So, I just stick to what I like to fully satisfy my cravings.  But if you really crave some Ha-gow, just walk a few blocks down to "Good Luck Dim Sum." They have good to-go Ha-gows there, with a more refined wrapping filled with generous shrimp stuffing.
author: Nadine M.

description:
The best dim sum dishes for the price in SF.

 It's NOT the kind of dim sum that you invite your friends to on a Sunday and sit down at a table and people come by with carts. It's the kind of place where you just drop in, between going to Green Apple Books and that store with the cheap kitchen stuff, when you're hungry and don't have a lot of time, but want something really tasty.

The har gao is excellent, there's usually a chive or leek gao that's also excellent, the pork bun is one of the best I've tasted, the sticky rice is awesome, and everything is priced right.
author: PF D.

description:
This place has changed a lot since they first opened.  I still remember walking by the joint and watching them POUR jook out of a kettle!  Jook is not meant to be poured by any means!  

I've been going to Wing Lee's for years, especially when I lived in the Richmond.  I'd go there at 7 am when everything was just being put out...order a few dishes and it'd last me for the day.  

Now that I live in the East Bay, I still return to Wing Lee's when I'm in my old hood.
author: J T.

description:
So this is my new dim sum spot...  I would TOTALLY eat this over Good Luck Dim Sum (which is raved about here on yelp... for what reasons I have no clue)

I went early this morning after picking up a beautiful cake at the wonderful Schubert's Bakery... The dim sum was sooo fresh (well, I guess any dim sum would be at 7 in the morning, huh?) but I've even gone later in the day around 11ish and the dim sum is STILL piping hot fresh!!

The place is clean... or cleaner than most cheap, small dim sum places... a place I would def. recommend!
author: Kimberly F.

description:
Where else can you get fairly good dimsum and pay $12 for 2 people??

 You can't really go wrong with Wing Lee, they've got terrific dimsum for a snack or a picnic or if you just want cheap eats. The dimsum is very much above average, the dumpling casings aren't too thick, the fillings are delicious, and its kept fairly clean; can't really ask for more.

Try the bean curd rolls, they're delicious, but remember to ask them to warm them up. The pot stickers are pretty darn good too.
author: Ramsey J.

description:
The Chicken Skewers are fantastic.  I usually buy all they have.

I really like this place; but, sometimes they can be off.  For example, my Shrimp (Har) Gow smelled like iodine.  Clearly, the shrimp were past their prime.
author: Roy C.

description:
I luv their dim sum.  Best value take-out dim sum.  Huge shrimp and pork dumplings.

For a cheap value lunch/snack , go to this neighborhood hole in the wall restaurant.  For a few bucks, you can try almost every dim sum dish.

CHEAP EATS !!!!!!!!!!!!!   GREAT FOOD!!!!!!!!!!!!
author: Raider J.

description: Oh my god this place is ridiculous!!  Good and cheap.....just like me.
author: dennis h.

description:
I have tried most of the bakeries and dim sum places on Clement.  Each one seems to have one dish that shines.  The steamed pork buns at Wing Lee Bakery surpasses all others.  The items are consistently good and well priced.  
Nancy A.
author: Nancy A.

description: If you have a craving for a few goodies they have a large variety and it is very inexpensive.  The quality is decent and definitely hits the spot.  Love to hit this place on the way home from errands for a quick snack.
author: Jennie M.

description:
This is my favorite dim sum place, and I'm not ashamed to say that I like the Chicken Combination steamed bun. It's got random pieces of everything in it.

Also, just like every other dim sum place, food is rediculously cheap. A full lunch costs just over $2.
author: Helen L.

description:
When I'm working in the city, and am craving dim sum...Wing lee definitely fits the bill.

The only thing is I always order the same things, har gau, steamed pork buns, siu mai and a sesame ball with black bean.  All are very good.

I've noticed that their meat in the steam pork buns are nice sized chunks of pork unlike other places.  Excellent flavor and the dough is not mushy.  

The har gau you get is stuffed with good sized pieces of shrimp too.  

Definitely Rachel Ray should stop here for her show "$40 a day".  Typically I spend $3 to $5 bucks ordering all of the above mentioned tastey morsels and it makes for a hardy lunch meal.  

Parking seems to be not too hard to find during the day.  Make sure you have quarters to stuff the meter.
author: John D.

description:
Great place to get cheap dim sum.  I always stop by here when I have to attend a pot luck dinner with white people.  

The left side of the store is a great place to go for a cheap budget lunch.  Rice, noodle and side of you choice for less than $5. Fuck Panda Express, get your Chinese food from a Chinese person!~!~!~
author: Sang K.

description: I love coming here, especially for take-out dum sum. This is probably the first stop my family and I make when ever we head over to Clement St. They are also reasonable with the price ranges. What I love getting the most here, is jook. YUMM! Its good on both chilly and warm weathers.
author: Sylvia b.

description: 3.5 stars. The combination chicken steamed buns (filled with ginger chicken, shiitake mushrooms, quail egg & Chinese sausage) are yummy and HUGE! I also order the baked BBQ pork buns and egg tarts when I come here. Everything is so cheap that I always leave with too much food.
author: Angie L.

description:
The shrimp dumpling skin is too thick and they use too much cornstarch so the inside taste starchy.  Good thing they cooked it fully or the taste of raw cornstarch will get them one star.

The sui mai is huge!  Flavor is okay.  This used to be my all time favorite sui mai from a take out place, but not anymore.  

As for the potsticker, I don't think they believe in discarding the outer tough leaves.  I've never had such tough and fiberous cabbage leaves in a potsticker before.  Again, too much cornstarch to bind the filling.

I didn't have a chance to try the buns.  But if the other three items are any reflection of the current quality, I'm not setting any high expectations.
author: D C.

description:
Yummy Yummy Yummy, I got dim sum in my Tummy!!  And Wing Lee has the best selection and quality of any bakery style dim sum joint, imho.  I know people are gonna talk about Good Luck Dim Sum down the street, and I think it's 6 to 5 and pick 'em between those two places.  The thing I love the most at Wing Lee is the Steamed Chicken Bun:

Ode to a Steamed Chicken Bun - Haiku by G.

        it's fluffy outside
  with tender chicken inside
    what more do you want?

thank you

The place is very busy so the food has a high turnover and stays very fresh.  The ladies who work the counter are nice and still manage to move a high volume of dumpling out the door in a short amount of time.  Keep up the good work, ladies!
author: Garrett C.

description: Best commercial JOONG (Chinese "tamale") that I have found.
author: Vera P.

description: I like this place. It is my go-to place for dim sum. The green onion pan cake are the best in the city. Next door, is a good place to grab fast veggies and steamed rice for lunch. I think it is the same owners. Great inner Richmond spot.
author: marcus r.

description: I especially loved the bean curd rolls which were nice and chewy on the outside and had a crisp filling on the inside. I'd never had the dry bean curd before or the wood ear in the filling. I liked their savory sticky rice balls too and filled up on just that. My friend also bought me some flat rice noodles with just shrimp in the middle. These came with sweet soy sauce. I was hungry too, but the dim sum was quite tasty.
author: Sara A.

description:
Wing Lee has probably the best pork buns in the city, and at 80 cents each, that's hard to beat. When your hella broke, or trying to save money before heading to the many bars around it, Wing Lee is the best choice you can make.

-try the shrimp leeks and baked chicken bun
author: Craw H.

description: After hitting up Good Luck Dim Sum a walk a few steps over to here! Where I grab their yummy sponge cake!
author: Karen T.

description: One of my two favorite places in the world to get bbq pork buns.  Quality product, not too sweet, not fatty or chewy bits.
author: Mark M.

description: As I was on my way to the bakery, walking down clement st, I came across a Chinese dragon dance on the sidewalk.  I love all the random chinese stuff on this street!  Anyway, this bakery is one of my favorite places to get dim sum. The food is tasty and fresh, the people that work there run back and forth from the kitchen to the front with the steamed goods because they go so quickly.  I love the pork shu mai (that are only $1.50 for 3) and the steamed buns.  I would stay away from the rice rolls though.  The people there work like they're in a rush (usually because there's a line), so it's best just to point out what you want instead of trying to pronounce things in chinese.  This place is authentic and a good place for a snack or a cheap meal.
author: Margit H.

description: Came here today to have a quick lunch before spending the day in San Francisco.  This place is typical of other Dim Sum places in the area and definitely a "Hole in the Wall". Super cheap for what we got. Service is fast and dim sum is okay. They have a few places to sit inside and will let you use their bathroom. Sodas are $1 a can which isn't bad these days. I would probably come back here for dim sum again when we are in the area.
author: Monica L.

description: BBQ pork was very good, bread portion didnt leave an after taste.
author: K P.

description: This quaint understated Clement st staple has been buzzing with excitement each time I've revisited to settle my dim sum cravings. Today, once again, I walked away with a full stomach and a satiated palate from 6 Shrimp and chive gao and 2 delicious sesame balls for the low low price of $3.50.  Just beware, this is one of those joints that uses the "and then" technique that will have you saying "and then!?.... uhhh ok ahhh alright and then some coriander gao... and then!?.. ok and then some pork buns.. and then!?.. ok and then some..." But you're forewarned so go get sum dim sum and enjoy.
author: Phil M.

description: Cheap dim sum!  I mostly come here for their rice porridge which is $2/bowl.  They have two different kinds - one with chicken/bits of mushroom and the other salty pork/preserved duck eggs.  This is the only place I know that serves the chicken porridge.  Very hearty.  Order a fried donut (yau tiao) to go with the porridge and you are all set!
author: Mick S.

description:
i've been frequenting this fast food style dim sum awesomeness since i was a oh but a wee recent grad with little money and no career aspirations.  not much has changed since 2002, and neither has this place.  you can grab all your dim sum faves - bao, potstickers, sesame balls, shumai (my ultimate fave) and a host of others - to fill you up for $5 or less.  i admit i'm not a dim sum connoisseur nor am i particularly well known for my taste in chinese food (my other favorite "chinese" restaurant is panda express) but this place provides food yummy enough for those of us who still delude ourselves into myths of fortune cookies deriving from the ming dynasty.

i'm subtracting one star for clement street for lacking parking in an already lame neighborhood
author: J.R. R.

description: Best place to go for quick, cheap food after browsing at Green Apple.  A girl gets hungry when she shops!  I wish there were places like this on the peninsula... sigh... Where else besides the city can you get dim sum and sio pao a la carte?  Do tell, especially if it's in San Mateo.  :)
author: jen a.

description:
I read the reviews, and was so excited to stop by this bakery with my husband during our trip to San Francisco. We waited in line, got 2 cold cans of soda from the case, and picked out our very inexpensive dim sum choices from a large selection.  The ladies used tongs occasionally and wore gloves with which they handled food and money indiscriminately.

Eating the first of the food - it was cold. Not cold like "Someone refrigerated this", but cold like food left on a counter for a couple hours before it's put in the fridge. 

The chicken was tasty, but I wondered what the repercussions of the food's temperature was going to be.  The shrimp sew mai was cold gunk wrapped in goo, and the bbq pork bun was flavorless except for the taste of uncooked dough and the pieces of fat in the tasteless bbq sauce. 

I really like food, and it's a memorable day when I don't finish or at least want to finish all my food. We made a memory - I threw away 1/3 of our lunch and continued with our day, content to leave the sad lunch behind us. 

A few hours later, the sad lunch came back! My husband threw up, and my stomach is torn up as I'm writing this.  

It sucked having our hopes up and then having a crappy meal that turned into crap in our bodies far too quickly. I'm not giving up though - I will find good, inexpensive dim sum that doesn't make my mouth and my stomach upset. And if you happen to find it first, hit me up!
author: Ana D.

description:
You cannot find a cheaper lunch in all of San Francisco. 
A BBQ pork and a combination bun will run you less than two dollars and they'll fill you up. If you want to have a more elaborate lunch, it wont run you more than five dollars. Don't expect gourmet dim sum or a nice environment here, its just good take-out lunch for a great price. Maybe 1 out of 5 times I've been here I've gotten cold and/or stale food, but 4 out of 5 times it's delicious and fresh, just the luck of the draw I guess. The dining area is a little lacking, I'd suggest getting your food to go. Also check out the aquarium/flower shop down the street, really cool.
author: john f.

description: My favorite "Chinese deli" on Clement st. Quick, larger sized dim sum and consistently good service (if you call taking your order and stuffing it into boxes or whatever ASAP "good service.") Some standbys to order: steamed or baked chicken buns, chicken sui mai, har gow, pork sui mai, lotus wrapped chicken and rice and of course for my husband, jook. He loves that stuff. I can always count on coming here for a cheap meal that will fill the both of us up in no time. Plus, next door they have the BBQ restaurant version of this place and their plate lunches are tasty, cheap and filling as well.
author: cora j.

description: Great ha gow - skin is soft and sticky, better than decent siu mai, good lo mai fon (sticky rice wrapped in a leaf). Ok service. Good dim sum place for a cheap and quick bite!
author: Christina B.

description:
Good , Cheap food here. My son loves their wings. we got 2 lbs this time. 
Chow fun is good as well as chow mein. 
CHEAP good chinese food.
author: Jeanne D.

description: We always come here for especially their shrimp dumplings---big shrimps! Be sure to also try their bbq chicken skewers as well as their pot stickers! It's very affordable!
author: cindy c.

description:
I was introduced to Wing (I'm on first name basis) by a full Chinese person, took some other Chinese people there-and they've all liked it. It's definitely cheap and good enough for a not too frequent lunch, because the food is greasy, no doubt about that.  Compared to Lucky Fortune and Golden River, Wing Lee is the drunk, almost hot girl at the party.  You know you can get her, you get the cheap thrill of getting (dim) some for so little effort, there's a plastic barrier, and you know you might get a little stomach ache later and possibly herpes.  Ok, you won't get herpes from Wing Lee, but I did get a massive stomach ache (first time after many, many visits) from what might have been from eating a piece that was pushed off the plastic sheet and was straight on the metal plate.  
Still, you can get uncomfortably full for very little money, for one person about $6.  Personally, I think from now on I'll enjoy Wing Lee responsibly-just for snacking, and always with the plastic sheet.
author: Mike U.

description:
oh you gentle dimsum giant, you. because of you, i was able to coherce friends into helping me move. i was able to trick them in to lifting extremely heavy objects up three flights of stairs. i was able to get them to move the couch a  little to the left because it just wasn't quite center. i was able to get them to load a uhaul with lightening speed and put together a bed made out of a million pieces. because of you, i was able to move a three bedroom apartment in approximately 3 hours. all of this because i told them i'd buy them tons of dimsum from wing lee bakery. your power is overwhelming, and for that i thank you.

btw... you can feed 15 people for $50. can you really beat that? i think not.
author: Aly L.

description: Whenever I can, I go to Wing Lee for the best pork buns,chive ha gow, & ha gows with large shrimp in them. Their sticky rice in lotus leaf wonderful too. I always eat there and take more for home for later.
author: Joyce S.

description: Quick stop and cheap eats of dim sum at Wing Lee. Pork buns are decent and so are the sesame balls.
author: Yan M.

description:
a buddy of mine came to visit from SD. hes in the navy. hes about 5' 6", stringy, like the cheese, maybe 120 lbs. but he eats. like. a lot.

we stop off at Wing Lee to grab some lunch. i pull out a ten and lay it on the counter. we start rambling things off, just looking at the menu, at the food behind the counter, just choosing whatever we feel like.

we leave with two bags, and three dollars in change.

god. this place rocks.
author: Darrell L.

description: OMGOSH I LOVE THIS PLACE! I'm from San Jose but when I'm in SF, i most definitely drop by this place in the morning for their steam pork buns. It is delicious! I dropped by this place my first time because my uncle and i wanted to grab some breakfast while waiting on another shop to open. I ordered their steam pork buns and was hooked. Definitely come to this place in the morning when their stuff is still steaming hot. The prices are unbelievably cheap! I got siu mai, hargow, steam buns and drinks for like $6. There's always a line leading to the door though so it's a pretty busy place. But it's totally worth the wait!
author: Lilian D.

description: Now here's an idea!  Dim sum like Koi Palace, but with 99.98% less of a wait (roughly 1 second as opposed to 5,000).  Ok, sure they don't have the same selection, and sure it's less gourmet, but when you need something cheap, convenient and comforting, look no further than these little bundles of joy.  I brought some Chicken Sew Mai and Sticky Rice with Pork to a picnic and everyone was wowed by my brilliant idea...too bad they were mostly vegetarians.
author: Wes M.

description: I love this place!!! The price is right and everything has always been delicious...I wish i was there right now stuffing my face...
author: Jimi S.

description:
Love love love this place! Been coming here for at least 17 years now. Great value, fast service, & yummy food. 4 stars because it's not the best service. Most of the workers don't speak English and I don't like to order of the menu. I guess I'm a bit high mainetance, lol. I like to point, ask questions, and pick what I eat that way at this place. They are used to most customers ordering in Chinese or in English of the menu. It's kind of funny that I have no idea what I'm eating most of the time at this place, and for the most part I've been lucky. There are a few items I don't like here, but not many. Maybe 2. I can get stuffed here with 1 other person for $10 or less. Seriously, it's amazing. Definitely one of SF's best cheap eats. I usually get parking on the same block, most of the time out front. I come for lunch. 

The satays are good here and I like there juices in the juice boxes for kids, hehe. I'm pretty sure they are cash only and close on the earlier side of the night. There's not a lot of seating. I think 3 or 4 table max. Most people get take out. They also have a decent amount of pastries to choose from if you have a sweet tooth. I'm usually too stuffed to try any though.
author: S A.

description: I don't know where else you can get large amounts of dim sum for such a great price. This is definitely more of a take out place than a sit down dim sum place, but I really don't mind. The also have the best baked BBQ pork buns around!
author: Lauren Y.

description: Wing lee oh wing lee,my hangover haven of dimsum delight,How i savor your savory treats.In the morning when my heads are a throbbin(hehheh)one thought of wing lee and im all right.call a friend for a ride as im too delicate to drive,20 minutes later and at wing lee we arrive.Wing lee oh wing lee you are my hungover hearts delight!
author: eamonn d.

description: This is my favorite take out dim sum in the city.  For 2 boxes full of dim sum it costs less than $10.  Unreal!  After I pick up my boxes of dim sum and chicken buns, I usually head over next door to the Wing Lee bbq side for the 2 item with steam rice special for $3.25.  After a few bites I get noxious.  Eat at your own risk.  I don't recommend ordering the rice noodle wrapped in pork, beef, or shrimp.  The filling is skimpy and the rice noodle is thick and flabby like my thighs.  I would stick with the hot buns and dumplings.
author: Fatty A.

description: God, I miss this place. I lived down the street from here and could get lunch for about $3. Not uber-gourmet but the value simply cannot be beat. Don't let the line scare you. It goes fast, and because they do a crazy volume of business, everything is always super fresh. (Caveat: sometimes this is not true RIGHT before closing.) Tip: the coriander gao also has shrimp in it (you'd think they'd advertise this?) and is super delicious. Highly recommended.
author: Jen X.

description:
Wing Lee gives the term 'ghettolicious' a brand new meaning.  This is as close as you can get to a typical hole-in-the-wall bakery / coffee shop that you often find in Tsim Sha Tsui, Hong Kong.  

Not much thought (or dollar, even) is invested on fancy interior (~what interior? think four formica tables with chairs), tableware (~what tableware? choice of clingwrap-lined metal plates or paper plates... the servers' first preference is paper plates.. however if you insist, they'll let you use the metal plates lined with clingwrap to minimize the washing afterwards), or dim sum carts (you line up in front of the counter, tell them what you want, and there they come in the box and plastic bag for you).  Bathroom has a funny unexplained smell and also doubles as storage for the bakery's cleaning supplies).  

All these savings, though, are reflected on the prices of the dim sum.  $1.50 for steamed pork bun that looks like it's on steroid (read: big and plump) filled with generous amount of sweet red chunky pork meat.  That same $1.50 can also be used toward 3 har gow (shrimp dumplings), or 3 siu mai (pork dumplings), 3 postickers, or a giant-sized lo mai kai (sticky rice wrapped in lotus leaf).  $8 for authentic Cantonese dim sum for 2 people, no tip (act as if you're in Hong Kong), and no waiting.  I'll take it any day over the guaranteed 1 hour wait at Koi Palace.
author: Ange L.

description: Dim sum is two essential things. Har gow (shrimp dumpling) and sui mai (pork dumpling). If you can't raise those first two children correctly, any other sibling is bound to be a bad apple. Wing Lee Bakery makes fresh and tasty har gow and laps the competition on Clement Street with its version of sui mai. Fresh savory pork flava, tender texture, no MSG hangover. Wing Lee makes the best hom sui gow (deep fried pork dumpling), too. A trifecta!  Plus, "Wing Lee" is such a classic name for a Chinese business. There's no direct English translation for "wing lee", but "Hell, yes!" is pretty close.
author: G M.

description: A great dim sum place outside of Chinatown. I always go here when I'm hungry & running low on cash. For a dollar something I can get full off my favorite combination chicken bun. I love the dough on their bun & that they fill the inside with a ton of chicken, a whole mushroom, a quarter of an egg , & quarter of a Chinese sausage. I like it better than the Filipino siopao than I am use to eating. Their dim sum is also good they have all the staples that I crave.
author: Maritess N.

description: Get the ones w/ chives and the tofu skin rolls.  The other ones are not so good.  The saleswoman was really pushy -- she kept stuffing everything in a container w/o waiting for me to order while telling me: "2 orders of everything?"  Our order came out $36 w/ no receipt.  I think she might have miscalculated and charged us more.
author: Conrad M.

description:
they are open super early and it is sooooo goood. 

the egg rolls are definitely on the greasy side; i wrap them in a napkin for a few minutes and the napkin turns clear. i love the bun filled with red bean. and the shrimp dumplings. oh and the pork bun. 

oh my gosh - you will not believe how cheap it is here!!!!! i am fat because i am broke and ate here too much.

come to think of it, i should come here for a good ol' greasy dim sum to cure my hangover!
author: Rosalee C.

description: Dang, this place is dope in a gangster kinda way.  but seriously, it's cheap as dirt and you get awesome food for a few quarters.  I like the pork buns the best.
author: christopher h.

description: Love this little dim sum shop!  I always come here when I'm craving a quick yummy snack.  For $1.40, you can choose three items, and they have an assortment of dim sum choices, from the usual hargow and shumai and sticky rice balls to things I don't even know the names of.    Whenever my parents come to SF, they load up on the pork and chicken filled steamed buns since these are tastier and cheaper than what they can get in their area.  You can always freeze them and steam them later for a handy no-fuss lunch when you're on the go.  There's usually a line, but service is fast and you won't wait long.  Be warned though, practically everything is cookied oil and is greasy, so if you've got heart problems....
author: Swirls L.

description: Great hole-in-the wall place to get your dim sum fix before checking out Green Apple Books across the street. I like the har gow and the pork dim sum. For hot food (chow mein, rice, chicken, etc) just go next door. Very reasonably priced.
author: Patricia M.

description: I love this place because not only are the prices super great (cheap!), but the food is delicious. I go here for the Baked Pork Buns and Egg Tarts...yum yum dim sum!
author: mae e.

description:
2 orders shrimp roll + 2 orders har gow, + 2 orders siu mai + 2  orders shark's fin dumplings + 1 bbq chicken stick + 2 Cha siu baau (one steamed, one baked) + 1 order sesame balls + 2 sodas + 1 bottled water = 4 fat asses and roughly $20 ($19.60). 

yes, we ate this all in one sitting. (3 girls and 1 guy, oh the shame).
author: Giselle U.

description: This place has good cheap food. If you need a full meal for under $5.00. This is one of the best places to go. One side is dimsum and pastry and the other side is noodles, rice and side dishes.
author: Dao C.

description: Came here for their noodle soup and pork porridge. They are pretty good and cheap, too. So, it was all good for me. The people who work there, can't speak english, but who cares when the food are good, cheap, and you get what you want to eat?!
author: Daisy S.

description: Yeah,, this place is good when you're too lazy to walk two more blocks to Good Luck Dim Sum, or stand in that long line. This place doesn't really have lines. They do have a chicken skewer thing that's really good. GLDS does not have it. I think their cha siu baos (BBQ buns) are tastyyy!!!! Right across from the 44 stop and Green Apple Books for a quick escape!
author: O K.

description: This place was fairly quiet when I came here except for the local morning workmen who drank coffee and stood outside gossiping about which house they were going to do painting and roofing for next. I went in to get some juk (porridge) cuz I felt pretty cold and hungry since I was on my way to work. Pey Dan juk with fried bread real, 1 order of shrimp roll, 1 order of beef siu mai really hit the spot. I took 3 steamed chicken buns with me for lunch. This came out to be about $10 even. I was like sweeet! I'm cheap but I love to eat!
author: Jason C. J.

description: In college, this was the spot for baked buns and dim sum!  I would usually buy a dozen of the steamed pork buns and take them home to my family. Now... not so much. I went there yesterday, starving, and I scarfed down one steamed pork bun and three shrimp dim sums. At that time, it was very satisfying.  It wasn't as satisfying at 400am when I woke up to an upset stomach.
author: Josie W.

description: They have really good dim sum here. 3 pieces for $1.50. The lines are pretty short because they have about 3 workers helping you. The pork buns are pretty good. They are $.90 each now. Yes they do freeze well.  The jook or congee with pork and salted egg is pretty good at $2.50.
author: Steve w.

description: ever since i introduced my mom to this place, she always asks me to take her here after i bring her to her doctor appointments.  she likes to stock up on all the different dim sum and bbq meats.  they have a wide selection of dim sum and baked goods.  this is my favorite dim sum place out of all the others on clement.
author: Sheri N.

description: Biggest, fluffiest, meatiest steamed pork buns in town. Plump, juicy shrimp and leek gow. Breakfast of champions! And you can eat yourself into a stupor for $3.
author: Fawn F.

description:
atmosphere: 3 (is this why you're going here?)
food: 4

my morning/afternoon/6:59 BBQ pork bun fix!

quick, reliable, relatively clean, tasty.
author: Miss C.

description: This is my favorite spot for steamed buns on Clement, as they seem to be the best ones I've tried.  The pork buns aren't as cloyingly sweet as some other places, and the chicken bun is full of big thick pieces of juicy, YES juicy, chicken.  The one I had had a nice big slab of white meat in there, no gristle,  and it was incredibly satisfying.  For 70 cents!!!  Gotta go back to try the rest of the goods.
author: Nadine T.

description:
Wing Lee - the best dim sum. Period.

Always fresh, even at 7pm! They make the softest noodle for all their foods, and even microwaving leftovers - the hargow noodle is still soft and NOT pasty! pork spareribs and rice is pretty tasty too, and the jook is top notch. I dont care much for what the inside of the restaurant looks like, only what the food tastes like.

Are you tires of tiny ass pieces of dried out previously frozen so called dim sum? Then try out Wing Lees - I ve been going here for over 12 years, and they have never let me down. and get this : they actually have chinese cooks unlike most restaurants - makes for a more authentic meal and better taste. 
Hands down the best.
author: rusty s.

description: This is one of the places I always stop when going to Clement Street. Even if it's between meals, you can always get just a little dumpling or something. I was not familiar with dim sum before moving to San Francisco 4 months ago, but I love that you can pick and choose pieces that cost mere cents and come away with a little baggy full of tastey little buns and dumplings. I love the pork buns, the shrimp gao and the custard tarts. The sweet rice things are the only thing I haven't enjoyed there, but maybe it's an aquired taste (though my Chinese friend didn't much like them either). I am also a little intimidated by the frenzied activity behind the counter and ordering kind of stresses me out, but I give those dim sum ladies credit for their quick calculating skills... Man, I'm craving a pork bun right now...
author: Caitlin H.

description: My husband and son and I tried wing Lee Bakery for the first time last week.  I didn't have much but, what we did try was delicious.  I had some amazing Ha Gao.  They even clean the shrimp and de-vein it before wrapping it..which most dim spots do not do.  I also had the most delightful, tangy, chewy, saucy Cha Su Bao (steam pork buns).  They were some of the best I have ever had.  We also tried the Custard Bao.  I think that they could use a little more filling.  They also were not as creamy as I like...this could be because it was late in the day of course.  My husband is chinese and we love dim sum so this really is hard to say.  But, I mean it.  We had eaten lunch before spotting this place so, we didn't get anything else this time.  Next time however, I plan to try their Whole Wheat Baos.  All of the savory baos come in whole wheat dough instead of white rice flour dough.  As with most take out dim sum spots...the counter is crowded and it is a challenge to get in and out.  ONE OF THESE DAYS...someone will design a better access for a dim sum to go spot:)
author: Erin S.

description: GOOD ASS SUI MAI! :D 'nuff said.
author: Jasmine T.

description: very cheap stuff here. their meat buns are less than a dollar. apparently the bbq pork one was good(i dont eat pork), but my chicken one was kinda nasty. the chicken was border-line raw looking. of course, my fat-ass still finished it but that's beyond the point. anyways, i also got a bbq chicken skewer for $1.50. it wasnt really bbq, but pretty darn good(and cooked!). overall, a solid place. very cheap, but stay away from the chicken buns...
author: Andrew T.

description: i have been going here for years and it always seems alittle sketchy in the way of cleanliness, but their dim sum are mostly pretty good.  just went there and BAD!  if you ever feel grit while eating CHECK cause in this case it was MUD!!!  yes mud in my dim sum, i wasn't aware there was this variety, as who really knows what are in the dumplings, but truth is there is one with the mud ingredient. i will never eat here again.
author: misskim f.

description: You all were not lying when you talked about this place on YELP!  It is worth every quarter you spend on the dim sum.  I recommend that you get the items that are sitting in the steamer, because dim sum tastes so much better when it's warm!   So I recommend the shomai, the shrimp dumpling, and the sticky rice balls that have meat in them.   Sorry if I don't know the formal names.  So economical!  And the dim sum pieces are extra large!  mmm. mmm.  mmm.  You can get 3 shomai for $1.50.  it's 1.50 per order.  you can mix and match. that's lots of food for 10 bux!
author: gem a.

description: i have 2 main jobs. one of them is an environmental journalist, which forbids me from wasting water or going on cruises (not like i'd want to). my other job is a holistic nutritionist, so i am not allowed to be seen in places like mitchell's or mcdonalds. i'll don disguises to sneak into mitchell's, but wing lee is an example of somewhere i'm not allowed. super cheap but extra greasy, kind of cold and rubbery, and there's just something funky about the food, like they use pigeon and say it's chicken. last time we grabbed dim sum from here i felt super guilty afterwards and had to repent with kale/seaweed salad later.
