author: Mary V.

description: tasty dim sum and porridge for dirt cheap.  nuff said.
author: Dan T.

description: ok, my review for this place is longgggg due.  easily one of the great spots to get your dim sum on for cheap - excellent shrimp dumplings and shrimp rice rolls.  their sui mai is better quality here than the other spots i've been too, their meatier and tastier.  when's the last time you got full for 3-4 bucks? me?...ehh, earlier today.
author: Paul A.

description: excellent dim sum. those fried coriander balls are perfection. its a no frills experience, dear wing lee. you order, they set it on a plate or to go container, you pay and satisfy the hunger. the great thing is that you still have money to go to green apple or get a cup of coffee elsewhere...
author: Faye P.

description: Cheap but actually good and filling.  It isn't like a greasy spoon either.
author: Misti L.

description: wing lee is an interesting entity. the food is all very cheep. some of it is not very fresh. but let's give them credit for selling hamburgers and chinese food at the same time. if my memory can place the prices they are about $3.00 to 5.60 for a pretty nice meal (that may or may not haunt your insides). a few stars for being super cheap (i am a bargain hunter), minus a few stars for being "not so fresh".   let's just say "i'll eat it if i don't have anything important or physical to do within the next few hours/days/weeks" which is never. cause i'm a hybrid.
author: Pflip W.

description: i love dim sum.  heck i love it even more when i can have it whenever i want and i don't have to wait for a cart to go by me.  Wing Lee is pretty good for what it is.  the pieces of dim sum are huge!  now taste... its hit and miss but it's 3 for $1.50 so i'm not going to complain that much.  I always get the haw gow, sui mai and yee chee gow.  I like them all except the how gow has alot of the white skin on there which is a major bummer so the skin to shrimp ratio isn't proportionate.  But over all I keep coming here.. maybe its because my chinese isn't that good and the people behind the counter don't make fun of me.  And they have pretty good suggestions if you want to try something new.  And if you feel like jook... for $2.25 you can get some pretty good tasting and fulfilling pork or chicken jook with duck eggs.  I am disappointed with the pineapple buns.  it was hard and well it looked overdone.  so for under 9 bucks i got jook    , a pineapple bun and 12 pieces of dim sum.
author: Jenn Y.

description: I often stop here for dim sum.  I particularly like their baked barbecued pork buns.  Also good is the sweet rice chicken wrapped in banana leaves.
author: Daniel L.

description: one of my favorite dim sum joints.  not quite as tasty as places like big lantern on 16th, but faster, cheaper and larger portions. (and still pretty damn good)
author: John M.

description: I read a lot of positive reviews about this place and saw where it ranked on citysearch and I was totally shocked by the low quality of some of the dim sum I bought there: not at all correspondent with the place's reputation. I got the fried taro dumpling: it was still freezing in the center, almost frozen.  The shrimp leek gow did NOT taste good -- it was very fishy and tasted off.  The shrimp gow was better, and I liked it. The char sui bao (steamed bbq pork bun) was good, although the ratio of dough to pork was definitely weighted towards the dough --  the dough was of excellent consistency, though, and taste. Overall, disappointed -- although it is cheap, I still expect quality b/c it ain't THAT cheap.
author: Tina S.

description: This is a great neighborhood spot with cheap eats. I've had the pork buns, which are a steal at 80 cents, and the spring rolls. When you're short on cash and crave dim sum, hit up the bakery.
author: andrea a.

description: There is one dish that I love most and Wing Lee has done a great job in making it. It is Chiu Chow Fun Gor. They are these steamed dumplings with peanuts, scallions, mushroom bits, and a little bit spicy sauce in them. I've tasted many fun gors on Clement, and they make the best. If you are looking for some different dim sum taste wthout shrimp, try Chiu Chow Fun Gor.
author: Eric C.

description: The best BBQ pork bun you can ever get anywhere and trust me, I have had a lot of BBQ pork bun all over the Bay Area and Silicon Valley.  The fillings are huge and not sticky like some other places.  They also have great porridge if you like these things.  If you do go though make sure to get there before noon for the porridge, they tend to be gone by 2pm.  If you see a long line, don't be discourage, it usually moves fast and you have your delicious and cheap meal within minutes of waiting.
author: Paul Z.

description: They make pretty good dim sum. The flour on the shrimp dumpling is nice and chewy, not hard like other places make them. Their pork su-mai  is pretty good. The steamed bbq pork buns are good also. The flour are soft, fluffy and a hint of sweetness. If you want good dim sum and cheap, this is the place for you.
author: thea k.
